아름다운 힐링 하이킹 게임으로서 언뜻 보면 ABZU + BioShock 같은 느낌입니다. 하지만, 유일한 차이점은 부스트를 쓰는 듯한 속도감입니다.(일부 한정)
개인적으로는 패드보다는 키마를 추천드립니다. (중후반 갈고리 뛰어넘기가 패드가 의외로 힘들더군요. - 개인차일수 있습니다.)
 스토리는 록키 산맥에 카누타러 왔다가 사고로 어떤 2차 대전 중에 벌어졌던 당시 미국 비밀 프로젝트의 흔적에 휘말려 자연과 환경을 위해 주인공이 노력하다가 결국 산봉우리 하나를 날려 먹고, 산봉우리 근처와 아래쪽 숲과 자연까지 싹 다 화마에 휘말리게 했습니다. 그리고, 주인공이 그 증거를 인멸시키며 게임이 끝납니다. - 농담인듯 농담아닌 농담같은 스토리 요약이었습니다.
 의외로 JRPG처럼 꼼꼼히 맵을 훑으시며 아이템 파밍 하실 필요 없어보입니다. 대충하시는 것이 오히려... 개인적으로는 차라리 아름다운 풍경과 음악에 힐링하시며 하시면 될 것 같아요~ ^^

39447874.review:
Mi sono imbattuto in Valley totalmente a caso. quasi un incontro ravvicinato del terzo tipo, dove non sai bene perché succede, ma accetti passivamente la realtà. 
Totalmente alla cieca decido di prendere, dando ragione principalmente all'istinto e non a specifiche ricerche come normalmente faccio.
Ciò che ho mi sono trovato davanti è un capolavoro, a dimostrazione che ogni tanto fare scelte  no-brain risulta vincente (ovviamente con moderazione).
Valley si lascia scoprire con il contagocce, per apprezzarlo e soprattutto comprenderlo un minimo, devi dargli fiducia; la prima mezz'ora - ora di gioco è un continuo domandarsi ma che senso ha tutto ciò?  a che minchia servono ste ghiande ? ma perchè devo resuscitare sto cerbiatto morto ?  Domande leggittime intendiamoci, ma non riceverai risposta fino a quando non dimostrerai di aver la pazienza per sopportare la tua ignoranza.
Quando finalmente avrai dimostrato a Valley di voler capire, ti renderai conto di aver di fronte un gioco di una profondità disarmante, non per le meccaniche in se che sono direi piuttosto semplici, ma il significato filosofico che hanno; in questo gioco esce fuori il vero rapporto tra l'uomo e la natura e muove una critica fortissima alla bramosia umana di sfruttamento del nostro pianeta.  
Dal punto di vista grafico, le ambientazione e la valle sono realizzate davvero bene, i paessaggi sono davvero suggestivi e si nota un lavoro pesante sugli shader per gestire luci ambientali e non; nota un po negativa, nonostante risulti appagante lo stesso, non può comunque passare inosservato la poca cura nel arrichire l'ambiente popolandolo maggiormente di specie viventi  tanto che può dare l'impressione che sia ancora un "work in progress".
Nota davvero dolente di questo gioco sono le performance e l'ottimizzazione, perchè con una GTX1080 se attivo SSAO a qualità HIGH il gioco va a calare drasticamente di fps, tanto che ho dovuto disabilitarlo e tra l'altro usare o meno tale filtro non percepivo particolari differenze.
Dal punto di vista dell'audio stiamo parlando di una realizzazione superba,  le musiche per me sono mozzafiato e unite ai rumori del vento, delle piante creano un atmosfera magica; pochi giochi mi hanno saputo dare una tale sensazione.
Visto che tendo normalmente a dare molta importanza al suono e lo trovo un parametro fondamentale per giudicare un gioco,solo per questo aspetto li darei un 10/10 senza se e senza ma.
Per quanto riguarda la difficoltà, si tratta di qualcosa di abbastanza semplice  che richiede in pochissimi momenti  qualche abilità videoludica in più, anche se il fatto di dover iniziare dall'inizio del capitolo quando crepi è una cosa frustrante in certi momenti, soprattutto quando hai fatto chilometri e magari sei quasi alla conclusione del capitolo e ti ritrovi a punto e a capo.
Per quanto riguarda la durata, Valley è relativamente breve per cui forse se uno guarda al prezzo in base alle ore di gioco, forse 20 euro li trova eccessivi ma ne vale davvero la pena ; purtroppo non offre alcuna rigiocabilità, a meno non ti piaccia contemplare il paesaggio e le musiche .


Se dovessi riassumere :

- PRO :

- una trama profonda e ricercata
- realizzazione grafica ben riuscita
- colonna sonora e comparto audio da manuale
- una meccanica di gioco ben congegnata

CONTRO :

- ottimizzazione
- ambientazione un po povera di contenuti, soprattutto sulla fauna o microvegetazione 
- scarsa longevità
- sistema arcaico di salvataggio

Voto 86/100

39373661.review:
Wow. 

Einfach erstmal wow. Nach dem ersten Durchlauf bin ich sehr begeistert von dieser eigenwilligen Mischung aus Open World und Jump'n'Run. Das Exoskelett macht echt Spaß und wird mittels Upgrades weiterentwickelt, was tolle neue Fähigkeiten bringt. Jedes neue Techno-Spielzeug wird ganz kurz erklärt, und dann gibt's kleine Teststrecken, wo man sich gleich ausprobieren und den Umgang mit dem Gadget lernen kann. 
Die essentiellen Upgrades kann man nicht verfehlen. Aber selbst ohne voll ausgebautes Exoskelett kommt man gut voran und überlebt die Story, die sich von idyllisch zu apokalyptisch entwickelt. 

Die Story ist unumgänglich, aber die Hintergrundinfos sind bis auf die allerwichtigsten Funksprüche eher im... nun ja, Hintergrund. Wer möchte, kann sehr persönliche Notizen suchen, über die meisten stolpert man sowieso irgendwie, und auch ohne die Fülle an Informationen kommt man gut weiter. 

Ein paar knackige Stellen gab's für mich als Novize im Bereich des Springens und Laufens, aber ein innovatives Wiederbelebungssystem und sehr häufige Checkpoints vermeiden stundenlanges Probieren, bis man endlich den richtigen Winkel etc. getroffen hat. 

Empfehlenswert ist eine leistungsfähigere Grafikkarte als meine, was aber heutzutage sicher kein Problem darstellen sollte (meine ist einfach alt, ich sollte das so langsam einsehen :P). Ruckeln verdirbt die tolle Aussicht und macht es schwer, den einen oder anderen Sprung richtig einzuschätzen. 

Mein Fazit: Vielleicht nicht das neueste Spiel, aber lohnenswert, besonders wenn man es für wenig Geld im Sale ersteht. Sehr schönes Flair, große Spielwiese und eine Story, die bestimmt nicht neu ist, aber gut erzählt, und das Austoben mehr lenkt als einschränkt.

39357358.review:
Somewhere straddling the line between the creative locomotion of [i]Mirror's Edge[/i], the noir-soaked, recording-heavy storytelling of [i]Bioshock[/i], the tongue-in-cheek 40's nostalgia of the [i]Fallout[/i] games and the platforming adventures of Lara Croft and Nathan Drake sits [i]Valley[/i]. I would even say that those comparisons hold up fairly well in [i]Valley[/i]'s favor and the game manages to find its own distinct personality alongside those giants. In fact, the only criticism that I could make of this game would be that, for a game that only takes somewhere between 4 and 5 hours to complete (and probably still under 10 hours to complete with 100% of the upgrades/collectibles), it's a whole lot to take in and can, at times, feel a little bit schizophrenic.

[i]Valley[/i] was at its best when I was tearing down a hill or flying through the air in the L.E.A.F. suit. There are a few upgrades that enhance your ability to traverse the environments, but the core loop of building up speed on a downslope and launching myself off a ramp to travel hundreds of feet through the air never got dull. Blue Isle's ability to convey the sensation of that speed is really something that you have to experience for yourself, it's just that much fun. The (numerous) indoor sections of the game, while interesting - if you're a fan of WW2 spy intrigue or weird/supernatural sci-fi, the game's plot is definitely a strong point here - slow things down and left me wanting more of that open-air freedom.

It also has to be said that the soundtrack is damn near perfect for setting the game's (many) moods. As stated above, the game goes through more than a few tonal shifts in its 5-ish hour playtime and I never once felt that the music was jarring or out-of-place. During the slower, more emotionally charged, moments it was a somber piano-heavy score with some beautiful harmonies while during the faster moments it became a mix of traditional and wooden percussion with a fast-paced pan flute melody that perfectly suits the feeling of speed and nature. Later, as the story took more control and the game wound towards its climax, it turned to a more traditional string orchestra and percussion setup to really push the urgency of what was happening.

If there were one thing I wish could have been included in [i]Valley[/i] it would be a free-play arena, custom designed to fully take advantage of the locomotion abilities that the developers (obviously) worked so hard to get right, especially as a way to wind down after the game's tense climax. That said, [i]Valley[/i] is truly a great game and I would recommend it to anyone looking to fill a few hours with some fun and intrigue.

39356964.review:
This game is extremely underrated.

Pros:
Beautiful graphics
Unprecedented soundtrack and sound design
Gameplay mechanics are fantastic

Cons:
Not long enough
The combat feels like you're sucking your health away to attack enemies (which is literally what youre doing)
Combat fairly clunky

This game is something I expect out of AAA developers, not indie. At the start of the game, when you first reach the top of a hill and can see over the valley, was a breathtaking moment. The shaders and textures were fantastic. This soundtrack literally adapts to what you're doing. I was running across water when one of the main two facilities, Astra, (the other being SOMA) sucked the life out of the world. The music seamlessly adapted to a darker, more suspenseful and dramatic tone. I don't know why, but that blew my mind for some reason. The LEAF suit mechanics are extremely fluid, and with each new upgrade to the suit I feel like more of a god. Your suit uses energy for everything, from double jumping, to using a grappling hook of sorts, to attacking enemies. When you run out, you die. Because of that, the attacking enemies bit is a bit weird to me. You have to give the enemies your energy to actually attack them, and even then you may accidentally take the energy back from their more docile form and then they go ballistic on your ass.

But regardless of the cons, the game feels like you're in a movie. You play as a character who finds bits and pieces of information about researchers who were here before you. You yourself are the narrator, which feels like the best type of game. You're discovering things as you go, and it feels like youre the character discovering it yourself. The feeding grounds boss fight--while not particularly difficult--was one of the most mindblowingly amazing boss fights I've ever played in a video game, because of the visuals and the way my character moved and adapted to its attacks. This game is fantastic. Get this damn game.

39345491.review:
Contrary to what I expected, this game ended up being very similar to a walking simulator, with an emphasis on movement (a running simulator heheh). If you don't like walking simulators, or don't enjoy games with a gameplay based solely on high mobility, then you probably won't enjoy Valley. However, if you do like any of these genres, give this a shot. The closest comparison I can find is "A story about my uncle". If you enjoyed that game, you probably will enjoy this.  
Valley has a beautiful art direction. The graphics are nice to look at and there is a lot of attention to detail. The music is masterful. It isn't always present, but when it is, it goes so well with the moment it actually suck you into the action with it, making things epic. The story is a bit farfetched, but nice to follow with all the notes scattered around. The gameplay is fun and reactive, however the isn't really any difficulty. The game is on the short side if you're not a completionist and don't like spending hours finding every last collectible and secret.
All in all, Valley is a nice experience and worth it's price on sale. But you'll find yourself wanting more in the end. These visuals and mechanics in a longer and harder game could be amazing.

39344001.review:
Played it through in ~6 hours.
Grabbed it for 5 Bucks and it gave me alot of fun in those few hours. So grab it at sale!
For 20 Bucks its too expensive for the short, fast paced fun.

Gameplay: 5/5 Stars

Fast paced Jump&Run. Exactly what it proclaims. Yeah you can take/give Life, but you don't need to, except to give life for the Door-Tree things. Jumping and Running is the heart of the game and it really feels like it. Doing massive leaps while running at high speed, running on some kind of railroadtracks through underground tunnels.. Pure bliss!

Graphics: 4/5 Stars

Pretty good Graphic, looks nice, not the utmost best, but very good.

Story: 4/5 Stars

Decent Backgroundstory, fun to listen to the tapes and even reading the letters, lying around.
No Twists and so on, but i don't think Valley needs those. For it tries to be, it's good.

Sound: 3/5

Not very good balanced. If you play the game on standard settings the music will blow your head off. 
A few musictracks, but they aren't really needed. The ambiente of a waterfall and lake etc on the other hand is excellent.

39331165.review: Before I state anything about my opinions on this game, they are undoubtedly influenced by my having got this game on sale for $5.00 instead of $20.00. That being said, holy cow is this game fantastic. Granted, it is short; It took me about 4 hours and some change to beat the game, which sounds like a short time; and it kind of is. BUT, I haven't so thoroughly enjoyed a game from start to finish since The Witcher 3. Everything about this game is amazing. It's a first person, story driven puzzle platformer with a beautiful soundtrack and brilliant artistic design. Everything looks and sounds great. You spend most of the game blazing around the map in your L.E.A.F. suit, stopping periodically to solve puzzles, find lore, and just enjoy the breathtaking beauty of it all. I love what this game did with its limited time frame. The game is short, but with the speed at which you're traversing this gorgeous valley, it feels appropriately paced. I didn't leave feeling shorted, I left feeling a sense of wonder at how captivating a short, simple game can be. I really don't have anything negative to say about this game. If you find this game on sale, as I did, I HIGHLY recommend picking it up. Honestly, knowing what I know now, I'd be willing to spend the twenty bucks on this game, despite how short it is. I can't really say anything about the story or how the game plays out without spoiling it, because everything is interwoven in the storytelling. Just get this game. Really. Try it out.

39261127.review:
Valley is an unexpected gem of a game -- an almost-walking simulator with minimal combat, simple mechanics, a stunning soundtrack, and a movement system that makes exploration intensely fun. 

THERE ARE MILD SPOILERS IN THIS REVIEW SO READ WITH CAUTION IF YOU'D LIKE TO GO IN BLIND. 

The game sort of tricks you into believing that it's going to be a simple, peaceful romp through the valley -- restoring life to the plants and animals you find, chasing little forest sprites, doing parkour. The first three chapters have little to no conflict, luring the player into a sense of security before they truly reach the meat of the story.

In Valley, you play a protagonist searching for the mythical "Lifeseed", an artifact said to have the power to unmake worlds. Once you are strapped into your LEAF suit, you are then responsible for monitoring the life of the Valley around you -- collecting energy that acts as both your ammunition and your hit points. The interacting mechanic of quantum death keeps the player aware of their surroundings and constantly finding sources of energy to power their suit and protect themselves. 

The story starts out deceptively pleasant too, but eventually slips the player into the harshness of World War 2, and the desparation of a team of researchers and scientists desperately attempting to create superweapons to defeat the Nazis. The player witnesses the length of the project taking place in the SOMA and ASTRA facilities, all while dealing with the results of the Hubris of Man. All told in audio logs that have been waiting to be heard for years, the player looks in through a time vortex to see how the facilities came to be abandoned and how the Valley has remained a secret all the time. This game could benefit from a "suspense" tag. 

There's also a pretty impressive twist that made a choice I'd made under the assumption of it being the most moral one become one of the most horrific choices I've ever made in a video game. 

My only complaint is that the ending leaves a lot of questions. I want to know more about the "antagonists" of the game, and what happens in the aftermath of the climax.

39256035.review:
[i]Valley[/i] is a really rather nice little game. It's not exactly very long (roughly four and a half hours), but what is there is very good: the soundtrack is superb, the gameplay is quite enjoyable (although that being said, I am the sort of weirdo who quite enjoys first person platforming) with some real speed freak highlights, the enviroments are utterly gorgeous and the gameplay concepts like the global health bar and each death having direct environmental consequences I found to be really engaging and interesting. 

My one and only major gripe with the game is that the default FOV (which I think is also the FOV that the level designs were proportioned for) gives me a massive headache in much the same way that most source engine games do: Setting the FOV to minimum mostly fixed this issue, though the result was that I spent most of the game feeling like my viewpoint was about two feet off the floor. 

Happily, the game was otherwise excellent, and certainly worth the minor nausea playing it invoked in my visual cortex.

Ein toller atmosphärischer und mittreißender Soundtrack.
Schöne Landschaft.
Ungewöhnliches Spielprinzip: Stirbt man an einer Stelle, so geht der Umgebung Lebenskraft verloren (Tiere sterben, Bäume verdorren usw), welche man wieder auffüllen muss, um seine Leben zu erneuern.
Die Geschichte ist ganz nett, aber trotz des Mix aus SciFi und mythologischen Elementen nichts Herausragendes.
Die wenigen Gegner sind im allgemeinen keine Herausforderung, aber beim Kampf liegt auch nicht der Schwerpunkt des Spiels. Viel mehr geht es darum, durch verschiedene Methoden Hindernisse zu überwinden. Dies ist auch so gut gelungen, dass es einfach Spaß macht, in einem Affentempo durch die Landschaft zu rennen, über Hindernisse zu springen, Wände raufzurennen oder sich an Seilen durch die Luft zu schwingen, um an sein Ziel zu gelangen.
Nachdem ich das Spiel erworben habe, wollte ich nur kurz ausprobieren, ob es auch funktioniert. Es hat mich so gefesselt, dass ich prompt einige Stunden gespielt habe.
Wer ein rasantes und trotzdem entspannendes Spiel sucht, für den definitiv eine Kaufempfehlung, wobei ich dennoch auf ein Sale warten würde.
Wer aktiongeladene Kämpfe oder eine herausragende Hintergrundgeschichte sucht, langweilt sich hier hingegen wahrscheinlich eher.

39195457.review:
Wonderful and beautiful game. The story is very complete and the plot flows perfectly with the character and what he's trying to accomplish, but the developers made it difficult to determine where to go next at certain points in the game. All that aside, the suit is such a different concept that most gaming companies don't incorperate, which involves momentum and planning your next move before you hit the ground, and the game mechanics shine in that area with precision enhanced fun (if you like games like rocket league). There are also colectables throughout the entirety of the game for people striving for all the secrets and lore of the world, with some upgrades to help you along the way as well. The story and mechanics work nicely; however, the enemies are a different story, they are repetitive, bland, and very very easy to beat, but again they are very unusual and scary at first which was interesting and suspensful, and then they started to become annoying in the end. Also, the end boss doesn't necessarily complete the game's sincerity, which is why I would recommend playing this on a higher difficulty if you're looking to play for a decent amount of time or for a fun challenge. Altogether, I recommend this game on sale especially for $5.00 because it is a breath of fresh air if you're looking to take a short break from other games. 

Summary: It's a very fun game and is definetally worth your time which I recommend, but very short with fun mechanics and upgrades through the game, also with slightly repetitive enemies and pretty easy. Buy it when it's on sale!

39193127.review:
This was a last-moment addition to my Winter Sale grabs, and it's been the big surprising best of the bunch so far.  This is an awesome little game.  It's absolutely gorgeous.  The controls are smooth and enjoyable.  Additional abilities are introduced well, and at an easy pace.  The plot develops through automatically played audio clips, but is expanded by optional written pieces you can find in various areas.

Don't go into it expecting high-difficulty play - just about anybody could finish this.  However, the parkour aspect is handled well enough that you can put yourself to the test, and find complicated ways to do things that the game provides paths to do simply; climb tough areas just for the fun of it.  There's pretty minimal replayability, but it really doesn't suffer from that at all - it tells its story and does it well.

My only real problem with it was that true save points are much, much too far apart.  While when you die you respawn basically in exactly the same place, if you ever have to close out the game, you'll be restarted at the beginning of that area (although it does save collectibles progress) - and some of the areas are pretty sizable.  It meant I was reluctant to start playing sometimes because I wasn't sure I'd have time to get to wherever the next 'stop' might be.  Would've helped to have a proper save-at-this-spot mechanic.

Highly recommended if you like exploration games with enjoyable movement mechanics.

A bit misleading at first seemingly like walking simulator but becomes more of parkour as you progress.  Has elements of a 3d platformer type game with visual and gameplay elements similar to Ori and the Blind Forest with a narrative style reminiscent of Bioshock.  The soundtrack was wonderful and did a great job shaping the atmosphere of the various areas of the game.  While there isn't much fighting in this game, it is a bit of fresh air from all the other fps shooters on the market to have an experience not focused on combat.

I would highly recomend this game but suggest getting through the first few areas first before deciding if this is a game for you.


Extras - Two items I would request of the developer to possibly include in the future:

   - A developer commentary to the game since there were some very interesting places and parts of the story.
   - VR version as it would be pretty incredible to be inside a number of the immersive scenes through out the game.

38860020.review:
First of all, it's not a yes, I recommend it, it's not a no, stay away. It's a MEH. But we don't have it here.

Buy it if you want a peaceful relaxing game. You run, you jump. You listen to the grass, the wind and the rustle of the trees. The sound of animals going about their business, not sacerd of you. You feel tranquility and peace.

The first levels of the game are about exactly THAT: PEACE. If you need some peace and quiet in you gaming, get that, you'll love it. It's beautiful, even.

Story buildup, however, suggest a turn to a more difficult, puzzle-oriented, one-mistake-you-die platformer. Yes, it has a story, and it's quite OK even.
But, well, I find myself unable playing this game too much at a time. A bit here, a bit there.
A part of me wishes more interactivity. A part of me dreads the (spoiler alert, but you get it from the get-go, so no harm, no foul) doomsday machine hidden in this valley somewhere; BECAUSE IT'S ALWAYS DOOMSDAY MACHINES, why, oh why.

It's not a bad game, no. It's not a masterpiece either. It passes the time, and if you're looking for a little peace and quiet, THIS is your go-to game.

38846119.review:
Valley is an amazing, beautiful gaming experience. This is just one of the best games that I have found here on Steam, and I happened upon it just because someone mentioned it was on sale, on Gamng on Linux. Graphically it is splendid. The level design is perfect: it is the outdoors exploration sim that I have been craving. The gameplay is awesome - so far it is about using your powers to improve life around you (imagine!) You are managing your environment to enrich and not to destroy, but not in a dull preachy way. It is just part of the excellent gameplay that makes you feel part of the environment as you are also moving through it.

Give you an example of the gameplay: you are in the woods, see that the trail leads down to a river, you run full speed down the path, the motion blurring happens and there is a sound of air rushing past you, you leap into the air - over the river - and down into some photorealistic trees that are swaying in the wind, with a crunch that can almost make you feel the impact, and a plume of dust rises around you.

That is one of the many just-so-happens moments that this game gives you, just moving from place to place. I am not even going to try explaining the really special things that Valley delivers. And it gives a bunch of cool ideas.

It is challenging and compelling. I keep looking forward to coming back for the worldbuilding, the story, the level design, and everything else. And I bought this at such a huge discount that I feel like I robbed the developers. This is one of the very few games that I have picked up on Steam that I would have really been completely satisfied to pay the full price. I just cannot say enough about how thrilled I am at getting a chance to play Valley.

38719922.review:
I'll try to keep this review simple for you.

PROS
-Amazing originality as far as mechanics and overall game design. Life and death play a key role in everything you do, in a really cool way.
-Characters with a pulse: despite typicalness of everyone in the game, they still felt lively.  Basically good voice acting and development, pacing was just right on it.
-Quantum puns and Schrodingers Video Game that never was but is at the same time. 
-Only a few hours of gameplay, but can easily see myself replaying once I'm done. There are also quite a few things I missed on the first run already, so there's a lot to explore here and there.
-If you like stuff that makes you go "woo", then you'll have a fun time with this one. It's one of those games you'd really love playing in an IMAX theater if you had the opportunity.
-You fucking control life and death.

CONS
-A bit redundant here and there. Once you get around to upgrading a few things and learning the overall controls, you find yourself repeating gameplay every now and again.
-It's clunky at times, not nearly enough to be unplayable, but enough to irk you when it happens. Easy fixing w/settings and such, but still a con.
-The enemies were awesome, but very limited for variety. There is basically a bad, baddie, and baddest. Although I did not complete the game at time of this review, may edit later.
-I didn't have trouble personally with it, but my buddy pointed out that this type of game is better on a controller opposed to keyboard and mouse. It's subjective, really, but he brings up a valid point. 
-The animations for the rigs and models aren't TERRIBLE....but sometimes cheezy. Would have made this game a lot better for atmosphere if they worked on it more before release.

TL;DR: 
It's a solid game, as with any steam game, try to pick it up on sale. If you enjoy first person adventures and interesting little stories that have yet to be oversaturated on steam or by hollywood, it's worth it. It's no gem, could have been a little more worked on, but has replay value, is borderline fun, and at times was even reminiscent of classics like Portal. 

8/10 acorns for this game.

景色非常非常美，音乐非常非常好听，跑起来也非常爽，尤其是后面连续加速飞起的隧道。音乐和场景的配合也特别好。没什么难度，剧情也中规中矩，当成散步放松的休闲游戏是非常不错的。但最惊艳的反而是通关后片尾放credits时的原画设定图。

Just an all around very good game. Pleasantly surprised (not that I thought it was going to be bad, moreso I expected average and it exceeded that).

Gameplay/movement is very fluid and downright fun. Each new mechanic is added in a perfectly paced gradual progression.
Soundtrack is absolutely solid and suits the game well.
Visuals are great, the valley is beautiful.
Story/writing is nothing too incredible but is satisfying and again, suits the game well.

Side note: interestingly enough in terms of atmosphere and (at times) aesthetic this game felt very Bioshock (and that was welcome); there were lots of places where the influence was obvious. Just the mechanics are of course drastically different.

38640456.review:
It pains me to do so, but I'm not gonna give this a positive review. There's plenty going on here to warrant a purchase, but in the end there's a single problem with this fast paced action roller coaster...

Essentially they give you a race car, but ask you to use it in a jumping game. You typically can't see where you're going (always a hill crest in front of you) and the ramp is usually super short (forget going fast often).

There are two parts of the map where you really get to open things up and have some fun. Let's just assume those parts last 5 mins... you're left with 4 hours and 55 minutes of bumper to bumper crap to complete... most of that time is spent reading meaningless diary entries to flesh out a story that clearly occupies more lines of code than that little bit of fun you had a few hours ago.

There's a great game not in here.

38625011.review:
Since the beggining, the game has stunning graphics and glorious cinematic music that is worth obtaining. By looking closer, some textures look odd and the games has no real antialiasing and the creatures look creepy and like from child book. But the graphics are overall very great! The storyline is intriguing and exciting to hear, tape by tape. Altho I haven't finished the game, I am very excited about the ending. About the movement which is the main part (since it's a parkour game), the momentum is easly killed and overall the movement too smooth to be realistic. On the other hand, I enjoy the rails (gotta go fast!) and jumping across the lakes. It's a game using the Unity engine tho, it's something to bear in mind.
Combat also has more potential, since the L.E.A.F. suit was designed during the WW2 era - but it's purpose (excavation, probably) negates it. There are some enemies, like the swarms and the creature that keeps on walking through me and that's when thaughts about poor combat comes to mind. 
Many people describe this game as too short, tho I can't say anything about it 'cause I haven' finished it yet. I don't want to post much about the story (so, no spoilers), but the story is intence when you do something that should do good stuff and it makes something bad happen. Keep that on mind.
It's not a shooter, it's not a "walking sim", it's just Valley!

[i]Overall:[/i] [b]Good[/b]

For the measly 4 euros I spent on this on sale, it's very well worth it. A first person platformer(!) with a focus on exploration. Very chill to play and environments look great and immersive. It's quite fun to run down cliffs and make huge jumps, it makes for a certainly different than usual experience. The death mechanics are pretty unique too, the more you die, the more the world around you dies, so you wanna avoid dying or all the pretty trees and animals die. :P (though I've barely had any deaths since I'm so MLG, so only seen a few trees drop leaves so far).

It could use a bit more interesting collectables maybe, but it's still fun to explore around since the environment isn't restricted much. I wouldn't consider the game utterly mindblowing for what it does but if you want a little different story/exploration rich 'FPS' experience, can't go wrong with it.

38555104.review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review

PLEASE NOTE (2017): Due to recent false accusations of plagarism, I (the reviewer) would like to stress that all these reviews and upcoming reviews are original and are not blatantly copied. Other reviews are used to help stress my point across but are changed in such a way to make the review in my own wording [/h1]

Valley is a game developed and published by Blue Isle Studios, the same developers behind the remake of the Slender game called Slender: The Arrival

This game was... a hugely pleasant surprise. When I bought this, I thought it'd just be a nice, pleasant experience. I adored this game, and played it from beginning to end

The physics are fluid, and the exhiliration  is amazing. The graphics are fairly good especially the overall environmental graphics, but I noticed a few frame rate drops here and there in certain areas. Overall, it's a beautiful game though

When you first see the valley in the game called... Valley, it's really something, and you might even amaze yourself with its wonder and beauty. The environment around you is absolutely beautiful and astonishing since it was created on the Unity engine

The gameplay is really fun and exhilirating and the achievements aren't actually that hard if you're into that. Absolutely recommended for anyone looking for a pleasant, fun, and slightly short gameplay experience

Valley has a somewhat interesting yet cliche story with some really fun and fast paced gameplay and some beautiful scenery and the ability to backtrack easily

Sadly however, there is no real replay value, just exploring the valley once you've finished, it's sadly really short, clocking in at only two hours long even though I wanted to play more and from what I saw, it's a bit pricey but it's definitely worth the grab during a sale or when the price drops

38477495.review:
[i]Valley[/i] is an exploration game/platformer that gets one thing right: it understands that movement itself can be fun if it's cool-looking and fluid enough. There are issues, of course (clipping and invisible walls are unforgivable in a game about freedom of movement, and what's up with the camera often sliding down to the character's crotch level?); but generally, the jumping and movement in [i]Valley[/i] feel great.

The level design is hit and miss. Mostly levels are great to navigate. However, there are two different types of levels in [i]Valley[/i]: some are fast theme park rides that want to pump your adrenaline with special effects, speed, and huge jumps; others are calmer and reward exploration. The issue is, they play completely differently, and it's not obvious at first glance which type of level you're on.

I did, however, very much love the final run, that has you traverse a huge exploration-based level that is collapsing around you, turning into a linear path. It's a smart way to add spectacle and wink at the player, while making it clear what is expected of them.

The mechanics are numerous, but added gradually, so as not to overwhelm the player. And while it's definitely not a walking sim, it actually felt like one to me, since most challenges felt easy, and the mood was very relaxed; more than anything, [i]Valley[/i] invites you to absord the atmosphere, look for secrets, jump around, and hug trees.

Unfortunately, the setting and story of [i]Valley[/i] are... shall we say, confused. They combine a mystical valley inhabited by Ghibli-like cute magical creatures, a Greek-named bomb, the Aztecs, a random explorer finding a military-grade suit, a semi-serious plot about a scientist competing with Oppenheimer, but also a plot about his fellow researcher trying to sabotage their work because the bomb HURTS THE TREES. It's an incomprehensible mess of references and styles that wants to be mystical, gritty, thoughtful, social, and emotional at the same time—but ends up just silly.

Still, if you don't pay close attention to a supposedly serious military researcher qualifying the newly-found source of unknown energy as 'cute' and thus worth more than human lives, [i]Valley[/i] provides an array of nicely-looking locations, good atmosphere, and fun, if easy, parkour. Would definitely recommend waiting to buy this on sale though.

Весьма  странный  прыжковый  симулятор.  Нам  предоставляется  возможность  побродить  по  пустым  долинам  и  заводам  в  занятном  экзоскелете,  который  по  мере  продвижения  по  сюжету  обрастает  новыми  возможностями  такими  как,  например,  двойные  прыжки  и  бег  по  металлическим  поверхностям.  Сражений  как  таковых  в  игре  нет,  ибо  всё  крутится  вокруг  возможностей  закачивать  и  выкачивать  жизненную  энергию,  в  связи  с  чем  встречи  с  агрессивными  тучками  и  призраками  заканчиваются  накачиванием  в  них  этой  самой  энергии  до  полного  насыщения.  Главной  же  опасностью  является  наша  собственная  криворукость  и  падения  в  пропасти  или  воду.

Управление  с  одной  стороны  удобное,  вот  только  находясь  в  очередном  затяжном  полёте  очень  сложно  рулить,  но  разгоняться  и  прыгать  наш  костюмчик  умеет  отменно.  Собственно  на  прыжках  и  строится  большая  часть  игрового  процесса.  Особых  проблем  с  нахождением  пути  нет,  все  локации  выполнены  линейно,  хотя  никто  не  мешает  заглянуть  в  сторону  и  найти  записку  или  тайник  с  энергетическими  ячейками.  Возможность  оживлять  и  умертвлять  деревья  и  животных  могла  бы  стать  интересной  фишкой,  но  особого  использования  ей  в  игре  не  нашлось,  разве  что  от  наших  смертей  природа  потихоньку  загибается  и  теоретически  может  лишить  возможности  возрождения,  но  это  надо  очень  постараться  так  накосячить.

В  двух  словах  «Valley»  –  игра  на  любителя.  Если  не  заморачиваться  поиском  секретов  –  проходится  за  5-6  часов,  отторжения  не  вызывает,  но  и  в  памяти  надолго  не  задерживается.

Плюсы:  захватывающие  дух  затяжные  прыжки.

38394031.review:
This game is a fun little 3D platformer with high production values, and an engrossing (if short) plot line. It doesn't go out of it's way to kill you with punishing jump sequences, and instead focuses on providing cool movement mechanics and giving you opportunities to put them through there paces as you bound across the landscape.

The atmosphere was amazing, lots of great scenic outdoor locations, strewn with some ancient ruins and retro military-industrial facilities. The game is quite short, and the plot advances quickly, which keeps things fresh since you're constantly moving into new areas and aquiring encountering new mechanics.

I did find the combat encounters a bit weak, even the big boss went down easily on the first try, but ultimately the combat was more a sideline than the focus of the game so this wasn't a huge problem. Also there are collections-- I know some people like these, but I find they force me to slow down and poke around in all the out-of-the-way corners instead of enjoying the flow of the game. Not a fan, but your mileage may vary.

What makes this game great:

* smooth control mechanics
* great scenery and background music
* unusual plot concept

What's holding it back:

* combat not challenging
* collections

This is a fairly easy-going game where you are exploring a valley that was occupied by a military research facility during World War II; the military discovers new technology and seeks to develop a weapon using it.

You will navigate the game while utilizing some of this technology; there is quite a bit of platforming and plenty of story-related documents to be read. There are some enemies, but they're not particularly difficult to subdue.

I completed the game in around 5 hours and didn't run into any odd issues.

38290849.review:
This game reminds me of a cross between a walking simulator, Mirror's Edge and Portal. I guess first person puzzle platformer would be the best description. It's really short (which I liked) and looked pretty good. I thought the story was kinda meh (others may think differently, obviously) and by the end just didn't really care about it.

What this game gets right though is what I think it was going for: the awesome feeling of speed and momentum. That is what kept me playing to the end. It was awesome to run on rails that gave you superspeed, jump right before a giant hole, and fly through the air to the next part of the corridor. Awesome feeling... one that I don't think I've had in a game before. 

But in my mind, sadly there is a huge con...

It's made in Unity, and it seems to be quite unoptimized. I have an i7 7700k, gtx 1080 and 16 GB Ram, as well as have this  game installed to my primary ssd. As it's Unity it's very GPU based. My GPU immediately shot up to 99% for the entire game, while my CPU stayed around 20%. My fps would swing from 144 (rarely) and around 28-32 (most of the time.) Even if I turned own AA to medium, it would only push the average up to about 38-40. That's just unacceptable, especially in a game based around movement. Now, I will say that it didn't seem to lag even though the fps were as low as they were, but there's no reason they should have been in the first place.

Regardless though, I'd still recommend it. I had it on my wishlist for quite awhile, but luckily found it in a bundle. I'd be hard pressed to say $20 is worth it (for me, at least) but it's on sale all the time, so if you can get it for $5-$10 and have a couple hours on a rainy day, it's well worth it.

38272104.review: Meh. It can be a fun and beautiful game, but it almost feels like it doesn't want to be. Like, the whole 'you can shoot things to kill them or bring them back to life' is a cool mechanic that is absolutely never used in any way. And the whole 'there are things you can do to run faster, running fast is fun' idea came up a few times, and was so awesome that I don't understand why the rest of the game is spent walking around in dirty warehouses, looking for pieces of paper and acorns. What this game should have been was a breakneck-speed-sprint through a beautiful forest, dodging trees and other obstacles, sometimes killing them to get them out of the way, sometimes bringing them to life to let them help you. Instead, it's like 60% walking simulator.

38130475.review:
I bought this through a recent bundle deal and wasn't sure from the description whether I'd like it or not. It's quite different from any other 1st person game I've played and is quite relaxing to play in some ways. It's never frantic like a lot of shooters tend to be, the gameplay isn't that hard and the levels are enormous.

Pros:
The outdoors look fantastic and you get a real sense of size and space.
Easy to get into and play.
Gameplay is fun.
Levels and game is well designed and makes you want to play just one more mission!
Playing for 20 minutes turns out to be 3hrs ;)
The music is quite good (and really irritating too, see below).

Cons:
Controls! I'm a lefty and you can't change the key mappings (set for right handed players!) in the game. You have to launch the config utility for the game from within your Steam library in order to remap keys. What a pain in the backside that is!!! Oh, and if you launch the game any other way than via the library, it will ignore your mappings. From what I've read, this is a problem with the Unity Engine and not the game itself.
Music - every time I launch the game, I have to go into options and turn the music off. Even though it's set to silent in options, it still plays! Some new levels loading cause the music to start playing again and you have to turn it off, again. Really, really annoying bug!
Linear - Ok, so the outdoor scenes are massive and look open. You can explore as much as you like and there are hidden crates in some odd places. The problem is that despite this illusion of it being an open game, there's only one exit to each scene/level/mission or whatever name you want to use. It's a linear game dressed up (cleverly, I might add) as an open world. That is a con because I don't like linear games and yet hasn't spoilt the game because it's well hidden in the level design.
Variety - I think I'm almost near the end of the game after 4hrs+ and it is becoming a bit samey now. There's just not quite enough in each level to keep me as interested as there was to begin with.

All in all, a very good game and it does deserve all the positive reviews and praise. Full price is currently just under £15 and I don't think it's worth quite that much. For me, just under ten would have been more realistic.

38096599.review:
I have thus far played through what I take to be the majority of the game and have really enjoyed it. I have found it to be refreshingly different from anything else I've played. Its free flowing movement system and clever way of unfolding the narrative are very well paired with an affective music score and beautiful environments. I do have two particular gripes with it however, which have given me reason to write this review granted that I don't usually bother to do so. 

Firstly the save system is pretty old school in that you start at the beginning of each level whenever you load up the game. It's not an awful hindrance given the fast pace at which you can traverse the levels, but it does seem to be an unneccesary bother. 

Secondly and most significantly is the lack of reward for exploration. There is a MASSIVE potential for exploration in this game because of its sprawling level designs and the way in which the L.E.A.F suit enables you to traverse the environment. I have continually exploited this, but am very rarely rewarded for it. There are item pick-ups throughout the game, but the vast majority are in plain sight. There are also "acorn doors" which are non-essential to the games completion and the majority of these are in plain sight too. I wonder if the developers have done this to encourage a fast paced playing style, but given that the game lends itself to that naturally I think they ought to have made room for a slower pace too. I have continually felt let down that my exploring yields no extra reward and feel as though the developers have gone to the trouble of designing something huge without providing an extra incentive to explore and make the most of it.

All of that being said the pros still very much weigh out the cons here. I have been continually drawn back to the game to unfold its story, environments, sounds and game mechanics.

38093844.review: Fun game. Could use some polishing but for what it is, it's pretty good.

38075560.review: I have to admit, I almost dismissed this game.  It has two things I absolutely hate, head bobbing and no manual save.  I almost said forget it.  But, I gave it another shot and got the L.E.A.F. suit and suddenly didn't notice the head bobbing anymore and the game just opened up.  The lack of a manual save however does give it some bad marks.  I had to redo stuff often because life got in the way and had to stop the game.  You devs HAVE to start putting in better save systems.  This goes across the board.  Not just this game, but a huge chunk of games popping up these days.  A large portion of the gaming community are adults with jobs and families.  They will turn away a game they can't progress in because they have to keep repeating stuff to get where they were.  Putting that aside though, the game was beautiful, the music was great, though very loud, the gameplay itself really interesting and enjoyable and I really enjoyed the story.  Mechanically, the audio had a little trouble with the music volume increasing on starting up the game and in some sections. ( The volume slider didn't really do what it was supposed to do.  Had to fiddle with it a bit which meant I missed most of the music, because sometimes it was blasting loud and other times completely silent.)  Overall I would say the gameplay reminded me a little of Portal 2, without going into spoilers, I'll just say, the recordings, the past, the ruins all gave me that same feel.  It was really fun.  I did really enjoy it and I do recommend it.

配乐非常棒(特别是跑铁轨那一段，有点小震撼)；关卡设计有意思，整个空间的利用率很高；游戏画面还行，远景特别美；整个故事的来龙去脉逐渐地通过笔记和录音来展现。但游戏有点小BUG(有时会卡在某个地方不能动，声音的定位有点奇怪，游戏加载有时也可能卡住)。总体来说“Valley”是一款非常优秀的独立游戏。        8/10

37985953.review:
First time playing I spent an hour and twenty three minutes on the game. It just sucked me in and I lost track of time. It's a slow game, with little if any danger. But the movement is satisfying, and the story is intriguing. I saw that some people disliked the fact that you usually need to stop running to loot, but I generally see it as a choice that only needs to be made once. What I would like to see from the game is a reason to re-run every area at least once without looting before I'm done playing. That said, the momentum and movement are enjoyable and the looting only gets ever so slightly in the way.

The graphics are beautiful but not overwhelming. The music is well composed, and I barely noticed it because it set the mood quite effectively without being in the way of the plot. And the game sounds were mostly good apart from a few of the character footsteps and a couple waterfalls or wind gusts or something. Occasionally there was something going on that I couldn't see, giving it an almost eerie feel. I'll be putting more time into this game than it requires, just because I enjoy the movement and atmosphere.

Edit: For reference, it's kind of like A Story About My Uncle in play style. Lots of platforms and jumps. Grapple mechanisms and such. And a lost world that seems to have been left behind.

37984104.review:
Rating: 8/10
Genre: First Person Platforming

The Good:
+ It is obvious from the opening scene that this game has beautiful scenery and environments to explore. The environments are a mix of forestry, mountains and indoor facilities.  Furthermore, the game does an excellent job of mixing up the environments between each of the 8 levels. 

+ Level design stands out; some levels are more linear while others are more open. 

+ The platforming feels fantastic, running and jumping around feels fluid and natural. 

+ Exploring the levels carefully rewards you with upgrades 

+ The story is told through audio logs and documents scattered throughout each of the levels. I found the story to be engaging and interesting and has a satisfying climactic conclusion.  

+ Soundtrack 

The Average:
+/- This is a short and easy game. If you don’t care about collectables or replaying levels then you are looking at around 5-6 hours game time. 

+/- The game features some very light combat. You shoot a couple of shots towards the enemies and they die. It doesn’t distract from the game nor does it add to it either. 

Conclusion:
This game was on my Wishlist and I got it in a bundle and I am glad I got to play it because it was a joy to play and I loved every minute of it. Highly recommended!

37982757.review: Dude, sprinting and jumping in that suit is probably one of the most satisfying game experiences ever.

37977388.review:
It looks great and plays great. Playing through the story is relatively quick(finished in 2.5 hours) other than that, I really have nothing to complain about. I honestly enjoyed the story to this game. It's played in the form of tape recordings that are qued at certain points within the chapters. The story is alos backed by bits of lore spread throughout the environment. Yes you can speed run through a good portion of the game, but you may find yourself missing out on some plot points.
 
For the most part the controls are smooth and easy to use(sometimes I found myself overshooting a platform). Since you're piloting an exoskeleton that grants increased speed and agility. And I actually feel it. The physics of the game are based on momentum. Running down hill, you will see a significant increase in speed. Running uphill, you slow down. This in turn will affect jump height and distance. 

 The suit is upgradeable throughout the story to include a grappling hook, jump boost, push rods(makes for a fun sequence running through tunnels) and more. There is also the use of an energy based life-death manipulator. You can use it to bring dead things-trees, deer etc- to life or take the life from organic objects. The suit operates off energy that comes in the form of glowing orbs around the environment or you can retrieve this energy from living creatures if you need a boost in a pinch. 

The combat is, well, simple. There are four types of enemies(5 including a boss fight) and these are normally won by using the life-death manipulator against them. 

Overall, I would recommend this game. I had fun playing it, and if you're into platformers and parkour type games, then this one should be up your alley

37974991.review:
What an incredible experience. Imagine if Valve still made games instead of hats, and was contracted to make a first person Metroid game - this is how it would turn out. I could not put it down, and finished it in one sitting. The LEAF suit gives you an incredible sense of speed, mobility, freedom, and weight. Nothing has ever felt as good as running in this game, especially during one spectacular sequence. The dynamic music is not only memorable, but swells at exactly the right moments to make you go, "Wow." The story is there, it's non-intrusive, but still quite interesting. Gameplay comes first, as it should. Valley wastes no time getting you into the mechanized suit and letting you loose on this gorgeous world with super-powers. The art direction is phenominal, incredible attention to detail, great lighting, great atmosphere. Really, just overall a exceptional game.

This is an overlooked classic. How have I not heard of this game before? Yes, it clocks in short at 4 hours (without collecting all medallions), but it's 4 hours of non-stop excitement, awe, and wonder. Do you want 4 hours of steak, or 12 hours of spam? This is a steak, and you won't forget it.

The harshest critique I could lay against it is the limited replayability because of the linear progression.  But, don't let that scare you away.  Play it, and you just might find yourself coming back to enjoy the ride again after some time has gone by; I know I will.

37909502.review:
Valley is a great game that gives you a feeling of freedom, not in the sense of choices necessarily, the story is pretty linear. Instead the L.E.A.F. suit your character wears gives you a liberating feeling of movement. When I first was able to run in the suit, going extremely fast downhill while the music picked up to a cheery little tune I couldnt help but smile. You can jump high, run fast, skim over water- the environment feels like a playground in itself. While it does pose a few dangers (dont go too slow over water or you'll sink) it never feels nerve wracking. 

There is little in the sense of combat, a few enemies here and there as you go through the story, but they are all relatively easy to beat. I didnt mind. The puzzles of how to use the suit to move forward in each area were plenty for me. 
The story is quite intriguing, slowly being painted as you move along. I found myself worrying what was going to happen to these characters, even though you're only contact is listening to old recordings and readings of what happened. They did a great job making a story you want to keep going to uncover.

37740688.review:
This has been on my wishlist forever, it seems. It looked intriguing, but I had this nagging feeling it was going to be like Myst, and I'd never get it done because I'd just eventually get board with the games needed to progress. Last night I had a few hours to kill before heading to bed and this was on sale for pretty cheap. Reviews were all very positive and I read it was a fairly short play through so I figured I'd get it finally and play for a bit. 

I was not prepapred for the wonderful, beautiful, intriguing, enjoying, and exhillarating whirlwind of a ride I was about to embark upon. 

Long story short, I was up till 1:30 am because I just couldn't stop playing. I finished the game, start to finish, in 1 sitting, not getting all the achievements, just a playthrough. It took approx. 4.5 hours and my 11 year old son even sat with me the entire time and we had a blast figuring out the next steps needed to progress, and just enjoying the the game in general. The power running sequences were, by far, our most favorite parts. 

To sum up, buy it! It's super fun, has very pretty graphics, easy game controls, multiple play through value, the soundtrack is gorgeous (really wish I would have purchased it with the game) and is just challenging enough to make you think, but not so much that you get frustrated and quit. A nice short game to just pass a few hours with.

37376828.review:
[May contain minor spoilers]

I nominated this game for Steam's "Mom's Spaghetti" award based heavily on the one of the best gaming moments I've ever had, that happened in this game. The about four minute non-stop, high speed run on electrified rails at the Soma Reactor was Pure. Freaking. Bliss. It certainly elicited a real physical response as I got shivers and a raised heartbeat. I replayed it. And I replayed it again. And again. I would sometimes boot up the game just to do this run - it's such a rush. Pretty on the eyes with the visual effects and boon for the ears with the sweet soundtack that played into the experience. From the story and universe standpoint this whole bit is near pointless, which makes me even happier that it was included in the game just to indulge the player in a bit of crazy fun.

Enough of praising that one part lol. I just love it, so well done.

I meant to write a review earlier but with this award nomination I simply had to (and give my thanks to the devs). Because that is what this game is - simple, rewarding fun. All the mechanics revolve around moving freely in the world and explore, they've been carefully honed to ensure a great experience. The character is very responsive and there isn't much to remember to maximize the focus on the world around you. The visuals are simply stunning, beautifully crafted levels - there's a ton of treasures hidden in the maps and the combat is non-existent to minimal so it's encouraged to take your time to enjoy. Kudos to the composer for an incredible, atmospheric soundtrack. It compliments the world really well.

My only complaints are the lack of a save system, the somewhat forced combat, and the "horror" elements of the later levels.
- There isn't a clear distinction where one level ends and another one starts, and if you exit the game at the wrong point you have to navigate through the entire level to get to the next one. It's bad design to make your player to commit to playing one full level, that can take 20-40 minutes, in one sitting if they want to progress. This was hindering my own experience.
- The combat, as many others have said, isn't particularly well executed. It was clunky and the preset of the game doesn't support it to make it a seamless part of the whole experience. The angry bug clouds I could understand, but not the stuff later on...
- By "horror" elements I mean exploring the dark indoor facilities. At some points I had to check if I was still playing the same game, and not something like SOMA. Atmospheric, sure, but when you spend most of the game in open world, and build it to be a mostly peaceful experience, it's a notable shift in the mood. Of course the storyline and the build-up supports it but there was absolutely no need for the corridors to be so ominous - I was afraid something would jump at me at every corner, and wasn't really enjoying the stress it caused. 

A minor complaint is the strange timeline - it's hard to say how long these facilities and junk have been lying around because they're all clearly abandoned, but the immediate events affect the main character in the present. That being said, the story and the world/setting are engaging, and the voice acting well executed. The "bad guy" was a very believable character.

I would definitely recommend giving this little gem a run. It's a light game, with about 8-10 hours of playtime, depending how thorough you are. The devs picked a few simple elements that succeed in making the player really enjoy the time spent with the game. The sense of movement and the unique momentum mechanic was something I personally enjoyed, and like mentioned earlier, visuals and audio are very notable strenghts. Thanks Blue Isle Studios for your game! It was a good experience.

36954457.review:
[b]" Ещё в долине росли светлые колокольчики: кремовые, похожие на крохотные фонарики, хрупкие и стыдливые, они встречались очень редко, и в них было столько волшебства, что, найдя такое чудо, ребёнок радовался и гордился целый день" [/b]
(c) Джон Стейнбек. К востоку от Эдема.

Симулятор ходьбы никогда не был прорывным жанром. В лучшем случае, такие игры дают приятную картинку, сносную музыку, нулевой геймплей и сюжет прямиком из кинца категории B, который вроде бы должен заставить тебя поразмыслить, но у него скорее всего это не удаётся. И казалось бы, что может предложить хоть что-то потенциальному игроку [b] Valley [/b] - с первого взгляда абсолютно непримичательный представитель вышеупомянутого жанра? Оказывается, может .

Разработчики из [b] Blue Isle Studios [/b] постарались на славу. В графическом плане игра невероятно крута, даже немного не верится что из Unity можно выжать настолько вкусную картинку. Выглядит всё сочно, ярко и детализировано: как огромные открытые пространства, так и подземные лабораторные помещения. Звук тоже отличный, каждый скрип и шорох задаёт нужную атмосферу заброшенности и оторванности от мира.
Геймплейно же [b] Valley [/b] не симулятор ходьбы в привычном его смысле, а скорее симулятор [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ygE01sOhzz0] "Ludicrous Speed" [/url] - игра заставляет игрока бегать быстро-быстро и прыгать далеко-далеко, что в сочетании с отличными картинкой и звуком чувствуется ну ОЧЕНЬ круто. Динамика крайне высока, впрочем, вполне можно просто медитативно блуждать и любоваться местными видами. И готов поспорить, что игравшие ещё долго будут помнить эпидод с подземкой и рельсами: ты, словно Флэш из комиксов, бежишь на огромной скорости в окружении постоянно вспыхивающих вокруг тебя синих молний под потрясающую музыку. И выдыхаешь только на финише. Непередоваемое впечатление. 
И к слову о музыке - она так же не менее замечательна и в сочетании со всеми вышеупомянутыми плюсами задаёт игре приятную атмосферу волшебного места. Рекомендуется к отдельной покупке.

Но, разумеется, не обошлось и без минусов, причём довольно серьёзных. Во-первых, очень сильно проседает сюжетная составляющая игры. Сюжет вроде бы и есть, но крайне незатейливый: военные нашли очередную потенциально опасную вещь, попытались сделать из неё оружие и заслужено огребли. И скоро огребёт весь мир, если ГГ не остановит эту опасную вещь. Невероятно "сильно", не правда ли? К тому же, большая часть сюжета подаётся через богомерзкие записочки и редкие аудиозаписи. Такой себе подход к повестованию.
Во-вторых, уныла и сломана основная "фишка" игры - манипуляции с жизненной энергией природы вокруг cебя. Убери её полностью из игры и вообще ничего бы не изменилось, настолько незначительно она реализована. Хотя на бумаге всё выглядит довольно здорово: фиданул - природа вокруг тебя тоже гибнет. Повторил на одном месте это пару раз - всё вокруг мертво. Но так как в игре просто повсюду разбросаны энергетические шарики, подзаряжающие ГГ и позволяющие ему вернуть всё к изначальному состоянию - умирание природы просто не имеет смысла и не подстёгивает игрока быть осторожнее. А ведь эти шары ещё и самовостанавливаются. Действительно стоило бы убрать у них респавн, тогда игра начала бы давать хоть какой-то челлендж.
Из более незначительных минусов - пара некорректно работающих механик(иногда срывающийся сам по себе граплин хук, например) и не самая лучшая оптимизация. До сих пор не понимаю, почему в рекомендованных требованиях указано 16 гб ОЗУ, игре и 4-х более чем достаточно. Так же она довольно коротка, но имхо - это не критично.

Подводя итог, можно сказать что игра удалась. Она выглядит и ощущается как настоящая сказка, эдакая Терабития, из которой не хочется уходить. Не уверен, что стоит платить полную цену, всё же [b] Valley [/b] реально коротка. Но по скидке - крайне рекомендую. Один вечер она вам точно скрасит.
[i][url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/Malkolm/] Stellar Lunarus[/url], прости что украл твой стиль повествования - я никогда не был хорош в рецензиях :C [/i]

36687076.review:
Egy kalandor felfedezőútra indul messze, Kanadába, hogy megkeresse az Élet Magvát, viszont amit a Völgy-ben talál, az túlmutat minden képzeleten. Egy második világháború alatt zajlott szupertitkos projekt nyomaira bukkan. A Pendulum sok katonát, tudóst foglalkoztatott, akik szuperfegyvereken dolgoztak, katonai támaszpontokon, hatalmas kutató komplexumokban, ám egy nap rejtélyes módon a teljes személyzet eltűnt.

Blue Isle Studios tavalyi dobása egy belső nézetű ügyességi játék, ami kezdetben egy sétaszimulátornak indul, viszont hamar felmegy a fordulatszám, mikor megtaláljuk még a játék elején a L.E.A.F. exovázat, ami nem egy hétköznapi eszköz, képes az életenergiát elvonni és hozzáadni növényekhez és állatokhoz, de ez még semmi. A vázat a kalandozásunk során fejleszthetjük, más és más tulajdonságokat adhatunk hozzá, így mindenféle terepen elboldogulhatunk vele, de kibővíthetjük az energiatárunkat is. A legjobb tulajdonsága viszont alapból jár hozzá, mégpedig a Kvantum-halhatatlanság, ami a halál pillanatában aktiválódik, energiát elvonva a környezettől, visszateleportál minket a legközelebbi biztonságos helyre, így már a játék elején félistenként ugabugrálhatunk hegyek-völgyek között. Viszont figyelni kell rá, hogy amit a természettől elveszünk, azt vissza is kell pótolnunk, mert ha nem marad honnan energiát elvonni, akkor valsz kampec. Velem nem esett ez meg, ez egy könnyed játék.
Legjobb, hogy sok helyre fel lehet mászni, nemegyszer sikerült kiugranom a grafikából is.
Nem minden pálya szabad terep, néha a hegyek gyomrában kell haladni, síneken szaladva majd a levegőben szállva 200-al! Nagyon élvezetes pontjai a játéknak a föld alatti részek.
Harcra néha sor kerül ugyan, de az erőszak minimális.
A zene remekül passzol az aktuális történésekhez, vagy napszakokhoz, hol sejtelmes és komor, hol könnyfakasztó, hol könnyed folkos. A kiváló, egy órányi zeneanyagot külön meg lehet vásárolni.

Jó hogy nem hagytam ki a Valley-t, egyedi darab, kissé rövid ugyan, ha nem vagyunk maximalisták, és nem bóklászunk kincsek után, akkor 6-7 órányi kalandot nyújt.

36612834.review:
6/10

Valley is a first person platformer with light combat elements. It reminds me a little of another game I played entitled "A Story About My Uncle," so if you're a Valley fan, the one might be worth checking out too.

Almost immediately after starting the game, you find a "LEAF" suit. It's basically an exoskeleton that allows you to run faster, jump higher, and get this: revive or destroy local flora and fauna. When you're charging down a hill, gaining momentum the whole time, and you launch across a crevasse, the game is exhilarating. There are quite a few moments like this, and things get especially exciting when you find train tracks that seem to interface with your suit to generate more and more speed. In addition, it creates an oddly tranquil feeling in the player to revive deer and dead trees that you come across.

However, I can't say that the story really resonated with me. First of all, your character is exploring ruins that seem to be at least 50 years old. The game attempts to create an immediate crisis that the player is responsible for solving, but the thought that these ruins have been sitting here without incident for so long really undermines the pressure and immediacy of the crisis. It is true, though, that someone else could happen upon the site and abuse the technology found within. So perhaps it's good that the protagonist stopped by, but she definitely doesn't need to be in a hurry.

Secondly, and at the risk of giving too much away story-wise, I felt that one of the big "reveals" in the late game could be read as an allegory for the stem cell debate. This came to mind as I was playing, and actually soured me a little on the title as I tired long ago of conservative legislators delaying potentially life-changing medical advances.

If I do not count it being short (around 3-5 hours), it might worth the full price, because it was done pretty well.

36524563.review:
Ah, Valley...

When you were very little, do you remember running down a hill to get that speed boost, to feel that sensation of flying forward at the limits of your balance and experiencing the exhiliration of moving faster thatn you ever could on flat ground?  This game is that feeling bottled when it wants to be, and a visually assisted audiobook when it doesn't.

A common rule of cooking is that if you are going to do something simple, you have to do it well.  Blue Isle Studios must have had that as a mantra when designing this game.  It doesn't do anything extravagant, simple story, simple mechanisms, simple linear path.  However, in doing those things it also does them very well.  The controls are tight and natural and work well with the level design so that movement along the path feels exhilirating and yet natural.  The music is built to make you feel the sheer joy of effortless movement.  The combat neither feels overly forced or completely ignorable.  Everything in this game is simple, and yet simply perfect.

36519411.review:
Beautiful graphics, decent music and sound, this is a very pleasant run n'(occasional) gunner, with lots of collectibles and minor metroid-vania elements, and an okay environmentalist vs. technology story that unfolds through found journal pages and audio logs.

My big complaint is in how the game treats water. It says early on that the LEAF suit sinks--so why does touching a half inch of water kill you instantly? Also, after dying to water, you often respawn sliding down a hill into water again, and will die if you don't start moving even before you're fully respawned.

The combat seems a little tacked-on, the game could use a map, and there should be some way of tracking which collectibles you've obtained.

36431887.review:
I recommend this game to most people on the basis that it offers an immersive experience by executing on gorgeous graphics and a brilliant soundtrack to augment an intriguing foray into the unknown. You'll enjoy plenty of beautiful vistas and heaps of atmosphere which evolves as you move through the valley's various "biomes" and uncover gameplay and narrative elements. Incidentally, the pacing of each of these is really nicely done.

It's no spoiler to reveal that there are collectables in this game, and this element is never prohibitive of story progression. I would recommend a measured vigilance as you move through areas, and returning after concluding the story to complete your gathering of collectables. Pedantic search for them will cause the experience of the game to drag during its slower sections for all but the most fastidious of dispositions.

PvE Combat features, but its generally secondary or even tertiary nature as a theme is reflected in its simplicity. Depending on your taste, this might encourage or deter you. Consider this, then, an exploration and adventure game that delivers on all its major points. The various activities that you'll undertake typically involve conveying yourself to a new part of your environment; and in this, the game strikes me as a rigourous "walking simulator" at times.

I must stress, though, that it remains engaging throughout, as from the off, you'll have a suit which augments your movement drastically. Moving around the map in various ways really capitalises on the audiovisuals of the game and can feel a fairly liberating, joyous experience as it's not so bonkers as to seem fantastical and takes place in a world that looks real enough to allow you to suspend disbelief.

I'll also add that I'm so pleased to have bought the soundtrack at the same time, so consider doing that if you know what's good for you.

36426280.review:
A game quiet a bit philosophical about life and death. Is there some legitime reasons for a living being to get a second chance by robbing an other life in exchange ? Does it matter that this being is human ? A butterfly ? Or even a tree ? A fascinating application of the Everest interpretation of the quantum mechanics surrounded by an intriguing universe abandonned after WW2. Soundtracks are just so perfectly tuned that even without any true cinematics, I has this ineffable feeling to take part of a fantastic tale. 

Highly recommended game for those who are looking for simple gameplay in immersive world. 

I have to report some bugs using the ps4 controller (with and without activating DS4).

This game is amazing.  Blue Isle Studio really outdid themselves on this one.
Let's get the bad stuff out of the way.

Cons:
1. The enemies are not very threatening or exciting.
2. Lack of content.  I can get about six hours out of this game, which is still pretty good, but I would love to spend more time in this world.

Pros:
1. Amazing graphics that brings tears to your eyes.  (I can't believe that this was made on the Unity Engine)
2. A very unique story line, characters, and playstyle.
3. Amazing level design. 'Nuff said.
4. Audio is just as good as the game, I'm actually considering buying this as my first soundtrack.
5. The feeling of flying through this beautiful world and talking to small ghosts gives me a warm, fuzzy feeling inside.

All in all: 4/5.  This could easily be 5/5 if there was workshop support for custom missions.  Since this was made with Unity, most people could make creative levels.

36274796.review: This game is just, WOW. I've never had so much fun not just not killing stuff, but bringing it back to life. The puzzles are trivial, but oh, so much FUN. I mean can you tell me of any other game that allows you to walk on walls and ceilings? (Well you probably could but that's besides the point.) Can you tell me of any game where reviving and ressurecting dead things is so integral to the overall story and plot of the game? You get a jumping suit which does other cool things too once you unlock them; you can quite literally fly, in this game. There are also a few "running very fast" sections which were really fun.  Also a really good narrative to keep you interested. Anyways, my point is this game was definately worth every penny I spent on it. It's also pretty short; I finished the story in a bit over 6 hours, and that's with pleny of time spent on exploration. So, are we getting some DLC or expansions; or perhaps a sequel?? Although I'm not entirely sure how you could expand on this story, but I'm sure there's someone creative enough to figure it out. Cheers!!

36124996.review:
This right here is a nice little gem.
TL;DR: Fun and exhilarating, simple but good mysterious story. Non-violent, centred around movement through—and state of—'Valley'.

The game mechanics are centred around the locomotion enabled by the L.E.A.F. suit, that you get very early in the first area and it is to say very enjoyable experience. 
There is something about running down the hill in first-person view, accelerating up to 110—I think it was kilometres—per hour and then jumping over a chasm onto the other side, landing and continuing to run, which makes this so much fun; fun that wouldn't be so great if I was controlling a car, or if it was 3rd person view.

The underground levels that let you run that fast (or faster) on electrified rails are extremely exhilarating, because of the combination of well-chosen awesome music, sound and visual effects.
Sent shivers down my spine many times and the levels are fun to repeat.

[b]Graphics:[/b] The game is pretty. It is not THE best looking game you can get, but it has it's charm and the style suits it like no other probably would. Not that I care—I prefer games that don't sacrifice gameplay and story for pretty skyboxes, like it happens with many of those so-called AAA games these days.

[b]Story:[/b] There is a mystery almost right to the end, gradually revealed through notes and audiologs, at which point you'll get satisfying answers to almost everything and the ending nicely  ties it all together.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] I praised this enough at the top, now to nitpick a bit. You are encouraged to explore, but given the freedom of movement, you can very easily get to places where's nothing or where they forgot to finish the objects, so you can get under a pile of rocks, see/walk/fall right through them. At one spot, this is even at the place you can simply walk to, right next to a chest with stuff.

Overall, I can't recommend this enough for something so unique and nice. Although £15 does seem a bit too much. Pricetag of £10 would suit it perfectly—definitely get on discount if you were keeping an eye on this.

35975716.review:
I was, and remain, very happy about this purchase. My steam library wouldn’t be the same without it. The story is a fantasia of science fiction and historical fiction, with a touch of fantasy for good measure. The music is enchanting, the scenery is breathtaking, the motion controls are satisfying, the voice acting is on-point, and even the loading screens are beautiful enough that you won’t mind them staying on the screen for a few more seconds. The L.E.A.F. suit’s movement mechanics make you feel the way Sonic games would if they were any good. 

The only significant drawback of this game is that it was shorter than anticipated, which is the only reason I feel as though the regular price is just a tad bit too high. The collectibles aren’t as rewarding as I think they should be, which is another downside. Finally, although it is true that the developers didn’t always seem to put enough thought into the level designs (e.g., I ended up getting to at least one place which, it became obvious in time, I was not supposed to have reached yet – and I did so merely by curiously exploring the terrain for the correct way to go) I actually appreciated the sense of freedom the maps afforded the player the illusion of having. These are all negligible drawbacks to an otherwise outstanding game.

Overall, I’m happy to give this game an 8/10. I very strongly recommend people buy it if it’s on sale, and I applaud supporting the developers by buying it at full price.
