35953447.review:
Took 5 hours for me to complete, collecting everything in plain sight but not going out of my way to explore. I will definitely go back and 100% this though, because I'm very interested to see what else there is to discover, and because whenever you revisit an area it will tell you what collectibles are remaining there. For a game so short, I generally wouldn't bother buying it, and if i did, I wouldn't really care for it. But this was on sale so I thought why not. I'm very glad I did. Everything about this game was done beautifully. Great game design decisions, breathtaking visuals, flawless controls, constant introduction of new equipment to keep gameplay interesting, very immersive, great story, good voice acting and character development, great world and level design and no glitches or issues. 

I tend to avoid story based games, because I prefer to play rather than watch, but the story in this game is done perfectly. You discover things for yourself, and as you progress you will be given more and more information, without it pausing the gameplay. I mentioned how good the voice acting, character development, and story were, and if i'm remembering correctly it did it all without a single cutscene.

A lot of games I have played sacrifice a lot of polish and attention to detail for more content, whereas this does the exact opposite. And after playing this, I think that is how more games should be. Even for full price, I can't recommend this game enough.

35906912.review:
I would forewarn people that Valley is quite short. So, people looking for lots of content for their buck may want to look elsewhere. With my limited gaming time, I've actually started enjoying these unique, short experiences quite a bit more, so this is very much my bill.

Valley sounds much like a walking simulator from the title, but in fact has quite a lot of fast-paced movement. It often feels like a very well-done first-person Sonic the Hedgehog game with the way that ramps and momentum are used to keep you at high speeds. It's a bit light on enemies, but has plenty of collectibles and secrets, and attempts to have a pressing storyline that actually kept me interested the whole way through. You constantly collect new upgrades for your LEAF suit to make the gameplay interesting. This might even be a game that would be fun to speedrun because of its movement.

The goals and challenges of the game may get complicated given that everything revolves around one resource - a life-giving "Energy" collected from, get this, glowing orbs. This is both your ammo, your puzzle fuel, and your health bar when the game starts throwing enemies at you. It was manageable for me having reasonably good FPS aiming skills to conserve/dodge shots, but I feel like it could have easily run into problems in someone else's playthrough who just wanted to experience jumping across a chasm in an exosuit.

However I do have one massive complaint, not because it affects me, but it will affect those who have older hardware. OPTIMIZATION could be better (although it's not that bad). I'm currently using a 1070 (+1600x w/ 16gb) and I'm noticing some stutter with my gpu overclocked. I should also say the game settings are maxed out though. Short and sweet.

The music is fitting and left me wanting more. The voice acting is mostly very good although the acting on the voice that introduces the LEAF suit is a little cringe-worthy. 

The gameplay is easy and fun: lots of running, lots of jumping and double jumping, swinging through the air, shooting and collecting orbs. If you have a controller I'd recommend that over using the keyboard unless you want to get crab hands.

35836718.review:
This game is difficult to come to a conclusion to about. 

For one it's a very pretty game, which feels good to run about as you make your way through the game. It doesn't recreate the wheel when it comes to the movement in this game but it feels good enough to basically carry the game.

Another highlight would be the sound design. The music always feels like it suits the moment and the one song that tends to repeat enough somehow managed to not get irritating. The sound effects are also good, with little things that you wouldn't expect from a game this small. An example being that if you jump through some leaves on a tree they actually rustle.

The story is quite cliche with a heavy emphasis on man corrupting nature. Whether that is a negetive is up to you really as I found the execution to be interesting enough within the setting they had created. But the game and the story itself is very short. I'd say 5 or 6 hours max just doing a normal run through without going out of your way to collect the in game collectibles.

Perforamce was good, with only a couple hickups lowering 60fps to around 50fps, but I'm running a pretty decent rig so that wasn't much of a suprise.

If I was to point out negatives I would look at the lack of replayability and the combat. I doubt you're going to get another playthrough out of this game once you've already played it. It doesn't have the mesmerising visuals of a game like ABZÛ to make replaying worth it. Possibly if you really personally enjoy the movement and want to collect all the collectibles you might return.

The combat could honestly not be in the game. It feels like it's just there to give you something else to do for a few seconds before you resume your running about. It's also laughably easy. 

Now this review so far probably looked very middling, but I beat this game in one session. You could put that down to how short the game is but I genuinely enjoyed the game, even with it flaws. My final verdict would be advising you to pick this up in a sale like I did if your looking for a game to take you away to it's little world for a few hours.

35814164.review:
A visually stunning game, Valley captivates the player right off the bat with its beautiful scenery and excellent soundtrack.  The story, while somewhat subtle and generic in progression, allows a moderate flow of curiousity and discovery through the various notes and audio logs.  Unfortunately, there was more or less no character development, as this ends up being quite a short, "to the point" game.

The overall concept and gameplay is unique, however, creating a feel similar to games like Dishonoured or Portal.  Controls are extremelely responsive, allowing for a wonderfully smooth-playing experience.  All factors considered, I would highly recommend Valley, especially at the $5 sale price.

35813455.review: Valley is an absolutely enchanting experience. The story is very interesting and kept me engaged from start to finish. Exploring Valley was very rewarding and memorable due to the awesome L.E.A.F. suit you acquire at the start of the game. This allows you to build up huge momentum as you run down hills or speed through underground tunnels on electrified rails. The various upgrades found as you complete the story add additional functions like a grappling hook (which is context sensitive unfortuantely), double jump, magnetic wall climbing, and water running. There is also a bit of an FPS element as you will need to use the suits ability to fire energy blasts to defeat enemies. The energy consumed for attacks is also your health and can be replenished by draining it from plants, animals, and generators. However if you drain too many animals and trees the health of the valley itself is lowered, if this reaches zero the game ends. Where Valley really shines is it's story and freedom of movement as you explore each beautiful area in search of secrets such as upgrades for the suits energy capacity. Once you have completed the main story you can revisit each area to hunt down any remaining secrets, there is a completion percentage shown for each level so you will know right away if you missed anything. The voice work and music are excellent throughout as was the overall performance, I did not encounter any major glitches or frame rate issues. Valley is an easy recommendation if you just want to relax and explore a fantastic environment while unraveling a mysterious story. Be aware that Valley is very light on the combat and the only real challenge comes from platforming as there aren't really any puzzles.

35812837.review: Valley is a consistent product. The environments are nicely crafted, the music is outstanding and the running-jumping mechanics are adequate. There is one big problem. The story is not. It is trite, cliche and uninteresting...blablabla...nuclear bomb....blablabla...superweapon...blablabla...nature in balance...very very forgettable. Such a pity for a beautiful game. Buy it in a sale. You will get 3 hours of fun out of it.

35812503.review:
This game is a wonderful place to play around in. While it mostly is a "walking sim," there's actually a little bit of combat thrown in. Nothing too crazy, so even those who don't normally play games can just enjoy the adventure at their own pace, and the enemies have a cool design, and tie-in to the main plot. 

Story is mostly told through audio logs, which is a pretty cool narrative tool I have never tired of since playing Bioshock. Unlike in older games such as Resident Evil, where you got most of the plot by only reading the notes and cutscenes, it got a tad overdone, leaving just a wee bit too much at the imagination at times, especially when you really wanted to know what happened to everyone, and not just the characters you played as. With the voice overs, you really get a sense of character from the world you're in, and changes up the many ways one can experience a world within a game.

That said, this is a very short adventure, much like Blue Isle Studios's previous project, Slender The Arrival, which also featured simple gameplay, but done in a unique fashion to cause paranoia and fear. That game still gives me the creeps just thinking about it, but here, Blue Isle Studios gets to make their own full project, with their own ideas, rather than taking off with a borrowed one and building from there. Not saying it was a bad thing for them to do that, I'm just happy they got to do a project that wasn't tied down to a mythos, and they really got to make their own here. 

No, there is no horror here. This is, for the most part a very touching, and rather spirited adventure from beginning to end. It's been a longtime since a game has made me feel "fun" for the sake of fun. I was never bored here, and if you're someone who just enjoys taking in the scenery, and nature itself, you'll probably love it for that alone. 

I can't really think of any real negatives, except for the length. I feel the main adventure could have been an hour or two longer, but the game does leave itself open for you to explore long after finishing the storyline. Also, while the aspect of being able to give and take away life for survival is unique, and not something really explored in games, I feel like there could have been more developed here, but not sure what could have been done without adding characters. 

If you enjoyed Soma, which was also another interesting walking sim, adventure type game, I'm pretty sure you'll enjoy this one. There's even an area named Soma, and while Soma itself is unrelated to this game and studio, I couldn't help but make the comparison once I made it to that point. Don't get me wrong, the tone is quite different, and this one is a more happy go lucky sort of experience, without too much thought being given to the morality of your abilities. 

If you need an adventure, or a need to pass the time, by all means check this one out. I certainly wasn't disappointed.

-Related to the above, but because of looking for secrets, and without a consistent baseline, I spent alot of time just roaming around the maps searching.
-The life/death ability wasnt used that much in puzzles.  Example Idea: Killing a tree to expose a  hidden cavern, then restoring it to life to keep persuit from finding you.  In short  other than using it as your own power meter and ammo, there wasnt much gameplay that delved into its abilities.


Pick up at full price if you want to support the devs, or otherwise very much a grab when its on sale.

35736011.review:
Have had this sitting in my library, and finally got around to playing it. No regrets. 

Pros:

-Beautiful soundtrack, and matches every scene and action. From running through a sunrich valley filled with wildlife, to sparking down a railtrack at increasing speeds through an abandoned military base each score invokes the feeling you come to hope.

-Response suit. Obviously the highlight of this game is the LEAF suit you wear. The parkour feels satisfying, and the movements are accurate to your input.

-The envrionment. The is a beautiful world. A mix of nature, ancient ruins and abandoned military facilites keep everything very diverse. 

Cons:

-It's a fairly predictable story. It does not mean it isn't entertaining, as the voice actors do a good job at delivering their lines, it's just you've probably have come to see this type of plot more than once.

-It's a rather short adventure. There isn't a lot of incentive to go back and find all the medallions unless you really want to uncover every last plot detail and upgrade. Expect anywhere between 4-5 hours for the story, but the good news is the whole of that has a lot action going on.

35587444.review:
Boy, this was a tough call for me, but after making a list of pros and cons, I would say that even with a low asking price (assuming you grab it on sale), this game probably isn't worth your time. Here's a quick glimpse of my pros and cons:

Pros:
- Moderately enjoyable running mechanics (but this has been done so many times before in so many games)

- Fantastic soundtrack (by far the best part of the game)

- Beautiful landscape and graphics

Cons:
- Gameplay itself is simply not engrossing, except for the levels based solely on freerunning

- Story is weak and overdone - mad scientist has developed device to take over world, you are discovering his plans through audio logs, etc. etc. Done it a million times over.

- Combat is laughably easy - might as well not exist.

- Collectibles are annoying and not rewarding to find. You find collectibles so you can unlock doors to find...really, really, dull upgrades for your suit. Rinse, repeat. And there are a lot of them. Not worth your time.

- Game is incredibly short. Can be beat in a few hours.

- Virtually zero replay value. As I noted earlier, there's not a great incentive to find all of the collectibles, so unless you're an achievement hunter, it's not entirely worth going through all the levels again just to search out every single crate in every corner of the valley. Would turn a 4 hour game into a 10 hour game. Again, waste of time.

Overall, this game had a few good moments that made me think, "yeah, this game was definitely worth the $5 I paid for it." And I certainly don't feel like I was robbed, by any means. I just think there's too many other great games out there to use your time on this one. To put it plainly, it's a boring game. But it is beautiful. So if you're one for taking in the scenery and snapping some screenshots...by all means, go for it.

35341777.review:
Valley is a first person fast paced platforming adventure that gets some things very right and a lot wrong. On one hand, it's a game that has a lot of fast and incredibly fun movement. It also has quite large areas which can be explored using this movement. As such, a lot of the time you're keeping the momentum going from one interesting place to another, getting some gradual upgrades to your movement option and able to always return to the completed levels. And it also has some very basic action moments, based around the concept of life/death manipulation mechanics that never really go anywhere and might as well just be considered "ammo/life".

And the big problem, that not only this, but nothing ever really goes anywhere. The story is of bland, with a very primitive environmentalist motive that tries to be written into mechanics, but it never feels right. Movement itself, while fun, can be a pain due to character suddenly loosing momentum inexplicably or easily ploishing through the walls. A lot of the levels are boring to look at. And levels are big just for the sake of it, never really feeling thought out. It's a fun ride if you just run through the game, giving you a few hours of really exciting high-speed running and jumping not a lot of games can give (it was reminding me of Tribes at times, in the best ways). But if you ever stop to think you see just how primitive everything is and start doubting you want to continue.

35321800.review:
86/100
You get to swing around, run at breakneck speeds, and jump like no animal on earth, twice! It's an amazing parkour game That more than makes up for any lack of gameplay with its overall beauty. The gameplay is good and the exploration aspect is really immersive and interesting. It leaves you wanting more with every note you read and everyplace you discover.
This game is 60% parkour, 20% story, and 20% bringing things to life (or killing them)
The Stunning graphics and breathtaking soundtrack truly bring this game to life, with beautiful music to fit every tone.
It seems you could take a screenshot at any point (unless you're looking at a nice corner) and it would make a good wallpaper, The lighting and modeling are stunning. 
The sound effects are utmost immersive, hear the wind in your ears as you fall, hear your steps, hear the electric tingling in your suit as you run on electrified rails. Wearing headphones is a must. 
It has a very Interesting story that I wont tell you about because I'm lazy and I don't want to spoil anything.
I just wish it was longer, had more content, more places to explore, more things to do, upgrades to acquire, It was a pretty quick play.

35292257.review:
A beautiful very atmospheric game. It reminded me of Portal in a few ways, for instance I loved how the gameplay was based on physics. (I am not saying this IS Portal, mind!)

The graphics worked really well to create some fantastic sceneries - and the music was absolutly beautiful and fit very well.

The story is interesting and logical, I like how you get most of it handed to you buy the audio files that start up when you reach certain points in the game - but how you can still find out additional information through these notes lying around. I thought the story was something were you might say "yeah, that's something I've heard before somewhere" - but it was still effective and most importantly: not overcomplicated. Because I think that could have well happened with a different, less talented writer.

Nethertheless, while I really enjoyed playing it and had a great time at it, here are some nickpicks:
- The time spent searching around the factory annoyed me. Mostly because it was too freaking dark, and the game has no option to set up the brightness or anything. And also because I had a really great time running down slops and feeling like Sonic the Hedgehog. (heh)
The game did make up for that later on with the tunnel rails that make you run very fast and the water skeeing part. But still. I was bored deep in the depths of the 1st facility.

- My second and biggest complaint is... not really a complaint. Or...well maybe it is. I dunno. It was just something I was HOPING for while playing: 

+SPOILERS AHED+
This mostly goes to the developer, I suppose.

After you extract the life seed and the reactor breaks down, it gets revealed that the second facility still runs, but now is sucking the life out of everything and you are being told that it will do so until the entire PLANET is dead. Wow. What an amazing way to rise the stakes! So - because I am a person who loves to get really lost in the world of a game - I went "Oh no! I need to stop this! I need to save all the trees and animals in the valley - and save the planet eventually! - by shuting this thing down! Let's go!" and I ran off. ... Coming to the next checkpoint the environment gets very dark as the facility emits a shockwave that kills off a bunch of trees. And I thought "oh no! I better hurry! It will keep draining the life off the environment until the Valley health is to 0 - and than it will be game over for me too!"

Except that... didn't happen. I usually hate being rushed in a game. Like when a mission in WatchDogs is so damn tightly timed that you can't possibly make it on your first try. But in this: I really had wished there'd be an element of the clock to it.

That every 30 seconds or so the Valley looses health through another shockwave from the facility. And you have to keep giving life back to the trees and animals (kinda wished there'd been more throughout the game) to keep it - and evidently yourself - alife. All while liberating (? cuz I don't think 'killing' would be the right word) the Verdigos. So... yeah.

So yeah. My thoughts.
I'd love to see a second game come out of this. Even tough I guess the ending was pretty... ending. But I couldn't help but think when my character pushed the suit into the water "No! I want to resurect that deer over there and all the trees! I want to run through the valley and revive everything!"
- uuuuntil I remembered that it would be kinda wrong because the blue things actually are +spoiler spoiler spoiler+

Still: Amazing game. Go buy it - it's not that long, but worth it's price, I believe.
Also, on a last note: I loved that the wonderful original concept art was included in the cutscenes.

35245660.review: Playing out like a kind of weird Portal/ Tomb Raider hybrid and with an unnecessarily interesting story this is definitley worth your time if you fancy something a bit different (if quite easy). I picked it up in the sale for a few quid and had a really fun seven hours.

35234296.review:
Valley is a tricky game to categorize. I think I would describe the genre as "Traversal". It has some light puzzle elements and some light shooting but neither of those are really the focus of the game. Instead this is a game about moving through the level using the environment to assist you. In this sense I would say it is very successful. The movement mechanics feel very smooth and the different tools you have mostly add to the experience (although I'd have liked to see more ability to use the grappling hook for general movement). The resource system is also interesting, using a single resource for your hit points, mana points and ammunition count. It forces you to keep an eye on things during the combat segments since if you shoot to much you can kill yourself.

The story is ok, not great but good enough. It's mostly delivered through audio logs and documents but it avoids the cardinal sin of making you stop playing to listen to the logs so that's good. It is a bit heavy handed with the enviromental message but it also ties that message into the game mechanics which makes it more enjoyable.

Lengthwise the game is short, it took me 9 hours to beat including achievements and the replay value is low. That being said I do recommend the game so long as you consider the price worth the length.

35204329.review:
L'Essere Umano è parte della Terra. Ma ne è un elemento sinergico o dannoso?

Questo è il dilemma a cui Valley sembra voler dare una possibile risposta, dandoci la possibilità di esplorare liberamente una regione in territorio americano, ignota a tutti tranne che ad alcune sezioni dell'esercito statunitense durante la Seconda Guerra Mondiale.

Noi? Il nostro personaggio? Un semplice archeologo che, dando ascolto ad alcune leggende e dicerie, si troverà ad affrontare una situazione di una certa importanza ed urgenza: la potenziale fine del mondo.

Perchè lo consiglierei?

Perchè il titolo ha il raro pregio di darti quello che dice di offrire: un'esperienza di divertimento ed esplorazione con un pizzico di pericolo. Di base, è un platformer semi free roaming: prendete A Story About My Uncle ma miglioratelo significativamente sotto OGNI punto di vista, a cominciare dai controlli (responsivi e precisi).

Valley è uno dei tanti piccoli gioielli del sottovalutatissimo mercato indipendente e dimostrazione che con Unity si possono sviluppare giochi degni di questo nome.

Da prendere senza riserve e, se scontato, è quasi un obbligo.

35190243.review:
Valley is like a really, really good book. You can't put it down. But all the boring reading crap is replaced by A1 voice acting, beatiful scenery, and running around at near-mach speeds in a pair of robo-legs.

Once you start this game, you won't want to stop playing it until you finish the story because the story is really really good, and so is the gameplay to accompany it. I found this game extremely enjoyable to play, and I absolutely reccomend it.

That being said, it's also like a book in that once you've finished it, there's not much to go back to. One does not finish an award-winning novel and then think to themselves "Man, that was great! I can't believe the plot twist at the end! I can't wait to go back to the beginning and read the whole thing again!"

There's pretty much no replay value. There's the story, and that's about it. And even then, the story won't take you more than a couple hours to complete. If you're looking for something that you can go back and enjoy for hours on end, this probably isn't for you.

So tl;dr, This is a short and sweet game that I'm certain you'll enjoy if you pay attention to the plot. 20 bucks is a pretty heavy price tag for a 2 hour book, so this is a game that you should only buy on sale, but still should definitely buy.

35109127.review:
I am a big fan of games about rapid movement like Mirrors Edge and the like, so of course this game caught my interest. And I bought it despite knowing from other reviews that this is a very short game and might leave me unsatisfied content wise. Surprisingly enough, I was pretty satisfied and did't feel cheated at all. 
I think the best way to describe this is: It's like an interactive movie where you wander around a beautiful world and find out about what has happened in the Valley.
The story is pretty simple, no major plot twists, not too deep, more or less a typical adventure movie story, when ancient artifacts are involved. But it is a nice story and it kept me interested in the happenings of the Valley, even if it went pretty much as I predicted. Since it is a running simulator and you dont actually meet any humans during the playtrough, the story is told exclusively trough recordings and notes left by the researchers. 
Now on to the main attraction of the game. Movement. You are equiped with a L.E.A.F. suit exo-skeleton that amplifies your speed and jumps and negates falling damage. This very simple concept along with well made levels is what makes this game truly shine, because running around high speed and jumping literal hundreds of meters trough the world feels AWESOME. And as you progress trough the game you gain many upgrades to your suit that let you travel in new ways, like hook-shotting or running on water. And the developers really tried to give you some fantastic experiences while traversing, making multiple long runs synchronised with music to really give you that feeling of epicness.
Besides movement there is also your God-Hand gauntlet, that lets you literally draw from or give energy to any living being. Now this is a very important mechanic, as this energy is what keeps both you and the Valley alive... literally. Whenever you would die, thanks to the L.E.A.F. suit, Living things in Valley will die in your stead, and your actual life depends on the health of the Valley, meaning that, when the Valley dies it's game over as you will not be able to revive again. So, besides using your energy to keep the Valley alive, and thus yourself, you also use it for special actions, like double-jumping and hook-shotting, as well as shooting projectiles to deal with the enemies.
Combat in itself is very simple, enemy shoots you and you shoot the enemy. In most cases you dont even have to partake in combat, you can just run past these enemies without consequences, combat really isn't forced upon you and neither rewards or punishes you. It's there to add a bit more action to the game if you choose so.

Now, there are downsides to this game too, as is with most things in this world. The main downside, that has to be mentioned is price/content ratio. My game time of 3-4h is not from speedrunning trough the game, I actually spent some time enjoying the views and searching for collectables, as well as looking around and reading the notes that added flavor to the story and world. Overall I found about half or so of the collectables, and it probably wouldnt add more than 2h to 100% the game. The replayability of the game also isn't that high. I personally will probably play trough the game another time, but after that I will not touch the game for a very long time, if ever. Considering the 20 Euro price tag, that is a good argument to call it quite expensive and not buy it. 
There is also the case of the afore mentioned collectibles and story related notes. Looking for these really breaks your flow of movement, which, in a game about fast movement and traversal, is very noticable. On the plus side, this allows you to appreciate the surroundings a bit more.
And finally, some of the traversal upgrades on your suit feel like they are not used to their full potential. During the last phases of the game you get introduced to mupltiple mechanics that would allow for many interesting traversal puzzles, but end up being almost forgotten.

Overall the game was very enjoyable with multiple unique and interesting gameplay concepts, but due to it's high price, I can only recommend this to people that really like these kinds of games. Definetly try to catch it during a sale though.

7.5/10

35098287.review:
In grad school, I was often tasked with grading papers from undergraduate students. Most of the bad grades I gave were to students who either hadn't learned, or wilfully ignored, the basic building blocks of how to write an essay. How to structure an argument, and how to use sources. How to start with a thesis statement, how to support it, and so on. I never felt bad about giving these bad grades. I may have felt bad for those who were never taught how to write, but ultimately I was there to grade what was turned in. And yes, of course, sometimes there were some good papers too.

Every now and then, though, I got the kind of paper that I absolutely hated. This kind of paper was technically sound on all fronts. It had a thesis statement, and a body of supporting statements. It had citations for sources, and the general structure of an essay. It met the required word count. On paper, it hit all the criteria needed. But then I would read it, and it quickly became clear that the person writing this had absolutely no idea what they were talking about. Imagine a generic Freshman level Sociology student who just found out about Karl Marx, and writes his big paper on why Communism is the only true system of government that can serve the people, and that's why Mr. Robot is the best show on television, because it's all about bringing down Capitalism. 

On a technical level, the paper is solid. But in terms of content, he has no idea how and why Marx's Communism failed, and failed badly. He has not taken an Intermediate or Expert level Sociological Theory course to learn more about why Marx's Communism can likely never succeed. He's given no thought to what governmental or economic systems Communism was derived from, nor any idea of the various semi-Communist states that have formed that are very different than what Marx intended. 

And so I was left with a technically proficient essay in which everything was wrong, wrong, wrong.

That's Valley, in a nutshell.

Technically, the game is fine. It runs like a dream, the movement is fast and fluid and satisfying. I encountered no glitches or bugs. The... story... such as it is, has a recognizable beginning, middle, and end (don't laugh; Batman v. Superman couldn't even manage that). 

But after about the first fifteen minutes, I started hating the game, and almost everything about it.

Let's get the biggest complaint out of the way first: the game is called Valley, so you'd think it would take place in a valley. And about 30%-ish does. The rest takes place in generic abandoned warehouses and factories and military bases. All grey and dark and bland, filled with incredibly loud and grating sound effects. One could argue that making my ears bleed from screeching metal doors over and over again was intentional, because they wanted to contrast the beauty of nature with the monstrosity of machines. I would argue that (a) they could make that point WITHOUT making my ears bleed, and (b) any parts of the game set in nature are spent running so fast you can't actually hear any beautiful nature anyway.

The Valley is in a perpetual state of really late sunset, which means you get a nice orange glow where the sun hits, and total friggin' darkness everywhere else. Be ready to crank up the brightness, or play in the dark, or both, if you want to try to find Acorn doors on canyon walls. And be ready to drown at least a few times because the underground is so dark that even with the brightness up, you can't see where the water you're supposed to run on is.

The gameplay follows an unfortunate rhythm. You get a few minutes to run and jump and play out in the open valley. These moments are the best. Running down hill to build up steam, leaping off a ramp and flying through the air, feels amazing. Then after a few minutes of this, you're forced into small cramped areas with "combat" that amounts to litttle more than "aim at the thing, click on the thing". Find the generator to open the door. Climb through the vents. Listen to audio diaries. Read notes. Open crates. Are you falling asleep yet? I am. This game does one thing amazingly well - movement - yet it spends most of its time putting you in situations where you can't use this movement in any interesting ways. 

The life-and-death mechanic feels much like the Edicts in Tyranny - clearly they planned to do something bigger with them, and just never got around to it. At no point in Valley was I ever so low on energy that I had to drain a living creature or tree to get ammo back. If it was meant to be a moral choice thing, it failed because I was never even tempted to suck the life force out of anything. The mechanic may as well not have existed. Just gather orbs and shoot stuff. Problem solved.

Speaking of which, holy hell, the LEAF suit grants you super speed, super jumping, AND POWER OVER LIFE AND DEATH? This is just one of many unintentionally gutbusting moments during the story. This must be the result of a late night "Wouldn't it be cool if?" brainstorming session in which no one had the heart to tell the guy everything wrong with that idea. If Quantum Immortality sucks the life out nearby living things to bring the user back to life, why the hell wouldn't you just send ONE LEAF SOLDIER into a battlefield? He dies, life from enemy soldiers gets sucked out, he revives. Repeat until he single-handedly wins the war. What on Earth is the running and jumping even for, if you can literally point at a living thing and drain its life force?

The gameplay demands the running and jumping, because that's what Valley does best. But the gameplay has no real use for the Life-or-Death mechanic. Conversely, the story cares a great deal about the Life-or-Death mechanic, but doing so means the rest of the LEAF suit makes absolutely no sense in the context of the story. 

Speaking of the story, it's... functional? The writing isn't terrible, I guess? I'm struggling to come up with compliments here. The only really annoying thing is that the voice actors were apparently directed to read each audio diary as if the characters themselves were pausing and emphasizing for dramatic effect. They don't sound like people recording diaries; they sound like people giving line readings for a stage production, full of ACTING~! Also, just a thought: Virginia, if you're planning to sabotage the Astra plant, maybe DON'T record yourself talking about your plan? Maybe? Just a thought.

---

The whole thing reminds me a bit of Thief: The Dark Project, and not in a good way. For you young whippersnappers who don't remember, Thief: The Dark Project was a game about a thief, Garrett, in a medieval steampunky kind of world. The first three or four levels had you breaking into Ye Olden Homes to steal stuff, and get out undetected. It was awesome! But the developers were worried that players wouldn't play a whole game like that, so starting in level five, zombies and monsters start showing up, and the whole thing goes off the rails.

That's Valley. It does one thing really, really well, then spends so much time getting in the way of that thing. It's like the developers were worried that the movement wasn't enough to make a game around, so they needed to add hidden collectibles and audio logs and running-sideways-on-walls platforming puzzles and "combat" (I use that term loosely) and the whole life/death thing. Like Thief, they didn't trust that the core gameplay conceit was enough to keep players hooked, so they started dumping in everything they could think of. 

I like variety in games. I like it when games give me lots of different things to do. But those things have to be fun, or at the very least, interesting. Every time Valley abandons the valley, the game becomes completely and utterly generic. If you took all the footage from the game's interior sections and told me it was from some Steam Greenlight shovelware called Base Escape, I would believe you.

Can't recommend it to anyone. Not even on sale.

Lifeseed(생명의 씨앗)을 찾던 여행자가 어딘가에 불시착한 뒤
그 곳에서 어떤 일들이 일어났는지 알게되는게 주요 스토리입니다.
장르는 3D/액션/탐험/플랫포머 정도로 볼 수 있겠네요.


[h1]장점[/h1]
1. 시스템과 게임성

동식물의 '생명'을 제어한다는 판타지적인 능력, 
넓은 공간을 지루하지 않게 만드는 빠른 속도감, 
장비의 업그레이드 요소와 여러 수집요소들, 
플레이어의 실수를 줄여주는 부활 시스템까지,

여러가지 크고 작은 시스템이 모여서 적절한 게임성을 느낄 수 있습니다.


2. 아름답고 리얼한 경치

전 이 게임을 하면서 경치 구경을 참 많이 했는데요. 
노트북 사양이 좋지 않아 낮은 옵션임에도,
상당히 자연스럽고 아름다운 경치를 볼 수 있습니다.
구도만 잘 잡으면 배경화면으로 써도 될 정도로요.


[h1]단점[/h1]
1. 눈의 피로.

능력을 사용할 때 마다 파란색 계열의 화려한 이펙트가 나타나는데요.
게임을 진행하는 내내 비슷한 이펙트를 수십번 바라보다 보니 눈이 아프더군요.
반대로, 이 화려한 이펙트를 강조하기 위해서 
지형/지물의 텍스쳐는 조금 탁하게 만들어져 있습니다.

어두운 색상 사이로 화려한 색상이 반짝반짝거리는데, 
다른 부분은 모두 정상이고 눈만 피로해지는 것 같습니다.


2. 세이브 
이 게임의 가장 치명적인 단점. 
각 스테이지를 새로 시작할 때 마다, 무조건 첫 위치로 되돌아갑니다.
실수로 게임을 종료했다? 해당 스테이지 처음으로 되돌아갑니다.
중간세이브?? 이 게임에는 그런거 없습니다.

물론, 플레이어(주인공)의 시작 위치만 초기화 되는 것이고,
진행한 부분까지 얻었던 요소들은 그대로 세이브됩니다.

34962100.review: Muy buen juego...excelentes gráficas y sobretodo una banda sonora muy buena 10/10

34884860.review:
From the people who brought you Slender: The arrival!? Are you kidding?  
 
This is hands down a 10/10 must play experience. I've played a lot of atmospheric and unusual games but this... this left me breathless... I am at a loss for words for the Valley's beauty. I could only silently mutter "wow" in shear awe more times then I have in a long while.  
  
This game dreams so big you wouldn't believe it, and it gets so much farther then you would realistically expect for an indie game. The only tell it's not triple A is it's brevity and originality. Valley also has possibly has the best sound track, audio cues and active layering I've ever heard in hundreds of games and tens of thousands of hours.  
  
The spectacle starts strong, lures you into slower speculation and exploration before ramping up to a stunningly explosive finale. The ending is WELL worth getting and after everything it still took me off guard with how well executed it was.  
  
Valley will leave on a surprising powerful and humbling note, though possibly a bit simple it's truly memorable. This game overflows with passion and creativity. Personally my game of the year.  
 
My hats off to the developers who I really want to thank, for a small indie studio that reached for the sky and made one of the best games I've ever played. You guys really captured something special and a truly beautiful experince with it~

34870075.review:
Blue Isle Studio znane najbardziej z gry pt. "Slender: The Eight Pages" i "Slender: The Arrival", które przez lata były uważane za najstraszniejsze gry horrorowe. Lecz to nie czas i pora o tym rozmawiać. Tym razem postanowiłem napisać recenzję gry "Valley", którymi twórcami jest studio powyżej.

Valley to gra, która została stworzona przez Blue Isle Studio na silniku Unity, która w przeciwieństwie do dwóch innych gier silnik ten został jak najbardziej najlepiej wykorzystany, aby dać jak największą satysfakcję z gry.

Na początek wcielamy się w pana lub panią (w grze jest wybór płci) archeolog gdzie naszym marzeniem jest znalezienie bądź raczej odkrycie jakichkolwiek danych lub informacji o istnieniu Lifeseed. Lecz nie spodziewamy się, że ów tytułowa dolina była ośrodkiem militarnym Stanów Zjednoczonych, gdzie testowano najnowszą broń, która miała zmienić oblicze II Wojny Światowej. Broń zwie się L.E.A.F. Suit z główną bronią God Hand, która pozwala posiadaczowi tego stroju na odbieranie jak i również przekazywaniu życia wszystkim istotom żywym (tutaj mamy do dyspocyzji drzewa, krzewy lub zwierzęta). Jednak w ciągu rozgrywania dowiadujemy się, że L.E.A.F. Suit nie była jedyną bronią testowaną w tytułowej dolinie, a na miejscowych kreaturach były robione eksperymenty, które zmieniały się w potwory. A technologia, która wykorzystywała moc Lifeseed sprawiała, że Valley umierała.

W dalszej części gry dowiemy się co jeszcze robiono na tytułowej dolinie oraz o tych, którzy próbowali to przerwać oraz jaki był ich los.

Gra jest świetna. Ma bardzo ciekawą i mądrą fabułę (w którą trzeba się wczuć i lepiej się jej przysłuchiwać) oraz co najważniejsze wyśmienitą oprawę muzyczną. Tam można poczuć się niczym ptak lub sarna biegnąc po łąkach doliny i wsłuchując się w muzykę, która sama się prosi o słuchanie jej w kółko.

Podsumowując gra jest świetna i polecam ją każdemu kto lubi takie gry z fabułą i styczności z naturą z dodatkiem świetnej muzyki.

34862199.review:
Beautiful looking game with an interesting story but I wouldn't buy it for full price so I highly recommend picking it up during a sale.

Pros: 
- Fun platforming
- Interesting characters
- Fantastic scenary

Cons:
- Rather short game
- Exploration isn't very rewarding
- Not very challengin'

Summary:
I really had higher hopes for it, it started of really good as you're introduced to the L.E.A.F suit and where you've ended up at. Putting on the L.E.A.F suit and just getting to places is so fun but here's where I got disappointed, it should've been an open world game instead of this linear backtracking game that it ended up as. You can go back to collect items you couldn't get before due to some upgrades but I never felt the need to as they were very generous with the energy capsules and orbs. Most levels wasn't very hard and it was just mainly to get from point A to point B. What kept me going was the story, I wanted to know what was going on here and what the creatures was. As I don't want spoil but it's rather interesting and you won't be disappointed as far as that goes. Short but memorable game that had more potential when it comes to gameplay

Final score:
For bein' how short but how well made it was I would pay around €15 at most but I am disappointed that it wasn't an open world game as the L.E.A.F suit gave you so much freedom to explore. Short, beautiful game with potential gives it a 6.5/10 in my book.

34786248.review:
VALLEY starts out as a walking simulator, then quickly becomes a puzzle-parcour-mix by handing you an upgradable suit which lets you jump higher, run faster, cling to magnetic walls and much more. After a while of happily exploring the beautifully arranged environment you start to encounter hostile creatures and at one point the game literally sent some chills down my spine (which only a few games have achieved so far). 

The storyline is pretty good and brought across via audio logs and notes you can find throughout the levels. A twist at the end changes your view of certain aspects of the game and provides some "oh-my-god"-feeling.

The graphics aren't perfect but fittingly beautiful. Excellent world detail and lighting never fail to convey the right mood.

The soundtrack is awesome and adds to the atmosphere of the world.

The controls are decent and make running, jumping and grappling-hooking come to you naturally. Whenever you fail, it's because of you, not due to clunky controls.


The only thing I would have really liked is the possibility of exploring the valley as a whole and not only via the different level sections, since it feels like a complete world, waiting to be discovered. BUT the more linear level design makes for some pretty cool and well-timed moments that would be hard to achieve with, for instance, an open world game.




Overall, I am glad to have bought this game and I can happily recommend it to anyone who likes something a little unconventional but all the more beautiful.



8.5/10

This is a pretty solid physics puzzle game. You can definitely skip it if you don't like that genre or you haven't played better games in the genre yet (like portal), but if you like the genre this is a decent one in it.

There's some good story as mechanics stuff going on, the LEAF suit feels bulky and old despite being powered by life force.

The game has some pacing problems, but it's not the worst paced game I've played. It's also maybe a little too easy? Some diary entries were the exact same as some voice over entries or damn near. The game makes sure you get all the story even if you don't read any entries, but this can make the diary entries feel a little meaningless at times. Especially open a crat ooh did I get an upgrade? no. a diary entry. with info you already knew.

It's annoyingly easy to get stuck on geometry. This is the sort of thing that a physics game should really nail: physics; however, nothing I encountered was game breaking.

The game has quite naive story and not-so-good way to tell this story - through letters and audio records, but for my taste it is still fair. But it is not the story that is the core of the game and not even the "innovative" mechanics of manipulating life and death. 

You feel this from the first second you climb into the L.E.A.F. suit - this speed, this power and overall this magnificent sound of jumps and landings. All in this game was made to let you enjoy your freedom of movement - landscape, sound, music, even the narrative itself. Although jumping can be quite clumsy sometimes, increasing speed while running from the hill and jumping right into the sky... it feels GOOD. The best of all I think is the rail sequence when the music accompanies your free run along the power lines.

The game is similar to The Story About My Uncle, but with far more interesting mechanics to play with. Recommend for one who wants to prance off the field like the proud deer.

34638487.review:
This game was made by Blue Isle Studious and I must say, they have done a very good job. Valley is about a man who found himself on an island with nobody else, for the first few minutes of wandering around, he finds himself the L.E.A.F. Suit which allows him to move at a incredible speed and along the way finding more upgrades that prove useful throughout the game. 

The L.E.A.F. Suit was made way back during the World War times and was used by soldiers in hopes that however had these suits would win the war. The L.E.A.F. Suit  used energy from other life sources such as deers, which you can do in the game as well, however, the more energy you take, the faster the island dies. 

Along the way there are crates which give you upgrades for your L.E.A.F. Suit and increases you energy bar and grappling hooks etc. As a result, the suit becomes more agile and allows you to access different parts of the island with ease.

Unfortunately, the main power provided on the island to these L.E.A.F. Suits was a "Life Seed", which fell into the hands of a professor who sought to use its energy and turn it into a weapon (a bomb to be exact). As you venture deeper into the island, you find research labs and a generator underground hiding the Life Seed. Your goal is to destroy everything that the scientists made as it is killing the island and every animal that lives on it.The Life Seed will be used as a weapon but will be used for a better purpose than intended. 

I can't relate this game to any other game and it holds a unique story of its own. Many will fail to understand the designers view of the game but many will also understand what he intended to convey. In World War 1, man seeked for weapons that could destroy cities so as to put them in power. In World War 2, every country had the same weapons, making it pointless as the only people who won were the people who had more resources. 

I doubt that there will be a second part to Valley as it is already a very complete story on its own and leaves many of us touched and feeling slightly emotional. 

If you are looking for a game that operates around the themes of parkour and adventure, this game is definately the game for you and will be worth your money and time.

34519269.review:
GUYS

GUYS

GUYS

BUY THIS GAME

Piloting a L.E.A.F. Suit, running downhill gives you tons of speed and makes running around so much fun, and unlocking new upgrades for different ways to run and gives extra variety. The story and setting are well-done, and there are also hidden collectables scattered around for you completionists. There is also some light combat in there to keep it interesting.

But the big thing that sold me on this game is that it is BEAUTIFUL. THE MUSIC. THE SOUNDS. THE TREES AND GRASS. THE SUN. THE SKY. THE WATER. IT ALL REACHES A LEVEL THAT PUTS MOST TRIPLE A GAMES TO SHAME. AND IT'S ALL ADMIRABLE WHILE GOING AT HIGH SPEEDS. I DID MY ENTIRE FIRST PLAYTHROUGH IN ONE SITTING.

My only complaint is that i wish there was more content. Don't get me wrong, the 3 hours it took me to beat the game were well spent, but i enjoyed it so much that i wish i could have played it longer without having to replay things, and while it's still great, it's never quite as fun the second time you do it.

You might want to wait for a sale, but honestly? I am glad I paid every cent. Sure, it's 3-4 hour game for 20 bucks, but imo it was well worth it. Do yourself a favor. Play it. Please.

34518285.review: This was very enjoyable. It was fun to just run around the valley in the suit. The story was good enough to keep me interesed.

34512750.review:
Explore the vast and beautiful world of Valley using the power of the L.E.A.F. suit: a fierce exoskeleton that grants exceptional speed and agility along with the phenomenal ability to manipulate the life and death of all living things (here: trees and deers).

tl;dr Valley is the prettiest walking sim (well, running sim actually) since The Vanishing of Ethan Carter. If you like these kind of games just play it.

Now for the longer version. Valley puts you in the shoes of wannabe Indiana Jones that finds himself in the mysterious valley in search of a mysterious lifeseed that grants power over life and death. Very mysterious! Mechanically it translates to running and jumping through some quite beautiful environments, looking for upgrades to your suit and shooting some spirit baddies once in a while. And it's very well done for what it is. The game is not challenging - it's possible to die but it's not easy - but it is very enjoyable and relaxing. Running very fast and jumping very high was more fun that I expected it to be.

I mentioned The Vanishing of Ethan Carter. Visually the games are quite similar. Valley even uses the same font and text effect to tell you what your character is thinking. It's a little bit longer than Ethan Carter, but not too long, I clocked in ca. 7hrs, that's for going through the game once and a little bit of achievement hunting. I think I got like 3/4 of the secrets too.

I liked:
* nice visuals
* running and jumping is very enjoyable
* interesting story

I disliked:
* music at places (but I really dislike your typical relaxing music)

Get this if:
* you like walking sims

34484535.review:
Denedim, sahiden denedim... Uğraştım, dişimi sıktım ama beceremedim...

Bir oyunu da bitirmeden ya da belli bir süre oynamadan incelemesini yazmam genel olarak ama sahiden dayanamadım bitirebilecek kadar. Ya arkadaşım bir oyun bu kadar mı sıkıcı olur? Fragmanlara bakarsak büyük olasılıkla oyuna "Fena değil" dememi sağlayacak olaylar yaşanacaktı sonlara doğru ama o kadar bezdirici ki sabredemedim.

Valley, Platformer - Yürüyüş Simülasyonu temelli bir oyun. Grafiksel olarak bir şölen denilebilir mi bilmiyorum 2017 yılındayız ve inanılmaz görsel şölenler sunan oyunlar var bir GTX 1080' e ihtiyaç duymadan ama konumuz bu değil tabi ki. Yine de şunu bilmenizde fayda var çünkü Valley ciddi ciddi ekran kartınızı sömüren bir oyun filtrelemeleriyle ama bu kadar çimenin bulunduğu bir oyunda da bunun olması oldukça doğal.  

"A Story About My Uncle" oyununu oynadıysanız mekaniklere aşikârsınızdır malum bire bir alıp geçirmişler ondan veyahut başka bir türdeşinden. L.E.A.F isimli bir protez buluyorsunuz ve oyun boyu bu protez ile geziniyorsunuz. Bu protez sizin daha hızlı koşmanızı, daha yükseğe zıplamanızı sağlıyor. Oyunda ilerleme kat ettikçe Graple Hook misali bir alet ve çift zıplama gibi özellikleri aktive ediyorsunuz. Bir de oyunda doğayı manipüle edebiliyorsunuz. "Manipüle" doğru tabir olmayabilir ama şöyle söyleyeyim madem; doğadaki ağaçların, canlıların enerjilerini alabiliyorsunuz tabi doğanın anasını ağlatmak sizin de can barınıza yapacağını yapıyor. Yani oyun bu noktada sadistliğe bir dur demeyi iyi biliyor. 

Oynanış süresinin oldukça kısa olduğu, en hantal oynanış ile 4 hızlı oynanış ile 2-3 saat gibi bir sürede bittiği söyleniyor fakat bitirmeye sabrımın dayanmadığı için bu konuda bir yorum yapamayacağım.

Söylemeyi unutuyordum, Valley' nin türdeşlerinden farklı özelliği olarak oyun mekaniklerinde "Momentum" özelliği mevcut. Yokuş aşağı hızlı yokuş yukarı yavaş koşma basitleştirecek olursak. Şu güne kadar hiçbir oyunda bunu görmediğim için hoşuma gitmedi desem yalan olur.

34479092.review:
Valley is quite an interesting game, with some irritating bugs, that I would in the end recommend. On sale, like I got it.

Pros:
Fairly laidback gameplay (until the last hour or so)
serious effort at a soundtrack
unique integration of your health with the valley's health
once you get LEAF suit upgrades, you never go back!

Cons:
save system that only saves after a chapter is finished. No manual method. Don't quit in the middle of one.
many times felt my POV was from about 6 inches high, not say 6 feet.
game is relatively short
the bad guys are so easy they almost kill themselves for you
the valley's history and the military ruins' history feels unconnected to today, unexplained.

You'll have fun running and leaping, and scenery is nicely done. But you can only quit the game after you have reached where it saves progress, there is no true autosave that works as you go along.  If you quit in the middle of a chapter, you start over at the beginning of same chapter.

But you may not want to quit much! It's a beautiful place. From the ruins history you'll find the psychologist babbles on about pyramids far too much, and when she isn't babbling about them she's leaving notes. Without giving spoilers, it isn't clear what happened in the valley or why. At least, to me.

The most interesting question I had was this: what would have happened if you never found the valley?

34427387.review:
Overall, this is a game to buy on sale.

On the plus side, this game is beautiful to look at. The nature scenes are really well rendered and I loved the look of the old stations and equipment. The game also can be a lot of fun, especially when you are flying over the scenery or racing around on the rails.

That said, the game can be frustrating at times. The physics are weird. If you hit the side of a hill or even just jump at the wrong moment, all your momentum goes away. And the swinging mechanic (the viper coil) never worked like it felt like it should. Again, I would keep losing momentum midway through a swing, which isn't how swinging works. And the controls are either a bit too sluggish or a bit too fast. The enemies are okay, but not very varied. The final boss is just a bigger version of one of the standard enemies. And the story is a bit simplistic and anti-climactic. The notes you find along the way often just repeat the audio logs that you pick up. And in the end, I really wanted more of a payoff with the life of the valley.

All that aside, I still enjoyed the game. I love exploring textured worlds, and The Valley offered plenty of that for me. I'm just glad I bought it on sale.

are not supposed to be yet ( That requres special Upgrades... ect...).

When a Jump seems to wide, try run down a short steep distance to gather momentum enough
to increase the jump distance. Also useful to enter places you are not realy supposed to get to, hehe.

34394546.review:
Prima cosa consiglio di comprare questo gioco in saldi , perché 20 euro sono tanti per 4-5 ore di gioco : io lo ho pagato meno di 5 euro e su questo baso la mia recensione
Siamo di fronte ad un platform in soggettiva abbastanza facile e lineare , quindi , adatto a tutti quelli che preferiscono giocare in tranquillità e rilassarsi
Avrete a vostra disposizione una supersuit da indossare e che migliorerà con l’andare avanti nel gioco : grazie a questa attrezzatura potrete correre velocissimo , fare salti grandiosi , camminare sulle acque per qualche secondo e sui muri ; inoltre avrete il potere di donare ( o togliere ) la vita ad animali e piante , e con questi raggi di potere dovrete sconfiggere i nemici … compreso un mini boss finale
Ambientazioni fatte molto bene ( vedere miei screenshots ) e nel gioco abbiamo lo scopo di eliminare il male che distrugge la natura per ridare vita appunto alla valle  : siamo immersi per metà gioco in questa valle misteriosa e bellissima e per l’altra metà dentro un complesso militare abbandonato
Le musiche sono molto rilassanti ed il gameplay è fluido ed i movimenti molto reattivi ai comandi : da segnalare un bug che colpisce xbox controller con windows 10 che molte volte dopo la prima partita non funziona piu’ e , quindi , sarete costretti a finire il gioco con mouse e tastiera
Altro piccolo difetto è la assenza di salvataggi : quindi se , ad esempio , si spegne il pc dovrete iniziare il livello dall’inizio , mentre se morite tornate in vita nello stesso punto
Vi consiglio a prezzi in saldo di comprarlo e passerete varie ore in maniera rilassate e godendovi al valle , nella speranza magari di un seguito di questo gioco magari con una storia piu’ complessa ed interessante
Voto 68 / 100
------------------------
First I recommend buying this game on sale, because 20 euros are so many for 4-5 hours of play: I paid it less than 5 euros and on this basis my review
We are faced with a fairly straightforward and linear platform, therefore, suitable for anyone who prefer to play quietly and relax
You will have a supersuit to wear and that will improve with the move forward: thanks to this equipment you can run fast, make great jumps, walk on the water for a few seconds and on the walls; You will also have the power to donate (or remove) life to animals and plants, and with these rays of power you will have to defeat enemies ... including a mini boss finale
Very good settings (see my screenshots) and in the game we aim to eliminate the evil that destroys nature to give life back to the valley: we are immersed for half the game in this mysterious and beautiful valley and for the other half in a complex Abandoned military
The music is very relaxing and the gameplay is fluid and the responses are very responsive to the commands: to point out a bug that hits the xbox controller with windows 10 that many times after the first game does not work anymore and so you will be forced to finish the game With mouse and keyboard
Another minor flaw is the absence of rescues: so if, for example, you turn off your PC you will have to start level from the beginning, while if you die back to life at the same point
I recommend you to buy it at a steady price and spend a few hours in a relaxed way and enjoy the valley, hoping maybe a follow up of this game maybe with a more complex and interesting story
Rating 68 / 100

34368922.review:
If you can catch this game on sale for $5 I would say snag it.  The game itself is very different then any other game I have ever experienced.  

GRAPHICS:

The graphics in Valley are well done for an indie title.  Although some muddy textures, the game world is brilliant. The large vistas and mountain-tops impressed me and the effects while running across water or jumping across valleys are top notch for an indie title.  The developer has put in about as much features as you would expect although I would suggest to keep the AA at SSAO (going any higher tanked my fps)

GAMEPLAY:

Valley is a fun game.  The thrill that you get from gaining momentum and making jumps is all around.  Valley will have you sprinting down mountain-tops and jumping across abusrd distances with help from a mechanical legs system called LEAP.  Spread across Valley are upgrades for your LEAP system that will allow you to explore as well.  The game is fairly linear and includes crates scattered across the world containing secrets and notes.  The game feels good to play, controls well and pretty easy to run as well.

STORY:

Valley's story is a short one although that is not a bad thing.  Ill save you the details but lets just say 1940s era nuclear-reactors, japenese style energy forms and lots of dialogue tapes.   The tapes provide interesting details on the backdrop and the ending gave me some satisfaction as well.

SOUND:

The sound desigh is pretty average, I would even say good for an indie title however, the music is where Valley shines.  Valley's soundtrack is wide and diverse ranging from peppy folk music to the strong beat of african drums.  I loved it and can say that it is definitely one of the best parts of the game.  Running down your first hill with some fast paced folk music adds up for a great experience.

Once again,  if you can get this game on sale I would recommend it.  I beat it in 2 sweet hours, but those 2 hours were never frustrating or boring.  Maybe you can get a couple more hours out of it by collecting all the secrets and upgrades.

34368683.review: Valley is an underacknowledged masterpiece. This is a game that has amazing mechanics for speed and traversal, but also a bit of a heart to it. The plot isn't anything too in-depth - a hiker comes across a supernatural part of the world, hidden from human eyes, only to discover a US military complex dedicated to creating a superweapon. But the gameplay is what really sells the experience here. Even more than 3D Sonic games, Valley has this incredible sense of speed and hugeness that I've never really seen quite on the scale I've seen here. Beautiful environments with lots of nature vs. technology themes, really great art direction, really great platforming and speed sections... I can't recommend this game enough. Easily my runner-up for GOTY 2016, after DOOM. Totally different narrative themes, but it's similar to DOOM in the sense that Valley knows its game mechanics make you feel powerful, and doesn't shy away from letting you feel like a badass,

34363104.review:
Un magique et improbable mélange entre Sonic pour son gameplay, Firewatch pour ses environnements, et Portal pour sa narration.

Simple mais onirique, ce jeu vous donnera un sentiment de liberté. Pas cette liberté que nous promet les open worlds à la manque, qui nous enferme plus dans une routine de remplissage d'objectifs rébarbatifs, non. Là c'est la Liberté avec un grand "L", celle qui va vous donner envie de courir, toujours courir droit devant vous pour ne plus jamais vous arrêter.

La Leaf suit est notre exosquelette qui permet de se mouvoir et sauter de façon surhumaine. C'est grâce à elle que nous arpenterons les grandes plaines que Valley proposera, dans le but de redonner une nouvelle jeunesse à la forêt qu'elle habite. C'est un réel plaisir de courir, le feedback est tellement bien foutu que nous pourrions presque sentir le vent sur notre visage.

La musique n'est pas en reste. Valley propose une OST magique, collant parfaitement avec l'univers et l'action. Ce genre d'OST qui vous restera en tête et que vous vous empresserez d'aller écouter lors de la fin du jeu.

Si je devais trouver un point négatif, se serai sur son contenu. Il n'est pas pauvre, mais on peut ressentir que les développeurs manquaient de moyen pour le réaliser, et qu'avec plus de temps et d'argent, il serait devenu un incontournable du jeu indé.

En bref, courez jouer à Valley !

34361349.review:
Felt like good proof of concept

Bought the game while on sale for $5 USD and it was well worth the money. I don't know if I would spend $20 on it though. Beatiful adventure, at times got my blood pumping but I'm not sure why; there's no real threat in the game. While there are enemies, they are fairly easily pacified. Yet, I still found myself enjoying "fighting" them.

 The running, jumping, and swinging sections gave me the same rush as playing some of the older Spiderman games. It felt very fluid.

My only complaint is that the game seems to pull you in two different directions. On one hand, you can speed through massive sections of the map with ease, all to a synchronized soundtrack. But there are collectibles scattered throughout the levels, and if you want to collet them, you have to interrupt the one thing that really makes the game fun, and that's the feeling of using the LEAF suit to glide through the levels.

I hope the dev makes another game where you can navigate in a similar fashion, with speed and agility.

SPOILERS ABOUT ENDGAME STUFF:
[spoiler] Super good job on the final boss fight too. I don't think I took any damage, but it felt like the perfect fight for the environment you created. The LEAF suit gives you decent control in the air. Having to dance and shoot at the same time was fun and I could definitely see y'all making more difficult fights for future games. Keep up the good work and I hope to see more stuff from y'all soon! [/spoiler]

原画美如酒，
建模无限丑。
BUG遍地走，
操作虐死狗。
音乐响起不舍得走。
毁我青春费我钱财，
通关过后来诉愁，
给个好评有没有。。。。

这是个65分的跑酷探索游戏。难度低，风景有，探索少，战斗形同虚设。
特价十几块，看到大家评论[b]很休闲，画面好，好评如潮[/b]，就入了。
[spoiler]坑啊，不带这样的。[/spoiler]
[list]
[*]1， 作为一个跳跳跳的游戏，最让人不能接受的就是跳居然没做好。僵尸跳的操作，毫无愉悦感。按键还会卡顿，其他键都正常，唯独空格失效几秒。。。
[*]2， 全高特效，画面依然乏善可陈，而且全程95%都是灰暗光线，必须深夜才玩的动。
[*]3， 第一人称视角，直到通关结束最后动画，才看到了自己的左手。。。 跑酷游戏不用第三人生视角，你行的。
[*]4， 场景中被卡住多次，只能退出重来
[*]5， 没法存档，退出了再进来就必须关卡从头打起。这个谁能忍？
[/list]

     1和5能忍的话，这游戏还是能玩的，5小时流程。

     剧情什么的不吐槽。二战，精灵，曼哈顿计划，机械腿，生物炸弹，灵异现象，吸星大法，失落文明，遗弃军事基地。。。。。 编的真好，把我骗进来了

     踩着高压线溜溜溜的那几段，还有2次穿墙而出破空滑翔，算是亮点，证明这还不是垃圾游戏。

     BGM也好评，虽然半数是改编的，但是用的很贴切，搭配场景心旷神怡。

     通关后几千人的制作名单比游戏本身好看太多，原画满分！那才是本来应该做到的样子。

[spoiler]算了，给个好评吧，心太软。[/spoiler]

34319069.review:
Valley is a good game. 

I'm kidding, it's actually a game that has not too great storytelling but makes up for it with solid movement gameplay and great graphics

GRAPHICS

(I always start with graphics as its the first thing you see when you click play.) 

Valley has incredibly well done graphics for an indie developed game. The water effects are gorgeous and the lighting is very well done. The opening of the game is one of the most cinematic openings I've seen because you can simply see the light shine through the trees in real time. The enviornments are well made as well. Sometimes you'll be running along and you'll stop as you realize you're standing next to a giant statue, and the thing covering you wasn't a tree, it was its hand.

The land feels ancient as there are tons of visually appealing yet intruiging things lore-wise. The buildings are visually decayed and feel like they were once full of life. 

The only con about the graphics are the enemy designs.

You have:

purple cloud

greenish purple cloud 

black and orange ghost dude

green and orange ghost dude

and the final boss isss

a red ghost dude but big

GAMEPLAY

Probably the best part about Valley is its gameplay. Players are in control of what the game calls L.E.A.F suits, granting the player the ability to run incredibly fast, jump several stories at once, double jump, grapple hook, and even run on walls. The controls are very fluid (albeit a bit clunky while running in tight areas like vents or buildings) and the game encourages fast gameplay with the games multiple ramps and with the many running sections. 

My only complaint about the gameplay is that it starts to fall apart when it tries to bring bigger things into play. One of the game's selling points is giving and taking life from living things. While that is an interesting idea, the game doesn't dwell on it too much. The giving life mechanic is really only useful for 3 things: shooting baddies, making the enviornment look prettier, and negating the effects of you dying (the valley has a health bar, and when you die, things start to die with in the valley so that you can be resurrected. Die too many times without giving life to the valley, and it's game over.) The take life button is even more simplified and useless. It takes life from living things to give you energy to do things, but that kills the valley, and there are plenty of energy sources to the point that it's only useful for grabbing orbs from far away. Then there's the combat. It's incredibly simplified  for a game that lets you double jump, run on walls, run on water, and grapple hook. The combat is shoot baddies with your give life button until they die. The boss dies in around 30-40 or so hits, and everything else dies in about 1-3 hits. The game isn't that difficult. 


STORY

This is probably the worst part.

The story is split into 2 times. This is the main story, and it's set in present day, where our protagonist wakes up in the Valley after canoeing in the Alps in search of a world destroying item called the life seed.

This story is I'd say the weakest part. Apparently they couldn't find a person to voice the protagonist, so they made him a silent character. The problem is you can hear him grunting in game while you're running, and there are parts where the character talks. When I mean talks, I mean words float up on screen, apparently trying to reflect what the protagonist is thinking in that moment. The other problem is that the character has this "cinematic" form of thinking. They'll have a "..." when something major happens in the side story, like they're contemplating something. It's dumb, because it's basically saying they just trailed off in their own mind so they could contemplate about what happened in their own mind. Overall this story is incredibly weak, with a generic story about saving the earth and protecting mother nature. The character even undergoes a generic character arc. They come in looking for the life seed and come out with one of those "the world isn't ready for it" moments. 

Oh yeah, by the way, the life seed becomes completely forgotten about until the end of the story, where it has a contrived reason about why you had to lug it around this whole time. This leads to some minor plot holes.

On to the second part of the story, which is set during world war 2. America discovers the valley and creates LEAF suits so they can look for the life seed.

Major fuck up right at the beginning. If they have suits that can make people run faster than a cheetah, sustain bone shattering jumps, run on walls, jump 5 stories, grapple hook, double jump, give and take life INSTANTLY, and allows people to be immortal, why do they need the life seed, which they might not know is real?

Besides the slip up right there, this part of the story is relatively alright. The main woman is generally likeable until she does a character turnaround and decides to almost kill hundreds of workers for something that the game things is "something a good guy would do". The scientist is also generally likeable. He's human, he wants fame from this over the manhatten project, and he's excited over his discoveries and sometimes apathetic. Then he also does a turnaround and goes crazy, but everyone is oblivious to it except for the lady who tried to kill a bunch of innocent men.

My big problem with the second story is that it's told through (guess what?)  notes and audio recordings. The bread and butter of lazy lore implementing. There are notes scattered in rather strange places, and it's really weird that your suit just happens to play the audio files conveniently. It's also convenient that every person recorded what they're thinking about and what their secret plans are. 

On to the lore!

It's bad.

The lore would probably be a lot better developed if it stopped asking more questions, and started answering things that the player is wondering about.

When you first meet the ghost dudes your protagonist wonders "what are those things?" And it's never hinted at. It's only answered vaguely on a billboard at the end of the game.



Overall, the game is well made visually and gameplay wise, but the story is less investing than a bucket of sand.

34318373.review:
I don't usually write reviews, but here I am regardless. 

Valley is an interesting game. You will like it, IF

-You come in with reasonable expectations of what it is

-You're alright with 2-6 hours of gameplay, maybe a bit more if you go back for some secret areas

-You're okay with some pacing that goes a bit wonky

So, to explain each point. Reasonable expectations means that you know it is an adventure platformer game with some combat, basic point and click stuff though. No combos or new weapons. The big pull are the large environments with the neat platforming bits. A few points for the story being decent at least. Not exactly up my alley, but some will really enjoy it. That is all this game is though. It doesn't do much more outside what I described (not that it should, I think it pulls off each thing reasonably well and doing more would hurt it). 

I don't like talking about hours, but it took me about 2 1/2 hours blazing through it a bit in one sitting. There are some places gated off by collectables, but they just contain tiny extra bits of story or some extra bits of upgrades. By no means are they needed. I think the game fits well in the 2-6 hours and doesn't overstay its welcome for the most part, however... 

There are a couple places the pacing gets a bit wonky, once when you get stuck underground for a while, and overall I think the setpiece/speed chase sequences last a bit too long each time. Not bad by any means, the sense of speed is nice and the scenery pretty, but they drag on some. 

Overall, despite these complaints, I think it's a good game. I think it is a nice experience with some interesting story beats and very nice platforming at times. Simple but enjoyable puzzles, a lovely time.

34314978.review:
Valley è un platform game in soggettiva, nonchè un run'n'jump. Ci sono molti titoli che corrispondono a questa caratteristica, però questo è uno dei casi dove delle buone idee, realizzate bene, possono diventare una valida ragione per soffermarsi.
Nei panni di un archeologo, alla ricerca di una reliquia chiamata [i]seme della vita[/i], ci troveremo bloccati in una valle totalmente isolata dal mondo comune. Nei primi minuti di gioco, entreremo in possesso di un esoscheletro che ci permetterà di correre più veloce e saltare più in alto del normale, nonchè di cedere o acquisire energie vitali dagli esseri viventi. Come anticipato, lo scopo finale del gioco è trovare la reliquia e naturalmente riuscire ad uscire dalla valle, nel frattempo però il nostro obiettivo sarà raccogliere degli elementi come ghiande e medaglioni, i quali serviranno sia per procedere nel gioco, sia per aumentare (seppur indirettamente) la capacità energetica del nostro esoscheletro. Col tempo otterremo dei potenziamenti per poter eseguire il doppio salto, per poter correre sull'acqua, per camminare sulle pareti metalliche o per usare il rampino. Essendo il level design piuttosto curato, ci troveremo spesso ad usare ognuno di questi elementi, spesso anche in maniera combinata, durante la corsa.
In alcuni momenti, ci troveremo di fronte a dei nemici, con i quali dovremo combattere a mo' di sparatutto, colpendoli con le energie vitali che abbiamo accumulato. In caso di morte, sia essa dovuta ad un combattimento perso, sia essa dovuta ad un salto mal calcolato, verremo riportati in vita a scapito di flora e fauna circostanti. Dovremo quindi tenere d'occhio lo stato della natura, così da porre eventualmente rimedio ed allungarci quindi la vita. Ricordo difatti che oltre ad acquisire energia, possiamo anche cederla, riportando quindi in vita gli organismi.
Dato che anche l'occhio vuole la sua parte, Valley ha una grafica colorata, piacevole, e fluida la quale accompagna bene il ritmo di gioco. Sebbene gli effetti sonori non siano particolarmente curati, la musica è gradevole ed anch'essa cambia dinamicamente da fase a fase.
Dato il recente sconto ed il prezzo piuttosto arrivabile, mi sento di consigliare Valley a chi ha il piacere di passare qualche ora (andiamo dalle 5 alla decina, a seconda di quanto ci si sofferma a cercare) con un gioco dinamico, ben fatto e che sa di nuovo.
