34297435.review:
I really enjoyed myself while playing this game, It had really good graphics, nice music, and an interesting story. However, the game still had some flaws that might turn one away from purchasing the game.
Here are the things that I felt were keeping me away from giving it a perfect review. Just like almost every game, this one has it's little qwirks and issues that bog it down.
Here are the pros and cons of this game (in my opinion)

Pros:
[list]
    [*]Good Music (really immersive, helps you get into the right mood to play it.)
    [*]The story is good. It keeps you interested in it while not trying to hard to do so.
    [*]The graphics are appealing to look at and really makes you feel like you are in the enviornment
    [*]The gameplay is pretty entertaining and is enjoyable to use all the gadgets on your L.E.A.F suit
    [*]The voice acting is very believable.
    [/list]
Cons:
[list]
    [*]No replayability value. Once you finish the story mode (roughly 3-4ish hours) there isn't really too much else to do. It's like watching a "popcorn movie" It's enjoyable to watch once, but after the first time, there isn't much else to see.
    [*]You never feel any danger in the game. Throughout the entire game, I never died once. I actually would've had to try really hard to get myself killed, thus making the game a little bit boring, but not enough to pull me out of it.
    [*]The story (while nice) is a little bit predictable. Don't get me wrong, there are still parts in it that kept me guessing, but the outcome of some of the supporting characters were pretty obvious and didn't really keep my attention.
    [*]The game feels a little bit too short for it's price. I bought this game while it was on sale for 5$ and I felt like I got my moneys worth, however, if I bought it for 20$ I would feel pretty ripped off.
    [*]The variations in enemies are pretty weak. There's really only 2 different types of baddies that you can encounter, each with one with a green variation on it. Also, every enemy seemingly only took 2 or 3 shots to kill. If it weren't easy enough already, their attacks are really easy to dodge, giving no real tention to the player while in combat.
   [/list]
 [b] These Next Few Cons have minor spoilers. Be advised [/b]
[list]
  [*][spoiler]The ending of the game is pretty shitty. The big escape from SOMA is pretty exillerating, but once you actually escape, it's pretty boring. Sure it ends on a calm and peaceful note, but I felt like it should've had a little more. Like, what happens to your character? Does he stay in the valley? What happens?[/spoiler]
  [*][spoiler]The final boss battle (and only boss battle) is VERY boring. It pulls the cliche of just making one of the enemies into a bigger version of itself for a boss. I'd be completely fine with this if it wasn't the only boss in the game, but alas, it is. To put more salt on the wound, the boss never really varies with it's attacks, making the actual fight very dull and easy to do. All you do is shoot it 3 times then dodge its attacks, repeat that a few times then you win.[/spoiler}
[/list]

It might look like I hate this game due to the number of cons outweighing the pros, but I don't. I actually reccomend this game, but only buy it if it's on sale. If you don't have the money, watch a playthrough of it on youtube and you'll probably get the same experience. So if you're looking for a game with a nice story, pretty graphics, and interesting gameplay, I'd reccomend this game for you.

34276142.review:
You might think, I did not play this game that much yet. And you´re right with that.
But there are a few things, which I really wanted to mention that early.

First: The atmosphere.

Starting the game you will hear the soundtrack for the first time. If you´re not in the mood for exploring the wonderful designed world by then, you should question your purchase.
Starting the game you will get a quick introduction into the story. I won´t tell you more than you get to know from the intro:
You are playing some kind of archeologist, who wants to find a mystical thing called "lifeseed". 
Your friend questions the existence of it, but you start an adventure to find the "lifeseed" in a small area in the Rocky Mountains.
And I have to admit, getting out of the cave and seeing the eponymously valley for the first time got me pretty melancholic.
The visual presentation at all is pretty stunning and I like the style of the graphics, which made me wanting to see and explore the whole world.

Second: Gameplay and Exploration 

Talking about protagonists, you have to talk about world, since the main character seems to be pretty flat, which does not present an issue though, because the game does not want to feature an interesting and developing character. 

In the beginning you will start in a cave, slowly searching for an exit. If you think this is a walking simulator and therefore feature a pretty slow pace, you are wrong. You are able to sprint around and the game does not force you to slowly wander through the world. After at most 30 minutes (depending on how many screenshots you will take and how much time you spend looking around) the feel of the game slightly changes with the introduction of the L.E.A.F. suit.
It allows you to run pretty damn fast and jump very high. You might think, this will destroy the atmosphere of such a game, but you're wrong. Featuring wide open areas, the abilities of being that fast will still feel flowy and won´t give you the illusion, that you´re some kind of super soldier like in other games with exo-suits.

Third: Mechanics

Talking about the game, you need to talk about some pretty unique mechanics.
Having the L.E.A.F suit doesn't only allow you to jump high and move fast, you are also able to give life to eg. dead trees or animals or take life from them. Giving life costs energy, which will be taken from your 8 energy bars, which you have from the beginning. After a maximum of 60 minutes and a bit of exploring, you are easily able to upgrade it and double the amount. 
This does not make you feel like god, since you only have a few charges and  every decision you make has consequences.

Jumping into water, you will die. This is not definitive, though, as your suit revives you at the cost of draining life from the world around you. An indicator will show you the health of the world, with leaves on a branch. If you don´'t have any leaf left, the world is dead and you won't be able to respawn (I was told so). Dying makes it necessary to give life to trees, which are dead to restore the health of the world.

This mechanics pretty got me, since I´m kind of into philosophy and it made the game more interesting for me.

So, here a short version of pros and cons:

+dense atmosphere, supported by a
+great soundtrack
+visually great presented world
+wants you to explore, but doesn't force you to do so
+freedom of movement because of the suit
+neat and unique gameplay mechanics, which give the game a
+philosophical meaning

-the story is kind of flat

As I did not see much of the game, I probably will edit my review and add some points.

I'll have to say right off the batt that I could not recommend this game at full price, I purchased this game for £3.74 while on sale and for that price this game offers all you could ask for. The mechanics are satisfying and the story engaging, with an emphasis on exploration to discover upgrades collectibles and small snippets of story. 

There are two main issues that I have first of which being it's length or lack there of. I was able to finish the game in a single sitting in around 3 and a half hours and this was at a leisurely pace, exploring and taking in the sights. The second issue is it's limited use of it's own mechanics. Several of the upgrades are used only in specific linear paths to progress the story and leave very little room for experimentation. On top of that, the main starting area is probably the largest and frankly one of the only places in the game where you can properly stretch your legs.

It's a fun little game all-in-all but I feel as though this is another gem that could have been something brilliant with some more time in development and a little more ambition.

34268902.review:
I very much enjoyed Valley and wish there had been more. The story is quite enjoyable to uncover. The exploration of the game is also quite fun. Movement is fluid and exhilarating, the environments are well sculpted (most of the time) and the game flows from point to point nicely.

That being said Valley has some issues. If you're reading this before you purchase, I would highly recommend you play through it once ignoring all collectables other than those in your path of story and environment exploration. My 100% itch had me rubbing against every wall and poking my head into areas I shouldn’t even be able to get to trying to find the collectables and it destroyed the game immersion. The rewards for collecting them are nice but insubstantial so enjoy the game first and if you enjoyed it enough to keep playing, you can warp around the worlds at will to do the collection afterward.

Combat felt highly unnecessary. If you know what a first person shooter is you are not likely to have any issue with any enemies you encounter. They are all fought and defeated in the same way making encounters feel like they are designed to slow down your progression rather than provide meaning or challenge. 

Still, I do recommend bounding through Valley if you get a chance. Its not a long game, maybe 6-8 hours if you don’t do collection 10-14 to 100% it so go enjoy the view :)

打折入手的，作为内容大小5g的游戏蛮不错了，游戏的画面和优化都不错，除此之外，音乐我觉得是一个亮点，一开始主角拿到装备后那段轻快的音乐真是很赞。
剧情还没有怎么关注，主要是讲了主角从皮划艇上下来[spoiler]得到了可以+-1s的神奇装备？[/spoiler]在大自然间遨游的故事（貌似）
然后游戏机制有一些解密因素，但都是很直接简单的，视角中左上角的叶子代表命数，跳入水中或掉入深渊之类都会回溯然后损失一定叶子，然后给树木之类灌输能量会恢复叶子。

34248517.review:
It's ok.  Some of the little details, like the military installations themselves, may turn you off if you notice how weird some of the set design is.  There's some issues with your feet sinking into the ground more than they should if you look down.  Some graphical glitches with the ground moving also detract from the experience.  The entire story is short; about 3 hours, and you'd probably add a couple more hours if you want to find everything.

Definitely a unique concept of life and death to go with.

I'm skittish.  The more aggressive creatures you face get to be a little creepy, but after a while, it's obvious that they're not all that bad.  Combat is dead simple if you've ever played any type of shooter game.  There's only 1 boss fight, and it's actually kind of fun because it the mechanics weren't expected.

The sections where you get to run really fast are kinda fun.  The first time you receive the rail-charged legs is a wee bit too long, but it's still quite fun.

It could have been a metroidvania if there was more backtracking, but as it is, the game is very linear.

The options screen is very weird.  The arrows to the right actually decrease settings, rather than arrows to the left like pretty much every other game on the planet.

No puzzles.  Just a short, straight adventure.  Probably buy on sale.  I got it for $5 and it was a good evening time waster.

Spodziewałem się gry eksploracyjnej, czy może walking simulatora z ich głównymi zaletami: ciekawą historią i głębokim klimatem. Niestety, nie uświadczymy tu ani jednego, ani drugiego. Historia jest banalna, można powiedzieć, że pisana na kolanie i nie była w stanie mnie zainteresować. Grę cechuje przede wszystkim nuda. Grafika jest przeciętna, choć na screenach wydaje się piękna. Sekrety nie zachęcają do ich poszukiwania, ani nie dają satysfakcji. Klimatu nie czułem żadnego. Można grę przebiec, jednak nawet w takim szybkim tempie zajęła mi ona 6,5 godziny (czas offline się nie liczy na steam) co uważam raczej za czas stracony. Irytujący jest też fakt, że nie działa adaptacyjna ekspozycja ekranu, więc kiedy wchodzimy do ciemnych pomieszczeń (a spędzamy w nich ze 40% gry) naprawdę ciężko cokolwiek zobaczyć. Nie pomoże tutaj suwak jasności, który jedynie zmniejszy kontrast. Wobec tego grać należy w mocno wyciemnionym pomieszczeniu.

Grę można raczej odpalić dzieciom, chwilami przyjemnie jest szybko pobiegać i poskakać, ale nie wynagradza to zwyczajnej nudy w grze. Nie jest to pozycja dla fanów gier z bogatą historą, w których jest ona wciągająca i cały czas zmusza się do zastanawiania nad tym, co odkryjemy dalej. Zaskakuje mnie ponad 90% pozytywnych opinii, ja niestety nie poczułem w tej grze żadnego uroku.

34064085.review:
It was really fun 4 hours.
The Valley is a first person platformer with a focus on mobility - through your supersuit you will run fast, jump high, swing, wallrun and more, through some beautiful outdoor sceneries and abandoned military facilities. You won't encounter anything platforming-wise that should cause you much trouble, though, so it is accessible to anyone. This supermobility is done in a fun way and the controls are good enough. There's some basic combat that is trivially easy and, with maybe with the exception of the last boss, will pose no trouble whatsoever.

I really loved the game's setting - a small mysterious valley with curious source of energy, and a large top secret military complex built there during the WW2 to harness that energy for war effort purposes that's been long since abandoned and dilapidated. You will learn what went on in there through audio logs and text notes, as you usually do.

Graphically nice with pleasant music.

Only downside I'd say is the save system, there are no manual saves or checkpoints so should something happen (not you "dying", that just returns you where you were) you'll have to repeat the entire level. This wasn't really a problem for me until the very end, where at one point the world stopped loading and I fell through the map with no way to "kill" myself, and had to resort to replaying it from the beginning.

33879041.review:
It's a fun environmental/mobility puzzle game with some interesting twists and a unique system requirement:

To play this game, you need the Suspension of Disbelief Mk.III

Why Mk.III? Because there are not one, neither two, but THREE parts you need to suspend disbelief into simultaneously.

One is the usual culprit, the plot.

Second is the setting. It's so farfetched, it is unbelievable.

And third is the... Well, your primary game tool.

So let me elaborate (no spoilers here, because all of this is thrown in your face within the intro/tutorial taking first 5 minutes of the game):

During the World War II, a lot of new unrelated to each other technology is invented and developed.

Among others, two tested and working pieces are an extreme mobility "grasshopper" exoskeleton and a weapon/device that could instantly and effortlessly kill any living organism by simply draining its life energy at any range, though line of sight is required (possibly -- this is a prototype after all), but moreover, can also revive dead organisms using that energy.

What do you do? Oh, what to with duch a tech during the most intense war in the human history?.. The choice... The dilemma... Should it be mass-produced and put on a front line as personal weapon or on some robust chassis like a tank? Or maybe, the atrocity, put them on a few long range bombers and wipe a couple enemy's cities?..

No! The best answer is to slap one onto the other, even though the grasshopper suit does not need the energy leeched by that weapon (don't worry, we'll invent some ways to waste it), build 25 units and get some special forces soldiers train to hop around the obstacles not encountered in combat scenarios. To make it make any sense, we'll divide them into teams and run competitions. And have dozens or hundeds of engineers build obstacle courses for them -- so difficult that we'll have lots of these engineers die in the process or while maintaining them. (No attempt to revive them should be made. The life giving device is strictly for toying around.)

And let's also do that in a super-secret area, under complete lock-down because we need them to hop around while we develop an immense yield bomb dwarfing any nuclear device, so we can obliterate to dust entire cities. With all their infrastructure, of course. Wait, our rivals at the Manhattan Project just did that? We won't stop until we build a bomb that can wipe an entire continent!!!

Because killing off just the population is pointless. That life draining weapon needs to decorate our entertainment teams... Let me check today's score in the grasshopper teams competition...

33836029.review:
Truth be told, it's a fairly short game.  It's about a dude that randomly stumbles upon a government project basically built on an indian burial ground, that more or less involves ruining everything. 

That being said... It's an interesting game with interesting mechanics. Short-lived as it is, it's an interesting story in an interesting world. The movement is all fairly fluid and enjoyable, and that seems to be the biggest component of this game. Even above the life giving/taking aspect of the suit, this game is about running your ass off. It almost seems more like a tech demo for movement, between the tram rail sections and the emphasis on the LEAF suit's mobility-enhancing properties. Don't get me wrong, it does that fairly well. It just seems a little lean otherwise; a modern 3D platformer. Between the collectables, the linear nature of it, and the semi-limited 'lives', this game kinda reminds me of a platformer with some more fluff.

Again, it's still an interesting game. I started playing it on a night off, and finished it on the same night. Get it, but maybe get it on sale.

33819691.review:
I wasn't sure what to expect from this game when I purchased it throught the Light and Dark Bundle, but I must say I was impressed!

The game operates smoothly on my computer which has rather high specs and was beautiful every minute I played!  For me its very rare I have a game make me want to finish it the first time I get to play it, this was one of those few.  The story, while nothing super new or original, was truely fun to follow.  There was a certain degree of mystery that was there as I played through the Valley, from the beautiful forests to the dark facilities that were present.  The dialogue that played over the game was well voice acted and helped the atmosphere of the game.

The largest pros for Valley would have to be the smooth gameplay, simple, but good, story, and music.  There is one small hang for me and it had to be the combat sections.  There could've been a bit more variety or encounters with larger creatures, but for what was there it was good fun.

I would highly recommend this game to anyone willing to have a few good hours of fun and exploration.  Come explore the Valley like I did and let it take you away for some time! :D

33781026.review:
I guess, I didn't quite know what to expect with this one. I figured it would be something leaning more on the side of a platformer though, given that most of what I'd heard was about the movement in this game.

And the movement in this game is, good, very good. Exploitable even. Momentum can be a bit weird at times but it's definitely fun to just move around in this game.

But the game itself focuses more on the narrative and exploration elements and... it kind of feels wasted. The game is easy as heck, for one. I never had the valley die and judging from the achievement stats the vast majority of players who finish the game also never had the valley die. The only challenge comes from exploration, which is... not worth doing, really. All you can get is upgrades that you don't and will never need, and even the big secret the medallions unlock is... pitiful at best. And there's just... too much to explore without enough to find. And the crates you're looking for are very hard to spot normally, put them in these huge maps with lots of absurdly hidden secrets and good luck finding everything without a guide.

The game itself looks great, but also a little... bland. I don't know. Visually it's just kind of generic. Good-looking but that's about it. The soundtrack is good but some tracks end up playing too long when you slow down and explore, and they all loop pretty fast. The story is solid, mostly told through audio logs and notes, it's nothing special but it works for the game.

On the whole I would say, yeah, this is a decent game, but it also feels like a lot of wasted potential. And for $20, for what amounts to probably a 3-4 hour experience if you don't explore much, I'd definitely say wait for a sale.

33680962.review:
[b]Valley[/b] (First-person Action-adventure)

Options are many, so I'll just mention a few here.  Separate sliders for Brightness, Look Sensitivity (how fast you turn), FOV (Field of View), Master Volume and Music Volume.  'Replay Narrative Elements' is an option, you can have subtitles or no, and you can choose whether you have a Male or Female voice/character!

We have an insta-travel [b]MAP [/b]with nine areas that we can jump to (once unlocked), although there are points in the story where this option is not accessible.

You can have up to four profiles at any given time, and saves are automatic, though spaced far apart.  The did-it-save-or-not issue is one I saw a lot when looking through reviews, so here is a [b]saving tip:[/b] Pull up the menu and choose 'Travel'.  If a new area hasn't shown up on the map, the game probably hasn't saved.

I played with a controller, but I think that keyboard & mouse would be just as good... perhaps even better!

[b]Sights and Sounds:[/b]

I was immediately mesmerized by the intro music.  I just sat here with a mostly-blank title screen enjoying the instrumental for I don't know how long.  Simply beautiful! ♥ As a matter of fact, I just turned on the soundtrack for background inspiration whilst I write this review.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=2&v=Xvg7c_kj-AA

The graphics, while not the best I've ever seen, are quite lovely.  I think that I took more screenshots in [i]Valley[/i] than in any other game I've played (except for Tomb Raider 2013 - that remains #1 on my... well... most of my lists ;D )

[b]Gameplay:[/b]

Things don't make much sense in the beginning.  There is no interface, you can't jump or climb, it's just walking (or running) around looking at things.  It won't be long until you find your L.E.A.F. suit, and that's when your movement becomes truly free.  There is something so satisfying about running like a deer through the forest and jumping and soaring through the air as if you were born to fly.  It makes me smile just to think about it.

[b]The Basics:[/b]
[list]
[*]The story progresses through a combination of notes that you find and audio tapes that play when you hit certain trigger points (You can't miss the audio files - you find them at the beginning of the game).  There are also occasional text popups as our character talks to him/herself, à la [i]Ethan Carter[/i]... I think it's even the same font!
[*]Your special suit allows you to collect energized orbs, which seem to spawn all over the valley
[*]You have an ugradeable energy gauge with up to 24 cells, each of which has four power bars.  If you take a hit and lose a bar, collect an orb to replenish it
[*]Your suit has the power to give life... and to take it.  The controls are pretty simple.  Walk, run, jump, give life (shoot), take life
[*]Whenever you give life to something, there is a chance of getting one or more golden acorns (I will come back to those later).  You don't get acorns if [i]you're[/i] the one who killed the animal/foliage, so keep that in mind ;)
[*]The valley itself has a life gauge in the form of a tree branch with leaves to the left of OUR energy gauge (top left). Leaves fall off of the branch both when you kill things and when you die.  Lose all of the leaves, and the valley dies
[*]Replenish leafs by bringing things back to life.  You lose power every time you give life, and you'll die if that power gets to zero, so find a good balance between collecting orbs and giving life
[/list]
[b]The Price:[/b]

I mentioned dying, and [i]Valley[/i] handles it in a way I've never seen before.  Your suit has the power to resurrect you (so to speak, I won't spoil the mechanics here), but at a price.  Every time you die, it brings you back, but in return it takes the life of the things around you.  This is why the health of the valley suffers when you get yourself in a situation that would normally end your life for good.

[b]Crosshairs:[/b]

The crosshairs symbol changes as a quick visual cue to tell you what actions you can take.
[list]
[*]White = no action
[*]Blue = can take life
[*]Green = can give life / attack
[/list]
Colorblind?  No worries, the devs thought of that!  Each color is also a slightly different shape:  White is three separate triangles, Blue is three triangles touching each other, and Green is three separate triangles with lines between them.

[b]The Enemies:[/b]

I probably spent the first hour just exploring, bringing things back to life, collecting acorns, and trying out my suit.  To be honest, I - for a moment - thought, "Do I really want to play Valley right now?  It's kind of boring... " I did, of course, decide to go back and play some more, and I'm so glad I did.  There aren't a huge variety of enemies, and they're not terribly challenging, but they certainly added some zest to the game!  Between the story and the appearance of my first enemies, I really started enjoying the game.

You would think that "taking life" would be the proper response to enemies, but it won't do you any good... What you need to do is shoot them with your "giving life" energy.  Here's a secret for those who would like a bit of an advantage during gameplay: [spoiler]Try jumping through an amrita swarm once you've quelled it... it will fill up four bars of power, and you can do so as many times as necessary to get to full power![/spoiler]

[b]Collectibles and Upgrades:[/b]

I've mentioned them a couple of times, so it's about time I listed them.
[list]
[*]Story element pages
[*]8 "Easter Egg" pages (references to another game by this dev - you'll know them by the "unintelligible sketchings" popup that appears when you get close)
[*]Golden Acorns (used to open "acorn doors")
[*]Medallions (used to open pyramid doors)
[*]L.E.A.F. suit upgrades (mostly found via normal story progression)
[*]Power modules for L.E.A.F. suit
[/list]
[b]Quick Info:[/b]
[list]
[*]No real puzzles
[*]Revival of our character comes at cost of living things around you
[*]Can "pull" orbs to you by using the "take life" button - you don't have to physically touch them to collect
[*]Collectible items will either glow or flash
[*]The "crosshairs" symbol changes to reflect possible actions (see "Crosshairs" above)
[*]Shooting enemies is not a primary - or even secondary - focus, so don't expect to spend a lot of time doing so
[*]Some platforming required, including an area where you have to take action mid-air.  (Not as difficult as in [i]A Story About My Uncle[/i]) 
[/list]
[b]Achievements:[/b]

There are 30 achievements to be had in [i]Valley[/i].  Many come via story-progression, but you're going to have to work for some of them!  If you're an achievement-hunter like me, I definitely recommend checking out the list (or my spoiler), because if you're not careful, you could end up having to re-play the game. [spoiler]The achievement:  Immortality - Complete the game without the valley dying[/spoiler]

When you play through a chapter, you have objectives that you need to complete listed in the top right corner... but [b]when you go back to re-play a chapter, it will tell you how many collectibles are left in that region![/b]  Bonus!  Be aware that achievements - like finding a certain item - won't show up on the list.

[b]Final thoughts:[/b]

Valley is a glorified walking simulator with some shooting later in the game.  It's not going to be something that appeals to everyone.  Me?  I loved it.  The combination of music and visuals is enchanting, and the story was interesting enough that I wanted to keep playing to find out more.  My only disappointment is that I really would have liked to see an epilogue, but that aside, I had a lot of fun with this title, and will be going back in to get the rest of my achievements.  Definitely a new favorite.

33613564.review:
Ein kurzes, aber höchst unterhaltsames Spiel.

Zum Gameplay: Man erhält nach Ankunft im titelgebenden Tal einen Anzug mit erweiterten Bewegungsmöglichkeiten, der im Lauf des Spiels ausgebaut wird. Weiter und höher springen, Greifhaken, Geschwindigkeit, Magnetstiefel... - alles schon mal gesehen, aber hier spektakulär in Ego-Perspektive umgesetzt. Stellenweise hat man wirklich das Gefühl, durch die Lüfte zu gleiten; das rechne ich dem Spiel hoch an.
Nach einiger Zeit friedlicher Erkundung stolpert man auch über Gegner, die aber recht schnell und einfach besiegt sind. Die Schwierigkeit hält sich in Grenzen; die Hauptsache bleibt die Erkundung und die Bewegungsmöglichkeiten.

Zur Story: Man deckt die Story über Tonbandschnipsel (werden bei erreichen von Abschnitten automatisch abgespielt) und auffindbare Dokumente auf. Keine großartigen Überraschungen, aber gute Atmosphäre und halbwegs glaubwürdige Charaktere.

Zur Grafik und zum Sound: sehr schön und gut. Top!

Zur Welt: sehr schönes Design. Man kann sich fast nicht sattsehen an der schönen Umwelt und den liebevoll gestalteten Levels. 

Mängel: Speicherpunkte sind merkwürdig - nur zu Beginn eines Levels. Wenn das Spiel inmitten eines Levels beendet wird, darf man wieder von Beginn des Speicherpunkts anfangen. 

Insgesamt: Valley ist ein schönes, nicht zu langes Spiel mit großartiger Atmosphäre.Empfehlung!

33492861.review:
Wow. That's the quick review. Seriously though, wow! I have only 2 cons on this game: 1 - you can't customize your controls. It uses WASD which I know is the default a lot of people use but I prefer the arrow keys (I hate when the spacebar is the jump key also). 2 - I wish it was longer! Everything else about Valley is simply first-person, platformer fun (and I'm not a big fan of platformers). I had a blast finding the next upgrades for the suit to see what I could do next. My favorite upgrade was the speed rails. No, the double-jump. No, the grapple! Hell, they're all great fun! For those looking to avoid hard games, I'm a 50 year old man and I found it fairly easy to get used to the controls (even though I'd prefer using my arrow keys) and also not too difficult to understand where to go next. That's not to say this game is simple. While it's very easy to learn and find your way around, it does have some challenging areas.
Ok the graphics were great. Not particularly exciting when in underground (cave) areas but quite beautiful when outdoors with trees and grass moving around with the wind and water rippling. Sometimes the sunflares can be a bit bright; I only found 1 situation where that was a minor issue.
The sound was also very well done. When you get the suit, you can hear the sound of the shocks in the legs when you land. Between that and the graphics, it made for a realistic experience. The music in this game is beautiful and can sometimes lull you into thinking everything is okay. Though I don't know if the soundtrack is worth $25 bucks (most music CDs are around $10 bucks). 
Anyway, I had a blast playing Valley. Completed in 5 hours, so yes, very short game. I do hope they pursue a larger game and really extend usage of the leaf suit. There are tons of possibilities. Oh, and it's probably worth mentioning that you can probably spend quite a bit more time with the game than I did by exploring every corner. I pretty much played through, sticking to the quest.

33440541.review:
Игра рассчитана на любителей бродилок. Я к сим товарищам не отношусь, но музыка в трейлере была настолько хороша, что я просто не могла пройти мимо. А теперь обо все по порядку:
Сюжет у данной игрули незамысловатый, в чем-то даже скучноватый. Особенно меня неустроила его подача. Я терпеть не могу, когда сюжет в играх подается через записки. Игра должна передавать сюжет посредством визуала и аудио, а текст должен быть вторичным. Лично я забросила эти записки уже на втором часу игры. 
Геймплей прост, как два рубля. Ходишь, тыкаешь на одну кнопку, идешь дальше. Но игра умудряется время от времени подкидывать разные приколюхи, вроде уровней на скорость, перестрелок с духами, прыжками и т. д. 
Музыка здесь настолько хороша, что иногда приходилось отрываться от прохождения и тупо стоять слушать трек. (Лично я не пожалела денег на саундтрек)
Еще поралдовал тот факт, что игруля весьма размеренная. Она понимает, когда нужно менять обстановку, чтобы игрок не заскучал. (Иной раз ползаешь где-нибудь среди сосен, думаешь, насмотрелся я уже на них, и играуля тут же забрасывает игрока в древние развалины. Надоело глазеть на каменные арки, вот тебе и шахты с лабораториями.)
В общем и целом, игра оставила хорошие впечатления. Для своего жанра она действительно неплоха.

33439563.review:
Valley is a walking simulator that tries to be a parkour game, puzzle game, and atmospheric story-driven adventure and doesn't quite manage to be any of them. 

The parkour is more along the lines of 3D platforming than it is actual parkour, but it is by far what the game does best. The L.E.A.F suit is quite a lot of fun to run around in thanks to a few different features that you unlock as you play the game. For example, when running downhill, you pick up a lot of speed which allows you to jump enormous distances, which feels great to do and there are plenty of sections in the game that make full use of this, in which you fly through the pretty environments, jumping over huge lakes or chasms and flying between trees. Similarly, there's an upgrade that lets you pick up enourmous speed when running along certain rails, and there are nice, high-speed segments that make good use of that, as well. Other upgrades include the ability to walk on metal walls, a really nice, weighty grappling hook, and the ability to run on water for a time. It's fun, and fluid and for some God forsaken reason the devs decided it would be a good idea to ditch it for half of the game, and have you wander around the inside of some buildings. Those parts of the game are really very boring, and also lack a lot of the pretty visuals you get outside in the valley, where there a hills in teh distances, and huge expanses of water and so on. You do still have the suit, but you only make use of the large default jump distance.

And this is why the game fails to be a proper parkour game or 3D platformer. Only half of the time is spent actually making use of it. And what time is spent making use of it is very linear and leaves very little to be explored. This is a game that could benefit from being more open. People say that about literally every game that is at all linear but in this case it is actually true. It can't be open world for the sake of the narrative, but more large, open, explorable spaces is a must, and it doesn't have them.

As for the puzzles, they pretty much consist entirely of collecting some things to open a few optional doors, and shooting the right trees (which glow, so you can't miss them) in order to open up some other doors. Incredibly shallow, and clearly only there to spice things up slightly. But unfortunately, all they succeed in doing is slowing the game down more, which, as I've said, makes the game boring. 

The atmosphere of the game is fairly competant. There is a nice contrast between the bright, vibrant outdoor valley segments, and the cramped, dark, industrial, and even menacing power plants and other human-built areas. The music, which is generally rather good, also helps to enhance this, particularly in the outdoor areas, where it is quite reminiscent of more light-hearted action-adventure titles like Zelda. Unfortunately, the music in the indoor sections is a lot more forgettable, and in fact, quite a lot of these parts have no music at all, which just serves to make them yet more dull. 

In terms of the storytelling in the game....chances are you won't give a shit. It takes place many years before your character comes to the valley, at the height of World War 2, and is told to you through audio recordings in your suit from a couple of characters who were at the facilities in the valley at the time, as well as some optional notes that you find in boxes you can open, and on random tables and what have you. It blends together a sort of mythology with a fairly generic anti-war and environmentalist slant. It's nothing groundbreaking, but some people may enjoy it more than I did. There's a fairly respectable amount of content if you're willing to spend some time looking around for the notes. 

The game also has combat. Sort of. It's bad.

In terms of the gameplay and story elements, it's an ok game. Some will probably really enjoy it, and even those who find themselves bored by the story and slower moments will probably enjoy the faster, platforming sections quite a lot. However, there is one major flaw that stems from a very fundamental system in the game that makes me unable to recommend this game. The L.E.A.F suit requires an energy source called amrita to function, which you can extract from living things (which kills them) or find in glowing orbs around the place, of which there are bloody millions. And the devs of this game thought it would be a great idea to make this energy come in the form of bright blue light. And if, like me, you have pussy eyes, the constant flashing that happens any time you do damn near anything in this game, will hurt your eyes, or even give you a headache after more than maybe 30 minutes playing. For me this is a deal breaker, and in fact I haven't even finished the game because every time I play it I end up with a headache and feeling nauseus. If you have slightly less sensitive eyes, you'll probably be fine, but if not, avoid this game. 

Now all that aside, here is how I would improve this game: remove the bright lights, or at least dim them significantly. This is, for me, the most important aspect, since I don't like being in pain just from playing a game. On top of that, however, I think this game would be at its best if it were an action game, probably a first person shooter, that uses the L.E.A.F suit  systems to make a fast-paced, frantic shooter, which makes use of wide open spaces. I honestly think that would be a very fun game indeed, but unfortunately this is what we got instead. 

TL;DR: Competant, but uninspiring linear platformer with fun, fast open sections, and boring, slow, restricted sections. The story is environmentalist and anti war, ad will appeal to those with similar leanings. Abundance of overly bright, flashing lights will probably give some users a headache. If you are usually unaffected by lights like these, it might be worth picking up on sale (it was 75% off in the Summer 2017 sale), but if not, avoid, it's not good enough to be worth the discomfort.

33427356.review: Best Sonic the Hedgehog game i've played in years. This is not, however, a high bar.

33419856.review:
[h1]Gotta go fast![/h1]
Remember the 2D Sonic the Hedgehog games? I never considered myself a massive fan of them, but I definitely had some fun with them; especially 2, 3, and Sonic & Knuckles. The really fun parts for me were where you're running at high speeds, making long jumps, clearing huge sections of the level. However, unless you're really good at the game, most of the time, you'll be moving pretty slowly through the levels, except for those brief, high-speed, sometimes-scripted segments. Valley, on the other hand, offers to let players move at those high speeds at almost all times, making wild jumps, with cool suit upgrades that let you do even more than that. This is where Valley shines. It's those brief Sonic the Hedgehog moments, that I wished could last for significant lengths of time, that Valley accentuates and stands to rival this particular sensation for me from those older Sonic games.

[h1]Hidden persistent upgrades...in a game almost exclusively designed around running and jumping fast from A to B...[/h1]
Unfortunately, Valley has other features which are self-defeating when it comes to that potential. As much good as it does for offering high-speed gameplay, Valley contains health upgrades and what equate to keys for doors, often hidden out of the way in little boxes. To find many of these, you need to deliberately [i]stop[/i] moving at those fun, high speeds, instead wandering around, slowly and carefully searching everywhere, because the developer literally sticks some of these upgrades in some of the places you will be encouraged to zip by at the highest speeds possible in-game. Each time I started to get a big smile from exciting music, running fast, and pulling off cool jumps, I would spot another box I needed to screech to a stop to open, or worse yet, a cluttered area I would need to run around and search high and low, looking for crates to open. The game tries to be really fun, but the hidden crates do everything they can to interrupt that fun.

Now, do you [i]need[/i] the hidden crates? No. Honestly, you don't. I'm not very good at games, and you don't need that many health upgrades. However, I didn't know one way or the other, starting the game out fresh. From what I now know, I would say that if you plan on playing this game and you can set aside the urge to go trying to find all of the crates, then you can probably have a good time by just opening crates and grabbing goodies you see while you run along. Don't explore at all. So to clarify: you're running, see a crate or unlockable door, grab it/go in, and then keep going after collecting the stuff. The momentum in this game is so fun, but these constant slow-downs were not.

Also, unlike some Metroidvanias (Dust, Shadow Complex, the Batman Arkham series, etc.), nothing tells you "Hey, there's a secret somewhere in the area," or anything like that. You will actually have to run around, manually checking pretty much everywhere in a game where you cover many square miles of distance. I reiterate: unless searching for tons of hidden items that won't do you much good and don't feel like they really have a worthwhile payoff is something you love, just don't bother searching. Just grab goodies when you come across them, and life will be good. If I'd done that, I might have had a pretty good time with Valley, but as it is, the fun was spoiled thanks to all the stops and long searching.

[h1]Clever Audio Logs...Not-So-Clever Documents[/h1]
The story is mostly told through audio logs, which is [i]brilliant[/i], because you can keep moving and listening while running along through the environment, and I thought the voice acting was well done. However, similar to what they did with upgrades, the developer put notes in crates, on the floor, on tables, and on walls, which have multiple lines of text for you to read. I would [i]love[/i] this in a slow-paced game like an older Resident Evil game, or the newer RE7, but not in Valley. This is a pretty game with pretty music, and it's fun using the L.E.A.F. suit to run fast and make crazy jumps, etc. Puttering around slowly looking for notes isn't all that fun, and though you obviously don't have to, you would be missing out on a wealth of lore. I think much of this lore could've been turned into audio logs for the voiced characters to discuss with slight changes to their voices (voice actors can do different voices, typically, of course). When the game has you stop or slow down, things like objects in the world and your perspective height being mismatched (you should be about 7 feet tall or so in the suit) kinda start to stand out.

I will say, however, that there is [i]one[/i] room right after a big battle (there is only one "big battle" in the game in my opinion), which I do highly recommend taking your time to look around, read the notes, and look at everything. I found it pretty unsettling and well-done. Other than that, though, run like mad when you can to have the best experience.

[h1]Zelda had the Hookshot. Valley has the Hookshit.[/h1]
The last thing I need to discuss is the grappling hook, also known as the "viper coil." It's basically the hookshot from Zelda games if it was possibly the worst grappling hook to ever appear in a video game. There were many times I would perfectly grapple, get yanked toward my target, and not quite reach it. There didn't seem to be much rhyme or reason as to whether or not I would reach my destination, but I had many quantum deaths caused by this, and didn't really do anything differently on the times I was successful. It was a crapshoot whether or not the grapple would give me enough momentum. I tended to have better luck when standing perfectly still sometimes, and while running at average speed others. There wasn't much rhyme or reason to it, and dying when you didn't do anything wrong is pretty aggravating.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
I really wanted to enjoy Valley, and there were [i]moments[/i] that I did. However, the rubbish grappling hook and the game's built-in mechanic of hidden upgrades and notes to read slows down that glorious momentum each time the game tried to present something that would otherwise be really fun to do. This undermined the biggest positive the game had for me to such an extent that my overall experience was not a good one.

33409520.review:
Valley is a mix of a walking sim, first person shooter, and a Sonic game. You'll spend a lot of the game wandering around listening to audio logs and reading notes left behind as you try to figure out What Went Wrong.  The shooter elements are minimal, but serve to mix things up a little bit.  Where the game is a bit more unique is the Sonic aspects.

Early on, you get a suit that you upgrade throughout the game, giving you the ability to run along walls, grapple, and jump in ways that make exploring the environment pretty fun.  There's some extended high-speed sequences that are better than anything from a modern Sonic game, and are the real differentiator for this game.

The central mystery is alright, but drags a little in the middle.  The game is nice to look at and the gameplay gets better as it goes along.  I recommend the game for people looking the atmosphere of a walking sim, but with a few more gameplay mechanics than is typical for the genre.  It's a pretty short and easy game, but worth going through.

33401145.review: 有点意思，游戏用UNITY引擎制作，但画面比一般UNITY做的好，物理效果也不错。但是仍然免不了UNITY常常遇见的 卡帧、同时按键卡顿等问题。游戏故事性一般并没有太多复杂的事情，剧情也是流程式，主要是以观光解密为主，游戏方式还是有些创意的，特别是生命值的想法很有意思，这里不透露了，要玩的时候自己看看

33398229.review:
Creo que este es el primer analisis que hago para steam, y este juego se merece uno por mi parte.

Para mi Valley ha sido una forma muy refrescante de volver a los juegos en primera persona que tratan de viajar a lo largo de un (grandioso y maravilloso, con un magnifico cambio en cada zona) mapa.
El movimiento frenetico, poder ir corriendo y saltando a cualquier parte. Las zonas de velocidad máxima ya sea en los railes conductores o en las rampas para luego salir lanzado hacia el cielo, todo eso hacen de la jugabilidad algo excelente.

Por mi parte, la historia me ha llegado a intrigar, teorizando mentalmente porqué existen los espiritus que vemos a lo largo de la aventura, el porqué del proyecto, etc.

Una mecanica muy importante del juego es el "cañón" para dar y absorver vida. Yo soy de los que intentaban revivir a todos los arboles y animalillos muertos, y la idea de que al morir revives con la propia "vida" del valle me parece fascinante.

Y por ultimo, por qué no hablar de los graficos? Quitando las tipicas plantas enredaderas y algunas hojas de los árboles en general el juego se ve muy bonito, además, la composición del valle, como está colocado todo lo hacen bastante creible, y además ayuda a la hora de moverse por él.

En conclusión, este me parece un juego muy pero que muy bueno que destaca en varios aspectos que hacen el juego único y espectacular como la movilidad y la mecánica de la vida en el valle, aunque flojea un poco con la historia y la duración (el final justo después de acabar con "Astra" me pareció un poco forzado, pero no estuvo mal).

Así que recomiendo este juego a todo el mundo, sobretodo si está al 50% o por debajo :p. Sin mucho mas que decir, disfrutad de este juego.

This game is easily one of the best "walking" simulators out there.  The valley is gorgeous, the music is haunting and the traversal is exhilarating.

The game is fairly short so it might be prudent to wait for sale.  But the length itself is fine as the game doesn't overstay its welcome and is decent variety of environments. eg. The open fields of the valley, underground caverns, industrial complexes.

33395255.review:
It's fine, but definitely not worth it at full price. Flying through the air is a bunch of fun, and when you get to high speeds the movement feels really good. There are some really cool ideas here, like granting life and running on walls, that would have been really interesting in a bigger game with more going on. But here they feel more like a proof of concept. That was a lot of the game really, it didn't seem to go anywhere. It introduced some very basic combat, but then made it easier to just run past enemies. Despite the minimal combat, there was a big end boss that felt like it was out of a totally different game. 

The movement in the game is really fun and feels great when it gets going, but there's not much else to the thing. Any time you don't have momentum it feels sluggish and dull, which makes exploring for collectables feel like a chore. There also really isn't much of a challenge to the game, it's mostly just moving through the levels, with the occasional confusing design choice that gets you killed or a quick and simple puzzle to keep moving. It's not quite simple enough to be a walking simulator, but not complex enough to stand out outside of the genre. Especially with a story this weak. The voice acting is a very mixed bag, ranging from decent to cringe-worthy. The acting itself isn't helped by bad recordings, poor audio editing, some writing that's fairly poor in places, and a story that isn't all that interesting. They have so little faith in their own material, they often have text pop up on screen to explain the audio tape you just heard in case you stopped paying attention.

I'm probably being too hard on this game. It does certain things very well and it's quite pretty. But it doesn't really know what it wants to be, cribbing the plasmid tutorials from Bioshock, a pointless opening sequence reminiscent of SOMA, level design out of Temple of Doom, it's aesthetically all over the place. It's not worth full price when it's only three hours long, but if you like the look you could get plenty of value on sale. But A Story About My Uncle does most of this stuff better, so play that first.

33394166.review:
I found this game to be very satisfying.  I played it primarily with an XBox One controller over the Steam Link on my 50" TV and the whole experience was just awesome.  No, it's not a difficult game, but it's beautiful, the game mechanics are fun, and the story is well done. It reminds me somewhat of A Story About My Uncle in that both titles use unique game mechanics (although they both share grapple hook gameplay) and tell the story little by little as you make your way across the map.  Valley is a very linear game--there's really only one way forward  but you are rewarded a bit by exploring the maps.  The voice acting is solid as is the music.  Graphics are often far above average, but can also be rather boring  in spots.  Specifically, some outdoor areas that you are meant to run through scale back the detail in order to focus you on the correct path forward.  Likewise, once inside some facilities, the rooms often blend together because they contain the same desks, etc.  That is, however, a small criticism because the majority of the graphics are superior--unique, imaginative, and authentic--giving a real sense of "place" and enhancing the atmosphere.


The only real complaint I have is that when you exit a game, you are generally forced to replay a portion of the mission unless you previously quit at the very beginning of a mission.  It's not a big deal, it just annoyed me slightly.

This title normally sells for $20, and at that price you probably want to wait for a sale.  It's not that the game isn't worth it, but it certainly isn't a AAA title, and it is rather short.  Replay value is questionable and the main draw is to just collect items you might have missed.  But I do recommend Valley...it is a beautiful, fun little game that will give you probably 5 or 6 hours of gameplay.

33301234.review:
Exhilerating and beautiful, but ultimately poorly conceived fluff.

The main issues with the game to me from a design standpoint, are that there are a few great tastes that don't go together. 

The valley is a first person platformer, with a set of metroid style suit upgrades, some random objects to collect, and the tried-and-true narrative style of a voice talking in your head and diary entries strewn about. None of these elements really go together for me, though I keep hoping it will click at some point.

The running and jumping mechanics on their own are really fun, but they are coupled with an energy mechanic that makes you want to do these cool actions as infrequently as possible. Speaking of the energy mechanic, you actually almost always have enough, due to the energy orbs being spread out everywhere - and you can always find a tree to bleed dry. The energy both makes the core mechanic less fun, and feels inconsequential on it's own. The scenery is beautiful - but the art design makes it hard to read the environments and determine where to go. It is also difficult to find the objects you are trying to collect, and I always feel like I have missed something. But then, it turns out you almost always have enough of the items when you get somewhere that needs them (which is rarely).

The story is not very engaging either. I would think learning about this secluded valley and what the army was doing there would be interesting, but there are no characters worth mentioning, and not much of a story really. It's all exposition. To make matters worse, even if you ignore the narrative, the beautiful environment fails to tell a story of it's own. You collect your upgrades from glorified ammo crates that were left there for no discernable reason.

I wanted to like it, especially after the opening and the jaw-dropping reveal of the lush valley, but the more I played, the more annoyed I got. Still worth a shot if you like these kinds of games, and perhaps want to take the platforming and artwork at face value while ignoring the flaws - but there are better options out there.

Interesting game but the horrible save system makes it very frustrating.

There are only a few discrete save points in the entire game (less than 10) which are based on map locations, but is is very unclear when you reach one.

You think you'll have reached a save point and stop (because the name of a new location pops up on screen) only to reload the game and have to replay a huge section.

I'm not clear on the exact rules, but it may be that the way the game is designed, you do have to replay the sections. The point were a save location is added may be after the point that same save location sends you to.

It's as if they want you to play the game in one sitting, which while this isn't a long game, is a little ridiculous.

I would reccomend the game if it wasn't for this one thing, so if that doesn't bother you, go ahead.

Also, while this isn't a horribly buggy game, if you do bug out and have to restart from a save point (happened twice) it is incredibly frustrating. The save system has  added at least two hours to my overall time.

33240880.review:
Honestly, I formed an emotional attachment with this game. I've been suffering from depression for a nice chunk of my life because of a life event I refer to as "ghost". A lot came from it, like suicidal thoughts, severe paranoia, depression, and more. I found gaming as an escape and started getting games off Steam once I got my new laptop for Christmas. Valley was one of the ones where I just glanced at it, and instantly bought it. I started playing this when I was going through some pretty heavy times. I saw Valley as an escape into an beautiful unknown world, and I absolutely enjoyed it. One day I sat down, and thoughts flooded my mind as the game was starting up. My aunt passed away weeks before, my dog was sick, my uncle died around the time I started playing Valley, and a whole lot of other things. The sadness just hit me like a tsunami. I just kind of sat there trying not to cry. Then the menu song started to play. It honestly never felt so good to cry and break down like that. After I was done, I started playing for a bit. Just seeing the Daemons play made me smile. I was at ease. I was happy. I absolutely loved the lore and storyline. I loved everything in it, from the beautiful graphics and landscape, to the random deer you'd find, all the way to the incredible creativity and concept of the game. I had to reset my laptop because it got a virus, so I plan on playing again soon so I have it finished again. I'd relive the journey in Valley over and over again. I love this game so much. ❤️

Edit: My baby brother was born today 7/10/17. But I lost my bestest friend, Ginger. Me and that dog have been through so much together. Me and her were inseparable. Rest In Peace 💔

Warning, for those who haven't played the game and are leaning towards buying it, avoid spoilers as much as possible. It's not a game you want spoilers for, even if you think you know what's going on just from the trailers. Do buy it, it's an amazing game that you won't regret. That being said, time to continue.

I beat the game in 8.7 hours. Technically less, I accidentally left my computer on while I went to do stuff for a few hours. I haven't gotten everything, I still need to get into the pyramid, and then I've done everything to do. The scenery is absolutely BEAUTIFUL. I spent the first hour of actually playing just admiring the scenery and running around, taking screenshots, giggling at the daemons. The gameplay is mostly smooth, the graphics are great(even on low), and I was getting decent frames on my laptop. The story was good, but I feel like there was a lot of build up for little payout, but it was still remarkable. The whole backstory to the Valley is quite interesting, and it left me feeling hungry for more. Some concepts in the game work incredibly well, like the life give/take. Some things don't work well. Like using the same system for combat, and having your health and ammunition as the same bar. Some things become natural feeling, like using the jump to go across entire rivers and crevices(Though never ceases to be amazing). Some things? Not so much. Like running on water, which felt like it was introduced late and then was used very little, only in like 3 scenes. Then, in the end section, you cannot use them to simply run on water. Granted, at the very end, it's understandable. Over all, 8/10, loved the game but felt like I needed more afterwards. Do I smell a sequel? Probably not.

Dieses Spiel spielt sich flüssig wie ein Ego-Shooter, ist nur viel schneller. Es fängt langsam und gemütlich (und niedlich) an, doch zum Ende wird es immer schneller. Es kommen kaum Schussszenen vor, nur in dem letzen Drittel wird es für Kinder gruselig, das erste Drittel läßt sich wunderbar spielen, wenn Kinder zuschauen.
Es macht unheimlich Spass durch diese Welt zu laufen und der Geschichte weiter zu folgen und das Ziel zu erreichen. Es ist fordernd, dennoch nicht zu schwer.
Ich bewerte das Spiel folgendermaßen:


Balancing   21 von 25 Punkte
Grafik         22 von 25 Punkte
Sound        24 von 25 Punkte
Spielspass  22 von 25 Punkte

Gesamt: 89 von 100 Punkte

RIYL: the Portal games, The Witness, the Talos Principle

TL;DR: A fun little first person platforming romp. Definitely worth buying on sale (as I did), probably worth buying at full price

It's a first-person adventure-exploration-platforming game about jumping really high and running really fast. In that sense, it's a fantastic game, a lot of fun. The environments are beautiful, the platform puzzle/challenges have been challenging but forgiving (so far), and exploration has been fairly well rewarded with extra energy cell things. I wish things were a little lighter/brighter--turning the brightness up leaves things washed out, but too low and it's kind of hard to see things and really enjoy the environments (and see the side paths that lead to the bonus stuff). That may be an issue of my visual problems though, your mileage may vary.

The story is kind of meh, nothing spectacular but nothing too terrible either. The characters telling the story are more enjoyable than the story they tell, personally. 

The controls seem kind of sludgy, but that may be because I'm using a Steam Controller and don't have all the settings tweaked just right. If I remember I'll update this again after I play using KB&M or a traditional analog controller.

33114738.review:
I just finished Valley mere minutes ago and I have to say this was an intriguing and fun game. It's also one of the very, very few games I've started for the first time and completed it in one sitting, about 6'ish hours.

My take on the game, and maybe I'm wrong--I haven't read other reviews on it--but I see Valley as a reminder of the harmful effects industry and the "pursuit of progress" can have on the environment, both flora and fauna. It also was a reminder that absolute power corrupts absolutely.

Now, the information--mostly by Virginia since she's the anthropologist--about the statues in the valley and the other observations she mentioned along the way I'm still puzzling out in regards to how it relates to the Pendulum project. I'm not completely sure there IS a relation; it could just be circumstantial. Whether or not Andrew Fisher knew the place he set up Soma and Astra was considered sacred by the ancient civilization(s?) that lived in that area, BEFORE he set those facilities up, I'm not completely sure.

Regarding the gameplay....for the most part it felt like a game of exploration, with the creatures you had to pacify being the only "combat." However, I believe they were just put there to be another obstacle to consider, but there could have been more diversity.

There were a few bugs I found along the way, too, primarily the music sometimes would stop for long stretches of time and then start back up. Or it would start and never end when it should have ended. Once there were two soundtracks going at the same time and it had me wondering if maybe a webpage I had open was playing music. Other bugs I encountered was clipping almost entirely through large boulders when accelerating at greater speeds and acorns that could not be picked up.

Overall, I really enjoyed this game and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys exploration and beautiful scenery. I'm kinda hoping there is a Valley 2 as I believe there's more story here than was revealed.

Es kommt ohne großartige Gewalt aus, man kann leben nehmen und geben, man stirbt und sieht wie das Tal immer mehr "stirbt" aber man hat die Kraft es wieder in vollen Leben erstrahlen zu lassen und dadurch wieder die möglichkeit hat durch Erkundung oder Fehler das Leben zu lassen. 33009207.review:
Ce jeu est une pure merveille, on prend vite plaisir à ce déplacer avec la "LEAF Suit", les décors exterieurs sont fabuleux et donnent envie d'explorer chaque parcelle de terrain disponible.

La capacité d'oter ou de redonner la vie à la faune et la flore de cette vallée est une idée vraiment inetéressante et peu donner plusieurs facons d'aborder le jeu, pour ma part je rechignais beaucoup à prendre une vie animale ou végétale ( hormis quelques rares champignons fluorescents) et m'efforcais de redonner splendeur aux arbres et arbustes dès que j'en avais l'occasion.

On découvre avec avidité chaques nouvel enregistrement audio qui lèvent le voile un peu plus sur ce qu'il c'est passé ici, on se prend vite d'amitié pour certain protagonistes disparus depuis longtemps(ou d'inimitié pour d'autre).

Les décors et structures intérieurs me rappellent mes premières incursions dans Rapture (Bioshock), une technologie avant-gardiste d'après-guerre mélangé aux différents enregistrement audios (avec la photo d'époque en vignette) font penser à ceux du titre de Bioware.

Le système de sauvegarde par checkpoint oblige a finir un niveau mais on a tellement envie d'en voir plus que les checkpoints s'enchainent avec facilité et si par "malheur" vous deviez arreter au milieu d'une région vous redemarrer au checkpoint précédent et recommencerer avec plaisir a parcourir les kilometres au chaud dans votre "LEAF Suit"

Merci Blue Isle Studio pour cette magnifique aventure

Tytułowa dolina jest pięknym, lecz też niebezpiecznym miejscem. Przemierzając ją w z pomocą egzoszkieletu L.E.A.F nie możemy się nudzić. Każda nasza porażka ma wpływ na dolinę,jej wygląd oraz na wszystkie żyjące w niej istoty. 
Wędrując po świecie gry napotkamy zapierające dech krajobrazy.
Nowe umiejętności są bardzo dobrze rozłożone w czasie. Do ostatniego momentu poznajemy możliwości ulepszanego egzoszkieletu. Gdy wydaje nam się, że już nic więcej nie jest w stanie nas zaskoczyć, gra właśnie to robi, zaskakuje nas po raz kolejny. 
Zdecydowanie największym plusem gry jest soundtrack. Muzyka przez większość czasu jest idealnie wpasowana w klimat gry i pozwala się cieszyć ze słyszanych przez nas dźwięków, aż po sam koniec napisów. 
Niestety gra ma też kilka minusów. W pewnym momencie natknąłem się na zbugowane drzewa których nie dało się ożywić. Z kolei walka z większością przeciwników jest po prostu monotonna, nudna, zrobiona jakby na siłę. 
Tak czy inaczej polecam Valley, podejrzewam, że sam nie raz wrócę do tego tytułu, bo rozgrywka jest po prostu przyjemna.

32850194.review:
This is an amazing game, probably along the lines of what I expected Mirror's Edge to feel like, and then a bit more. It's linear and the combat is pretty easy, but both of those are a backseat to the main draw of the game: the suit. You're gonna be running, leaping, falling, gliding almost nonstop. The suit gets better as the game progresses, and while there is an energy system, its not usually a burden. All that adds up to mean that the game is [b]FUN[/b], which is exactly what a game like this should be. On sale, this is absolutely worth it. The story takes no more than 4 hours and theres a lot of collectible hunting for a post-game.

If you're not convinced, let me describe a part of the game for you: There is a point where you need to get deeper into a mountain to find an abandoned reactor. You get an upgrade which lets your suit energize the rails as you run along them. What follows is about 10 minutes of sprinting along empty tunnels and caverns at blistering speeds while intense music plays. That's what sealed the game for me in my eyes. It was just so overwhelmingly enjoyable. The game is fun, I really can't say anything more. If you like going fast and you like soaring through the air then you will love this game.

32848569.review: I liked this game quite a lot. It does have an interesting story, with some decent voice acting, but the biggest reason to play and enjoy this is for the chance to run, jump, and run some more through beautiful scenery. The levels are designed well enough that the places you go, and things you do, are intuitive and fluid, and you can charge through vast open areas feeling like the Flash, or Sonic the Hedgehog in the Emerald Hills and Temple Ruins levels. There is very little to break up the enjoyment of the platforming and exploring, with the "enemies" you encounter both making sense, and generally not being a huge issue to deal with. My only issue is that, once I had completed the game, I did not enjoy going back and looking for all of the secrets as much as I woul dhave expected. I literally fell asleep twice while doing it. But even so, it is well worth the money.

Do like me and grab it on a sale.

32838299.review:
[h1]Valley is less of a game and more of an "experience"[/h1]

Valley is a game with very simple game mechanics: you progressively run faster when going down hill and can leap a tremendous distance. Later on you gain the ability to latch onto hooks in the air that assist in traversing large gaps. Ultimately you get the ability to run on water for short periods, which is sparsely used towards the end of the game. There is no challenge in any of these activities and nothing complex or requiring of ingenuity or a mixture of gameplay elements to proceed.

So what's the draw? Quit simply; running. The game has a fantastic sense of speed and acceleration --- it's like Sonic the Hedgehog but in first person. The enjoyment doesn't come from any intricate plot, or complex game mechanics that are used ingenously. Rather, it's all about running really fast and doing so often. The developers punctuated the whole experience with a beautiful Nordic soundtrack that plays during certain portions which makes it all feel whimsical. A strange sort of game whereby the enjoyment and draw is more about fiddling with a game mechanic more than anything else. It's almost like a rollercoaster: you're there for the ride. And it's an enjoyable ride that doesn't overstay its welcome. Much like mirrors edge there's no challenge per-se; it's all about running and experiencing a sense of speed. 

Speaking of Mirrors Edge; this title also suffers from unnecessary combat implemented into the game. It's not a big deal since the fights aren't long and you can run past the few, sparse enemies there are. But there's a half-assed boss fight towards the end that feels completely out of place, much like all the combat in Mirrors Edge. Just because your game is in first person doesn't mean it needs to also be a shooter. 

The game also has a mechanic which allows you to give life or take life away from the environment around you, but it serves no purpose other than making the forest look nice and placing life back into the surroundings, which is displayed as a health gauge. Once the gauge reaches zero its game over. What does a game over look like? I honestly don't know and doubt that at least half the fanbase does either since it isn't a difficult game. Overall its another pointless mechanic that, with some fleshing out, might prove useful but otherwise does nothing of any significance. 

I'll also lambast the use of audio tapes: I liked them in Bioshock since they were audio files left about that characters left behind. There was no exposition: you might find an audio file belonging to a character that begins mid-sentence and he is speaking of characters you know nothing about. It's up to you to piece all the information together and understand what's going on. Valley on the other hand uses audio files as exposition, which doesn't make any sense. Have you ever recorded something for yourself or left a note for yourself that begins with you explaining who you are, what you do, the year and date, and what your occupation is? It's incredibly lazy. I'm tired of audio files since no one seems to understand how to properly use them as a narrative device. It's just another way of having a character talk whom isn't on-screen.

My complaints aside; this is a 5 hour game (max) that is all about experiencing a sense of speed across lush environments. There is no real challenge to any of this, it's like a rollercoaster: it's about experiencing it. It feels slightly experimental in that there are a lot of good ideas here that I'd like to see fleshed out. If some challenge was included and more of the experience was about picking up speed and maintaining it (much like in Sonic Generations) then I can see this game's length being extended. Otherwise, the game is enjoyable enough and doesn't overstay it's welcome. If there was ever a title that was made for VR, this is it.

And on that note I'll also say that this game is one of those where graphical fidelity matters. So if you have a toaster I'd pass on it. I'll also say that it's worth nowhere near 20 dollars-10 dollars tops. Get it if you want to experience speed in beautiful environments punctuated by a wonderful soundtrack. There's nothing difficult here but there is something beautiful.

32822002.review:
Valley - an atmospheric adventure.

With Valley you get an interesting and beautiful made game.
A story telling,  atmospheric adventure with jump and run and puzzle features including a small touch of steampunk and metroidvania. 

You being thrown into this amazinglycreated landscape, exploring and adventuring through it. 
Very soon you get the narrative element of the game, the story.  It feels like a very stereotype story at the beginning, though it got some interesting twists build in. And all the time I just had one question in my mind as it has been told. "What am I doing here?"

It follows a very linear path but you dont get pushed at all.
The whole atmosphere of this game is very relaxed. 
With the well composed music build into you experience a very unique game where I would just love to go through for hours.
Allthough later in the game it had some almost horror like vibes to it, like it wants to show to you that its not just only nice but can also be dark.

The game never throws a big challenge at you, it's here for your enjoyment. 
Want to take a break from all these horrendously hard games? Play Valley.
There is only minor "fighting", it is not the focus of this game at all. 
Everything you will need in the game to progress is made easily accessible for you.

All over, I did beat the game in 4.5 hours. 

For the completionist under us, you have a lot to explore and look for wich is just great. I think you can spend another few hours with finding every collectible. Non of those are needed though to finish the game, and at the point where you actually need some of those, the game basically throws them at you.


The only few downers that I had were a few glitches here and there and objects like towers that I could find and jump to but 
not actually climb as it didnt seem to be intended and invisible walls blocked them. I would have loved to climb these and look over the scenery.
I climbed that mountain in Skyrim etiquette though I have to say.
Once I even skipped a door by accident that I didnt unlock yet.... I jumped back and unlocked it anyway, but it showed me that there are still some flaws to it. 

So my summary for this game:

Valley is an atmospheric adventure that takes you by the hand and guides you through the story with only a few challenges.
It doesnt want you to rage at it, it wants to tell a story. If you are looking for a nice experience with a beautiful scenery, this is your game.

If you are looking for a super hard challenge, masses of enemies, brain melting puzzles and hard plattforming, you are wrong here.


Oh and I forgot : You can see your feet and legs. Yes. You play a First Person View game and you can see Legs and feet. 10/10 would loot at them again.

32797093.review:
**i got this game on sale at $5 so this is from the perspective of paying that much**

Nice little short fun adventure game that has a decent amount of exploration and secrets. Environments are great, music is great as well. Strays close to being a walking simulator (not as much platforming/action as youd expect) but it's ok since the story is somewhat interesting, the world is finely crafted, and there's enough action between these sets that you don't get too bored.

The entire thing feels like a precursor to something great, you have a lot of great elements but they're never really fleshed out; You get introduced to fun elements, and then you get to play with them for a short section and that's it. The "rails" section was probably the most fun. It'd be cool to see some actual challenge with these mechanics they put into the game.

If you're looking for a nice little relaxing explore/run narrative game to kill in an afternoon this is a good way to go. At $20 idk if I could recommend the same. This game could benefit from a sequel which focused more on the gameplay than the story. With some good level design utilizing the speed and energy management that would be a pretty damn fun game.

Pretty damn good!  It's an indie game, so it's not as tight or as long as major games.  But very engaging and fun to play. 32707494.review:
You have to play this if you feel the need.
The need... For speed. 

First off, I don't remember adding this to my wishlist. Secondly, I don't remember hearing or seeing a wink about this game up until I decided to clean up my wishlist. It's a crying shame that I didn't play this gem sooner.

The gameplay is all about momentum. Remember the feeling of running down a hill as a kid? Well this game is the imitation of that feeling in video game form. It's actually quite similar to sonic in many ways, but I could say it tags a lot of games in terms of how it "feels" (Vanishing of Ethan Carter, Bioshock, SOMA, A Story About My Uncle, Portal, the list could go on...)

I should make it clear that this game is less of a challenge and more of an experience. You probably won't find any area too difficult and the "combat" consists of pointing and shooting enemies with energy. If you die, you respawn, but you are held accountable for retaining your [strike]sonic rings[/strike] orbs and keeping the forest alive... The game will explain how that works. Also, my advice would be to explore, but not too much... The game encourages you to really go out of your way sometimes when it's obvious, but other times I found myself climbing a mountain that I suppose I actually wasn't supposed to climb... Getting out of the map essentially. If the developer wants you to go somewhere, they won't make it so difficult that you have to die 10 times to get there... I learned that the hard way.

All in all, the best review I read used the word "catharsis" to describe this game. It's one great big rush from beginning to end... Speedrunners might think this is one of the greatest games ever.

ハイジャンプもできるしどんな高所から落ちても平気で、動植物から生命エネルギーを抜き取って殺したり、逆に吹き込んで蘇生させたりできる不思議スーツで野山を跳び回るジャンプアクション系FPS。

生命エネルギーはそこらに光球の形でも落ちてるしある程度はスーツに貯蔵でき、敵を殺すための弾として撃ち出したり二段ジャンプするためのコストとして消費したりする。弾一発、ジャンプ一回分で救えたはずの鹿が一頭死ぬ。びっくりするほど命が安い。

もちろん残弾補給目的でいちいち鹿を殺してなんかいられないので、生命エネルギーを補給できる電池もどきやら補給所みたいなものが登場する。それ作るために何頭の鹿を殺したんだ。

32640077.review:
This game has a very interesting mix up of genres that make it a really engaging, rewarding experience from beginning to end.

It is mixed genre: Walking simulator, first person platformer, racing, RPG and shooter. The mechanics are expanded over time and introduced to you at a really good pace. I wasn't bored at all throughout the story. The game is all killer, no filler, a truly unique experience.

The biggest problems I've found with walking simulators is lack of engaging gameplay. Valley solves this by giving you sonic-like movement so you can explore the beautiful world and enjoy every moment doing it!

Music is beautiful as well, very medieval folk sound with a lot of variation in the tracks.

Highly recommended!
