[h1] А Густой лес и вправду имел недобрую славу. Иногда там видели блуждающие огни, иногда – людей в зелёных одеждах, которые шли, не касаясь земли. Так что в нём вполне могла жить прекрасная ведьма, которая заманивает в свои сети молодых охотников.[/h1]
Ещё одно интересное приключение. Оказываемся в пещере, подбираем костюм и оно начинается...
[h1] Странный этот мир, где двое смотрят на одно и то же, а видят полностью противоположное.[/h1]
Вот такие ,,Симуляторы ходьбы,, мне нравятся больше. Помимо того, что красивые локации, ещё и не скучный геймплей. 
-Тут можно просто бегать, прыгать, и любоваться пейзажами. 
-Довольно забавные ,,Духи леса,, 
-Управление. ЛКМ-Дать жизнь. ПКМ-отобрать жизнь. Пробел, WASD и E. Всё.
-Дать, забирать жизнь можно и у животных, и у объектов. После убийства врагов, остаётся их душа, которую можно опять вернуть к жизни.
-Нужна энергия для этого всего. Орбы с энергией разбросаны по всей карте, так же энергия даётся за то, что вы забираете жизнь.
[h1] Знаешь, как появились сказки? Никто не хочет верить в реальность.[/h1]
-По ходу прохождения дают всякие улучшения для костюма.
-Локации огромны для игры данного жанра, красивые, наделены животными, но пустые. Исследовать бессмысленно. Но просто побегать можно, помечтать.
-Саунды. Они тут такое себе. Просто где-то на заднем плане присутствуют иногда и всё. Не западают в душу
-Главная проблема. В игре нет русского. Вроде рассказывается интересная история, но понять тяжело.
Субтитры, тут ещё можно вполне понять, о чём говорят. Но мысли ГГ. Записки. Это тяжело. 
Что касается субтитров. Когда бегаем, ГГ может воспроизводить записи, где люди рассказывают. что здесь происходит, кто это такие и прочее о лесе, обо всём.
Но т.к. это динамичный ,,Симулятор ходьбы,, мне охото бегать, прыгать, летать, наслаждаться пейзажами, давать, отбирать жизни. Но приходится постоянно переводить, и правильно ты понял, или не правильно, вот и думай. Мне удобнее, когда за меня уже всё перевели. Ты просто читаешь и всё. А рассказывают тут обо всём довольно часто. Что-то понятно, что-то нет, и это минус.
Это возможно бы подошло, для игр таких жанров, типа Файрвотч. Где весь геймплей максимально медлительный. Там заняться больше нечем всё равно. Пока идёшь куда-то, можно сидеть переводить. 
-Просадки до 50 фпс на HIGH. А так оптимизация норм.

32568154.review:
Valley is a gem of a game. It's proof that honing in on a good mechanic can make a great game, even if all the pieces aren't the best. Jumping through the air, like I'm in an Ang Lee film, feels so good! The thud sound you hear when you land feels so realistic. It's worth a purchase just to experience that feeling.

But that's not the only thing Valley does right. There's enough exploration to keep you in wonder and discovery for hours. The game looks realistic, albiet a little too brown at times. This game also lends itself to speedrunning quite well. There's a good blend of skill and luck that keeps the game fresh, even when you backtrack to find that last medallion. 

Another cool thing I'd like to give kudos for is the day/night cycle in this game. Time moves as you move through the various sections. It feel natural, unlike most games day/night where every 10 or 15 minutes it just changes. 

You owe yourself the experience Valley has to offer!

Minor Spoiler:
[spoiler]If you had told me this game was about Wendigos, finding Slender Man posters, and paranormal events, I would not have purchased it. I've always found those games woeful. There's jump scares or lots of walking around in the dark. Valley took the good of those elements and placed them in a setting that worked perfectly IMO[/spoiler]

God, where to begin with this game. Firstly, as some of the other reviews have expressed this isn't so much of a game as it is an experience. This game is meant to be played with a good pair of headphones, in a dark room, on a nice machine, alone. This isn't a game to chat with the boyz in discord while you play. 

The graphics are fantastic, and the in game narrative is not only interesting, but in my opinion extrememly well voice-acted. 
Finding the in game notes lying around only adds to an, ableit short, but fantastic plot line. [spoiler] I think the idea of a separate secret government project going on alongside the Manhattan project is so interesting, and plausible. Definitely not so sci-fi, but all the same [/spoiler] There is much more depth to this game than you would imagine if you stop to look around and explore, which is much more difficult than you think. It's a ingenious formula they've created to make you want to speed through the game, but simulataneously make you feel bad for not stopping to take it all in and explore. It's a feeling I haven't had playing very many games. 

The soundtrack is top notch, although I agree with other reviews that it is disappointing it only plays the first time you enter an area and never plays upon returning. 

This game is a must play in my opinion. I picked it up for 8 bucks on sale and It was 8 dollars well spent. Hell I spent countless amounts of money on my last girlfriend and she still cheated on me after 3 years. Anyway, just buy the game.

32521661.review:
This game is extremely easy. There are no difficult enemies, no puzzles, no difficult maneuvers. The gameplay consists of running through an almost entirely linear path, occasionally clicking on things. 

The story is okay, but there is practically no character development or significant plot twists or anything to make it more interesting than what it is: A few notes and audio recordings which tell you why you're walking down the linear path.

The best part of the game is the level design, which is still lacking. The environments are pretty enough, but again: The path is linear, and there are no puzzles or challenges. And you often find yourself looking for secrets - using your fancy abilities - just to get disappointed that a hard-to-reach object is meaningless, or end up clipping through the floor, or breaking the narrative by skipping ahead in the storyline.

All that said, it's not a bad game. The areas are really pretty, and sometimes quite memorable. But honestly, that's all there is to this game.
If the story was really inspirational, or if the level design had actual gameplay in mind, or if there was some kind of challenge of any kind, this game would be recommendable.
But props to the people who designed the visuals. The sound people have their good moments, too.

32517039.review:
This game...to me, I see it as a work of art. Even with an incredibally short play time, it was easily worth the sale price that I got it for, though I'd even pay full price. While short, it is an extremely well crafted masterpiece. However, keep in mind, this is much more of a subjective review. It is an amazing game to me, but I can see it as having a somewhat niche audience, so it may not be this incredible to you.
Also, please beware, this is an extremely long review. However, it will give you a good idea of if the game is for you. Also, there is a tl;dr pros and cons at the end of the review if you don't feel like reading all of it.

Graphics: 7/10
For the most part, it looks really good. Yeah, it's not amazing, and someparts show that, but it conveys what it means to in a visual appealing way. It looks good enough. A large part here is the landscapes. There were a few times in the game where I would come out of a cave or small passage way, and I would be greated with incredible landscape shots of mountains, forests, rivers, and fields, with some small animals running along. This, combined with the mix of old and new ruins, sometimes creates breathtaking shots that I won't soon forget in video games. 
The graphics could be improved, but they still look good.

Sound: 8/10
The sound in this game...it's just so good. First of all, the sound effects are very well done. They create a good atmosphere that's a mix between natural and artifcial. Sometimes that makes me feel calm, while also slightly nervous. What really shines here though, even through that, is its soundtrack. The soundtrack here is beautiful. One of the best video game soundtracks I've heard. It just creates so much atmosphere. Of course the beautiful main menu piano piece is just amazingly played. But throughout, there's always perfect music for the occasion to create the best situation. When you first start out with the L.E.A.F. suit, and you're running through hills and forests with animals around you, the music has such a feeling of discovery, and almost child-like amazment. In high contrast, crawling through small shafts and abandoned facilities has music that just creates a sense of anticipation and fear. 
All together, very atmospheric music, and great sound design.

Story: 7/10
This is where I feel the game suffers the most. The story isn't bad by any means. However, it is pretty predictable at a lot of points, and the end feels a bit rushed. Also, some of the voice recordings you discover can sometimes feel fake and forced. However, they convey the story in a unique sense. Yes, there's your story, however, the main story is actually in the past. As you move along, you find voice recordings and notes that tell what happened in the ruins a long time ago. Instead of you being the main character, you slowly find notes that tell another person's story as you try to finish what they started. The notes are delivered in small doses, so you don't have to do to much reading at once, and the voice recordings are pretty straight forward, and they're easy to play and listen to at the same time. 
I think the biggest pitfall here is that it wasn't long enough. It was paced well, but it took me about 3 hours to finish the first time. I will be playing through it again, and there were some optional paths and branches that I could have taken but didn't, but overall, it dissapoints me how such an amazing game has such a small play time.
Still, fairly well-written story, if a bit short, and delivered in a unique way.

Movement Mechanics: 9/10
The gameplay mechanics in this game are really what made me go through it so fast. It was just so fun that I had to keep going. They aren't anything too unique, but combined with the location, landscapes, and music, it creates a experience I haven't felt in another game. Basically, you have a suit that allows you run really fast and jump really high, and you gradually find upgrades (like grappling hooks) to help you find different ways through the enviroment. What really makes this amazing though is the momentum mechanic. Basically, if you are running down hill, based on how steep it is and how long you're running, you'll start building up speed. Once you jump, you can end up going hundreds of feet into the air, and allows you to jump much farther. It's just so satisfying to do, and really gorgeous to see at times. Whether you're running through a forest, and flying into the air, greeted with a beatiful landscape beneath you, or sprinting through a mineshaft, suddenly launching into a wide open underground compartment, the feeling of being able to jump so high and run so fast is a feeling I haven't really come across before.

Combat Mechanics: 5/10
The combat in this is game is bad. Now, the reason for this is because it is very sparse, and not at all the point of it. However, if you want deep or fun combat, this is not for it. It generally just consists of running around and shooting something a couple times so it explodes. There isn't even a dedicated weapon. It really is boring, but can add a little bit of challenge and stress to get your blood pumping. However, like I said, it's ok. You don't come across it very often, and it's not at a focus of the game. It's really mainly there just to add some danger.
However, something in here that is somewhat related is the life and death mechanic. Basically, you have the ability to kill things, or keep it alive. This isn't used too often, but it is interesting. Basically, the Valley has "health". If it loses too much, it dies. It can lose health in a couple ways. One way is if you die (I'll talk about that in a minute), but another way is if you steal it's health. Basically, you can use your "weapon" to steal life from trees and plants and use that for energy, which you use to do things like double jump and use your grappling hook. However, you can also use your "weapon" to give life back to the plants, and restore it's health. It really creates an interesting affect of balancing how much energy you need, and needing to keep the Valley alive. This leads into my next point.

Life and Death Mechanics: 8/10
Basically, when you die, you'll immediately respawn almost exactly where you died. No checkpoints, nothing. You just respawn. However, they've added another things that makes death bad, which is pretty unique. I won't go through all of it to not give away spoilers, but, when you die, the Valley loses health. Die enough times, and the Valley dies. Now, I haven't done that, so I'm not sure what would happen. But, this creates an insentive not to die a lot. You can restore the Valley's health, but you have to use your energy, which you don't get back when you die (you have to find sources of energy). So, it's a nice risk, that dying can have potentially permenent affects on your surroundings.

Overall Experience: 9/10
Overall, this game to me is amazing. It has such an immersive atmosphere that I've thoroughly enjoyed playing in. While relying more on platforming and movement than combat, it has a story that, while somewhat predictable, is still easy to get sucked into, and amazing, fun mechanics.

tl;dr

Pros:
-beautiful landscape shots
-amazingly done soundtrack and sound design
-unique storytelling mechanic
-amazingly fun movement and platforming
-interesting life and death system
-a very immersive experience

Cons:
-graphics pretty average
-predictable story
-rushed ending
-bad combat 

Overall, a great, immersive game with fun mechanics and a great soundtrack, but nothing too innovative, and it really appeals to a certain group up people.

32516751.review:
Das Spiel ist eher ein Erkundungsspiel mit Story und Jump'n Run Einlagen und ein wenig (jugendfreiem) anspruchslosem Geballer. 

Macht schon Laune mit dem Exoskelett durch die Pampa zu fetzen und zu hüpfen.
Der Anzug wird nach und nach aufgewertet mit neuen Features und damit kann man später sogar nochmal zu vorherigen Lokationen reisen um noch Extras zu suchen. Und als ich mit Magnetschuhen an Metallbahnen an der Wand entlang gelaufen bin hat das wohlige Erinnerungen an Prey (das alte) hervorgehoben. Sehr schön. 
Die sensible Story mit der Lebensenergie und dem "Lifeseed" ist auch nett und mann möchte immer wissen wie die Story weiter geht. 

Die auftauchenden Gegner sind leider keine echte Herausforderung. Wenn man mal stirbt dann weil man in den Sprungeinlagen mal in den Abgrund oder ins Wasser fällt (Schwimmen ist nicht mit Exoskelett).

Die Mechanik mit der Lebensenergie verspricht leider auch mehr als sie später hält. Enegiemangel hatte ich jedenfalls nie, auch weil die "Energiekugeln§ immer wieder respawnen. Hier hätte man noch etwas an der Balanceschraube drehen können. Es macht zwar Laune ständig tote Bäume neu zu beleben aber das macht man eigentlich nur um diese goldenen Eicheln zu sammeln die man dadurch bekommt und mit denen man dann antike Türen öffnen kann. 
Der Endboss war als einziger Gegner ein wenig anspruchsvoll. Hübsche Angriffsanimationen da übrigens. Aber selbst dort bin ich nicht wirklich in Bedrängnis geraten.
Die üblichen überall herumligenden Notizen welche zur Story beitragen haben mich allerdings schon irgendwann ein klein wenig genervt weil das einen immer wieder aus dem Spielfluss herausreißt. Meinetwegen überall Audiologs verteilen (Die gibt es auch zur Hauptstory) aber ich will hier nicht ständig stehen bleiben um Notizen von irgendwelchen Leuten zu lesen. Das widerspricht völlig der Spielmechanik. Mit dem Exoskelett möchte man sich ständig bewegen. 

Fazit: Leider etwas anspruchslose Shooter-Mechanik und das zunächst vielversprechende Lebensenergie-Management löst sich in Wohlgefallen auf. Aber die Gegend erkunden mit dem Anzug macht Laune und die Geschichte ist nett. 
Also im Sale kann man das allemal kaufen. 
Und nach dem ganzen Games-As-A-Service Kram derzeit und der Open Word Schwemme tut es mal wieder richtig gut ein schönes Singleplayer-Spiel mit absehbarem Ende zu spielen wo man nicht wieder hundert Stunden versenkt.

一款跑酷类游戏，基本上没有什么解谜要素，独特的地方大概就是吸收生命和给予生命的能力，个人和自然紧密相关，倒是给了人很多的思考。
游戏从峡谷开始，寻找lifeseed，直到最后炸毁了战争工厂，流程算是很长的，地图也相当广阔。只是一定要跟着生命能量走，不然自己到处乱跳会耽误很长的时间（毕竟我是一个在峡谷里转了三四圈最后才找到正路的人）。
优点：
1.探索区域很广，适合休闲玩家看风
2.操作比较人性，没有特别为难玩家的地方
3.BGM好听
4.主旨环保反战，主角的死亡会导致周围生命的消亡共存，而给予峡谷生命则会获得金色松子的回馈，有种我与自然共存亡的感觉。并且穿着原本用于战争的套装销毁了战争工厂，也是一种引人深省的设计。
注意：
1.想要过关的话，最好跟着蓝色的生命球走，不然很容易迷路（PS：有蓝光的碎石块墙壁都是可以通过冲击撞破的，最开始摸索了好久，被自己蠢哭）
2.虽然有最低配置，但是还是配置越高越好，不然一半时间都拿来顿卡了，会非常影响游戏体验

32455081.review:
I usually never complete games bar a few and this game was one of those rare occurances where I enjoyed every minute of playtime. The scenery is beyond beautiful, and expectations considering the normal (and reduced) price of the game. Along with this the music really made the game for me, whether it's during exploration around the forests and ruins of the Valley or engaging in combat it really grounds your existance in the game & really brings the scenery and Valley (and what you're doing) alive, I love it.

The audio recordings give you the general gist of the story, along with the ingame writing on the screen, however to really dig deeper into the story of Valley you will have to read the notes and research scattered all over the place, so it may take you a while longer to complete the story (which is really only 3-4 hours long depending on how much you skip). Or a few more playthroughs.

The combat is simple yes but sometimes you will be overwhelmed with enemies so it does enhance the combat to some extent, but I think that this isn't the focus of the game so if you're looking for strong combat then I wouldn't recommend it but it is a nice change from heavy combat mechanics and games which I personally like.

Overall I loved this game more than anything I played, it is short, but there is quite a bit of replayability with the medallions and acorn doors and I just know I've missed loads of content and boxes in the game so I'll definitely be replaying a few times not only for that, but just for the atmospherics of this game. I highly recommend it if you like these sort of games although I haven't come across anything like this yet.

By the end of the game you'll start to want to revive every tree and animal you see, you get attached

購入を考えている方へ注意したいのが、３D酔いである。
私自身、酔うゲームそうでないゲームがあるがこのゲームは前者でした。
本作は楽曲もビジュアルも非常によく、それに加えファストトラベルが付いているためクリア後もぶらついて楽しみたかったのだが、それが叶いそうになくて非常に残念である。ただただ己の三半規管をのろうばかりだ。

ゲームとしては高速で坂道を駆け下りて大ジャンプをしたり、その辺に生息している動植物の息の根を止めたり命を吹き込んだりする、序盤だけを本間丈太郎が見たらデベロッパーに説教しかねないおこがましいグローブを駆使してチャプターをクリアしていくという流れである。
日本語はないが、ゲーム進行には特に関係がないし、がっつりテキストを読もうと思わなければ概ね問題はない。
点在する音声記録から何が起こったかは大体想像できるだろう。

一つ極々個人的な不満点を上げるのならば夜と地下描写が長いことか。
夜も幻想的な景色が見られるので悪くはないのだがやはり明るい描写がもっとほしかった。

32419451.review:
In short, this review's general premise is to get the game. You might notice my strikingly minimal hours put into the game, but disregard that because this game is short. It takes roughly no more than 2-3 hours to complete the game, and the 100% completion status isn't appealing to a general gamer such as myself. But, that's not this games highlight. Instead, this game focuses on areas of a game that some big triple a video games fail to develop: the experience. 

This game has no multiplayer or co-op because it doesn't need one. It's game mechanics are one of the game's main highlights as you get to jump around and sprint all over a breathtakingly beautiful landscape. That's another thing this unity game is beauitiful. its level design is, while a little too linear and too hand-holding at times, it is still entertaining and enjoyable to go through. Could this game be more popular, than it could potentionally be a pretty fun game to speed run. The player progression is satisfying at best, and the difficulty of the game is negligible. Like I said, the game hand-holds the player sometimes. 

What I remember most fondly about this game, however, is OST. The way this game blends in a beautiful landscape or a fast paced area exploration to test out a new suit mechanic with the music is nothing short of perfect. It creates, as i mentioned before, an experience. It's one that can't be replicated the way this game handles it.

I would highly reccomend this game to anybody with a few dollars to spend even if a game like this isn't exactly what you're used to.

32412073.review:
This is a nice game - it is for 99% of the time very chilled out - but what is it?
well its a parkour sort of game. Exploration is the main gameplay in the game and this is achieved through your char having access to a suit that allows him to perform superhuman jumps and speeds etc - the suit upgrades as you go along and none of the new abilities you gain is overused to the point where you get sick of it. Its a nice game to look at as well with great scenery - my only gripe with the graphics is that at times when you are stood still you can ascertain a kind of jerkiness in the animation of some tree branches but its very minor. The levels are quite big and credit to the design team the attention to detail when bulkhead doors etc open is really good giving the impression that a huge door is being opened. I completed the game in a little over 8 hours because i stopped a lot to see the sights and there are some very impressive vistas and herein lies my second complaint about this game - it has no photo mode - I really do feel like the devs could have really given a photomode or at least the ability to remove the HuD to take nice screenshots. However i brought this game for £5 and it was a very good purchase - I managed to clock 73% of the achis on my first run through the game and its actually a game i would like to play a second time just to make sure i didnt miss any other nice sights.
Overall a very nice exploration game with a hint of parkour and the odd enemy now and again to shoot at. Oh and the music is actually rather pleasent and works well with the game.

32402491.review:
This game captured me right from the very beginning. From the very moment you put on the L.E.A.F suit and the music kicks off, you feel like you are on a huge adventure. Much of the game has a bright theme to it as you see woodland creatures going about their business and huge areas of lush foliage. The real story lies underneath all that, given to you both with audio recordings and notes. The notes can be hard to spot and are sometimes out of the way as many of them are in hidden crates but it does help breath life into the world if you track some down. The searching for crates does bring you out of the action sometimes and I wish that instead of being scattered here and there, that they had specific challenges to get to a large cache that you would have to go back to after getting the correct upgrades for the suit. My favorite part by far was the first time encountering the rails. The music, insane speed, huge jumps, and lightning effects made for an epic run.

I made it through the story in roughly 3 hours of play time but I know I'll be hopping back in for more high speed fun.

9/10

32401900.review:
It only took a few minutes of playing this game to fall in love with it. Running around in the LEAF suit surrounded by beautiful hues of blue and green is actually a lot more fulfilling than it sounds. The music is bright and cheery and really helps you immerse yourself into this world. The narration isn't annoying at all and I found myself bonding with the story even though most of the characterization was done through reading. Still, if that isn't your style of game, you still get a decent amount of story just by running around the world and following the plot-line. The replay value is limited unless you're looking for 100% completion - but you'd be playing this game for a very long time to achieve that, and the novelty of the LEAF suit and the abilities it grants will wear off after the few hours it takes you to complete the game.

PROS:
-Good music
-Beautiful atmosphere
-Interesting story
-Very relaxing

CONS:
-Running around looking for boxes doesn't fit in a game where fluidity of movement is the primary feature
-Absurdly easy (don't have to look for upgrades if you don't want to)

32399282.review:
An interesting blend of several genres, producing a well paced and enjoyable adventure.

The gameplay is part fps, part first person platformer (reminds me a bit of Mirror's Edge), and part walking simulator (akin to SOMA or Dear Esther). The movement mechanics are a blast and feel great when momentum is maintained.
The game also features a very interesting death mechanic that quite well ties into the game's world and story. Unfortunately, it doesn't quite have time to shine due to the relative ease of the game and the plentiful energy pickups.

The story pans out as a sort of mystery/adventure-tale where the main drive is figuring out what is going on. It is definitely intrieguing and works well as motivation for driving forward.

Artistically, the game is top notch, both visually and audibly. Special mentions go to the amazing soundtrack.

Clocking in at around five hours, Valley is a great way to spend an evening.

I highly recommend checking it out.

P.S. Works well on mesa open source drivers, which is always a plus.

31862172.review:
I figured I would give Valley a go because it looked like an interesting game. I will say if you're the kind of gamer who likes to do a lot of grinding and work between two remote locations seperated by a lot of landscape than this is your type of game. I will say that it lacks a lot of real content to warrent such large and spacious landscapes and underground railways to begin with. It feels almost incomplete. However I tend to think of that more as a drive to see what else there is out there to explore. Most of the game is optional. You have no real incentive to pickup acorns unless you plan on L.E.A.F upgrades (they're not required to complete the game) and the medallions as well.

I've never seen a game where your health is effectively the health of the very island you're on. Your ability to traverse that island requires life from the island itself. Taking life from the island is how things around you die. Like tree and animals. Take too much and game over. Everytime you intentionally die the island helps you out. The game is very much about life balance. Keeping yourself and the island alive. However every action you take, in addition to defending yourself from enemies takes health.

About those enemies. The game has no real variety of them, there is effectively three of them. One of which you can ignore since it's the final boss fight. The primary enemy you'll first encounter is a swarm of what appears to be fire flies which shoot what I can only assume is "negative" energy which then takes from your health. The way to attack these is to overpower them with your energy thus isolating them around a sphere of your own energy. If you're not following this game's concept of health and energy are the same thing. The second enemy is exactly the same except they're ghost-like monsters which move a lot quicker and a lot more randomly. The combat system in the game is pretty underdeveloped and could use a bit more work.

The game is very linear, perhaps too linear - forcing you down corridors and heating vents, train tracks you name it. However when you're not bombarded in all those tight spaces you're out in the open with absolutely no restrictions on where you can go. The game gives you a wide variety of mechanices for traversing this island. Perhaps too many mechanics?

The first mechanic you learn is effectively how to give and take energy/health/life (again all the same thing here). The second mechanic is the jump. This game loves jumping, to the point where you eventually gain a double-jumping mechanic. The island you're on has very low gravity allowing you to leap incredible distances, especially when you build up momentum. The two most important mechanics to the game however are more interesting. Walking on walls, which is used only rarely in the game and the grappling hook. This game has a lot of vertical open places where the use of the grappling hook is requireds and boy is it absolutely fun. Did I mention that once you get going you can reach incredible movement speeds the likes of which destroy games like Tribes?

If I were to give it a rating I would say a 7/10. There is definitely something here, it needs to be fleshed out a little further with more set pieces and mini missions. More variety of weapons and a better combat system and it would probably be a massive hit.

There is one other thing I forgot to mention and it really deserves it's own section in here. The soundtrack is absolutely one of the best I've ever heard in any form of digital enterainment / medium bar none. The game makes incredible use of 3D sound, ambient sounds, exceptional music, played at the right time, very organic and very well done. The music alone is 10/10.

31809916.review:
There's a particular style of play that I'm not sure you can even wrap a genre around, which is annoying since it's one of my favorites. It's games where the joy of movement is a central feature. A lot of parkour games capture this, though I'd say every genre has a few examples.

Valley captures this feeling so well that some of the other stuff it does almost feels superfluous. The running and jumping feels great on its own, and many set pieces are built around that. The sound and the music combine with this to make some sections downright exhilirating.

But it shoots itself in the foot a bit with the other items it adds on, stuff that seems geared to make it more marketable. Having enemies you have to shoot was mediocre, but making your ammo come out of the same pool as your other abilities made a few parts frustrating. And having to hunt for upgrades involves the sort of environment scouring that didn't feel proper in a game built around speed and jumping.

Also, and this goes out to all gamemakers, this is not elementary school, quit trying to pass me notes. Reading huge chunks of text while I'm trying to play a video game is a sloppy way to stuff more lore and background into your product. The voice recordings were fine, but when I want to read long text-based stories, I'll find a game that's properly built around that. A game like this should define its story through the environment and the players actions.

But otherwise it was a fun game that never overused any of its play mechanics, and had the decency to end before it wore out its welcome.

Then I discovered that this game had combat, really basic and mediocre combat. I am not against combat in games since the vast majority of my gametime is in combat games but I thought that it was a wholly unnecessary addition to this game that was neither challenging nor fun. I went with it since the movement and the views in this game are very good. 

So then I was playing around for a while, discovering new areas and having a good time when I discovered the pathetic piece of shit excuse for a grapple gun (called Viper Coil in this game) that makes you jump around like a spiderman. That utterly idiotic contraption ruins this game given that on a number of occasions it will send you to your death. That would have been okay if this game didn't come with a limited number of respawns. Run out of respawns? Well, restart from a chapter start! No thanks and congratulations on ruining what could have been a good game.

On another note, if you are an achievement hunter, [b]DO NOT[/b] under any circumstances buy this game, not on a 50% off sale, not on a 75% off sale, not for any amount of money. There is an achievement in the game for completing it without dying that I am sure will be a great deal of [i]fun[/i] given the aforementioned piece of festering shit that is the Viper Coil.

31782267.review: Really great game, loved the soundtrack.

31780334.review:
Valley is an outstanding game. Along with its beautiful graphics, this game creates an original and emotion-capturing story line. To top it off, it plays astonishing tracks that are to die for. From pianos pieces to cello solos, the soundtrack is probably one of the best parts of the game itself.

I would recommend this game to anyone who loves a fun, free-roam game that comes with small challenges. It is, by far, my favorite game of all time. Though it is a small game, to find most of the secrets it takes about 6 hours, it's fun to go back and rediscover the wonderful world this game can immerse you in.

31755171.review:
Опишу коротко:

Очень годный платформер от первого лица. Очень неплохой сюжет и очень неплохая графика как для инди проекта.


Сразу оценки с пояснениями:
Сюжет - 8/10. Да, можно было сделать сложнее и длиннее, но это все-таки инди а не ААА. 
Графика - 8/10. Да, Unity далеко до UE4 по возможностям, но игра ВПОЛНЕ на уровне. Долина простоо шикарна.
Саундтрек - 100/10. Пройдите эту игру хотя бы чтобы послушать божественную музыку, идеально подходящую под ландшафт.
Игра в целом - 8/10. Паркур шикарен. Боевая система средняя (либо вы игнорируете врага, литбо убиваете его с определенного количества тычек). Идея забрать/подарить жизнь изначально очень интересна, однако реализовано слабо, можно было по жестче привязать это к развязкам головоломок, а не только к воскрешению персонажа. Но игру один раз пройти однозначно стоит. Плюс можно позадротить в speedrun прохождении.

游戏过程整体以探索为主，大自然的景色很美，地图很大。

恢复生命方法：复活枯木和死去的动物。

游戏的隐藏门有两种，各自需要一定数量的果实和奖章才能打开，隐藏门后面的宝箱可以给装备升级，比如能量扩容、二段跳飞链不用消耗能量等等。

收集果实方法：满生命值时，用能量把周围的枯木复活，这些树重新开叶成长后，会结出很多果实；打死敌人也有几率掉果实出来，不过很少。

收集奖章貌似只能从箱子里拿，平时注意探索地图，后期祭坛两个大门总共需要70个奖章才能打开。

最后建议游戏打折时候买。

31595569.review:
I'll give Valley a solid 7/10... but I's really difficult to rate.
 - What's Awesome?  
The concept, the art, the music, the level design.   The Physics!  Somehow they've managed to code a nearly physical sense of satisfaction into the running, jumping, swinging, bouncing, and skipping.  
 - What's Not so awesome?
It's almost painful in that for all that the game is... It could have been SO MUCH MORE!  The story setup hinted at an epic confrontation of primal forces.  Life and death!  Greed, love, creation and destruction!  A fall, and the hope of redemption, or the temptation to repeat the mistakes of the past.  A twist of fate and a reversal of understanding.  The monsters may be the victims.  New goals!  Undoing the damage done in ignorance!  A final temptation weighed against noble sacrifice.  Maybe someone gets murdered by pirates.  But no... That story happened here, but that was seventy years ago.  You missed it.  You just get to explore the disused scenery from that story.
But I still recommended Valley for all that it is.  I got my money's worth in fun.  Maybe if we ask sweetly, Blue Isle will call this release a "game play demo" and create the thundering epic that this game should have been.

31471675.review:
[H1]Valley, een running simulator met een beetje actie en een interessant verhaal[/H1]
[b]Inleiding[/b]
Valley is het tweede spel van de kleine ontwikkelaar Blue Isle Studios uit Toronto Canada. Hun eerste spel was Slender Man: The Arrival, dat ik - ondanks de hoge score op Steam - niet zou aanraden. Valley was daarom een onverwachte verassing. Het spel doet een beetje denken aan een kruising tussen Shadow Complex, Singularity en Dying Light. Je bent een archeoloog of archeologe die op zoek naar de mytische 'Lifeseed' met planeetverwoestende krachten met zijn of haar kano wordt meegesleurd door een rivier en uiteindelijk in een verborgen vallei in de Rocky Mountains terecht komt (vandaar de titel van het spel Valley). 

[b]Het verhaal[/b]
In de vallei vind je de restanten van installaties waar de geallieerden gedurende de Tweede Wereldoorlog onderzoek hebben gedaan naar een geheimzinnige energiebron die alleen in deze vallei gevonden wordt en die verbonden is met de Lifeseed waar je naar op zoek bent. Deze energie is enerzijds gebruikt voor de ontwikkeling van de L.E.A.F. suit, een exoskelet waarmee snel kunt rennen en  hoge sprongen kunt maken. En anderzijds voor de ontwikkeling van een bom die de atoombom van Oppenheimer naar de kroon moet steken. Het exoskelet is uitgevoerd met een apparaat dat de God Hand wordt genoemd en waarmee je leven kunt nemen en geven (vergelijkbaar met de Time Manipulation Device uit Singularity waarmee je dingen kon verouderen of verjongen). De enige tegenstanders die je tegenkomt zijn zwermen vuurvliegjes en natuurgeesten die agressief zijn door een gebrek aan de energie die door de installaties aan de valei wordt onttrokken. Je kunt ze uitschakelen door ze met je God Hand te beschieten, maar dat is alle actie die je in dit spel zult vinden. De rest van je tijd ben je vooral bezig met rondrennen, springen, glijden, klauteren en slingeren op zoek naar een manier om de vallei te redden. Het verhaal achter deze installaties en de reden waarom ze verlaten zijn, wordt beetje bij beetje door middel van briefjes en bandopnames onthuld. Erg cliche, maar de briefjes en opnames zijn kort en goed geschreven en geven vanuit verschillende standpunten weer wat er gebeurd is en hoe verschillende mensen de gebeurtenissen hebben ervaren. Het spel houdt je aandacht verder vast door je beetje bij beetje nieuwe uitbreidingen voor je L.E.A.F. suit te geven. Eerst een boost, waardoor je een dubbele sprong kunt maken, daarna een ketting waarmee je aan specifieke blokken kunt slingeren, magneetlaarzen waarmee je tegen bepaalde wanden kunt lopen en nog meer. 

[b]De lengte van het spel[/b]
Als je de verhaallijn volgt en braaf de opdrachten die je krijgt opvolgt, kun je het spel in een uur of drie uitspelen. Als je het spel voor de eerste keer speelt, zou ik je die strategie aanbevelen. Vervolgens kun je alle levels opnieuw spelen en op zoek gaan naar verschillende voorwerpen die in de levels zijn verstopt. In de verschillende levels zijn kisten met briefjes, eikels en medaillons te vinden. De eikels kun je gebruiken om poorten te openen en de medaillons openen een pyramide waarin je twee verbeteringen vindt die het ontdekken van de levels nog makkelijker maken. 
Het is niet eenvoudig om alle kisten te vinden, omdat de verschillende gebieden waar je doorheen trekt groot zijn. Hieraan zie je ook de aandacht die de ontwikkelaars hebben gestopt in dit spel. Waar je in veel spellen voortdurend tegen onzichtbare muren oploopt, moet je hier enorm je best doen voordat dat gebeurt. Het spel is verdeeld in negen van deze grote gebieden die zich afwisselend bovengronds en in ondergrondse installaties plaatsvinden. Omdat je voortdurend nieuwe manieren krijgt om je voort te bewegen, kun je ook steeds moeilijk bereikbare gebieden bereiken, ook in de gebieden die je al bezocht hebt.

[b]De kwaliteit van het spel[/b]
Een van de grote nadelen van spellen van kleine ontwikkelaars is vaak dat er veel bugs en glitches in het spel zitten, dat het spel niet goed in elkaar steekt (gauw eentonig wordt of onverwachts eindigt), dat de besturing slecht is of dat de User Interface onduidelijk is. Maar dat is hier niet het geval, hoewel je soms wel merkt dat het spel door een klein team is gemaakt, voelt het spel over het algemeen net zo solide aan als de eerder genoemde spellen van gevestigde ontwikkelaars. 
Waar ik ook nog een compliment voor wil geven is de kwaliteit van de achtergrondmuziek. Deze varieert van rustgevende Ierse/keltische deuntjes in de zonovergoten bossen tot dreigende muziek tijdens de ondergrondse gebieden. De aandacht die in veel onderdelen van het spel is gestoken, is ook hier merkbaar. Soms verandert de muziek van vrolijk naar opgewekt, naar dreigend afhankelijk van het gebied waar je bent. 
Ook op andere vlakken merk je dat de ontwikkelaars zorg hebben besteed aan het spel. Het rondrennen voelt heel natuurlijk aan en het gevoel van snelheid is indrukwekkend. Het camerastandpunt is bewust laag aan de grond, waardoor je soms het gevoel hebt een dwerg te zijn in plaats van een reus. Volgens een van de ontwikkelaars is dit bewust gedaan, omdat het anders te moeilijk was om sprongen goed in te schatten. Daarnaast verhoogt het ook het gevoel van snelheid. Ik kon me er persoonlijk niet aan ergeren, maar het viel me - net als andere spelers - wel af en toe op.
Vind je het leuk om de verschillende gebieden uit te kammen op zoek naar alle kisten en het behalen van de achievements dan ben je al gauw zo'n 10 tot 15 uur zoet met het spel.

[b]Conclusie[/b]
Sommige reviews en opmerkingen in het forum zijn ronduit negatief over het spel. Daar ben ik het, zoals je hebt kunnen lezen, niet mee eens. De oorzaak is denk ik dat het spel zich moeilijk laat classificeren. Het heeft veel elementen van een walking simulator zoals Dear Esther of Gone Home of The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, maar de L.E.A.F. suit maakt er veel meer een platformachtig spel van zoals The Story of My Uncle of Mirror's Edge. Als je echter een aantal verbeteringen hebt gevonden voor de L.E.A.F. suit en je wat meer ervaring hebt met het rondrennen en springen dan worden deze platformachtige elementen zo makkelijk dat je het moeilijk een platformer kunt noemen. Een echt actiespel is het ook niet, daarvoor zijn er te weinig verschillende tegenstanders die bovendien niet al te veel tegenstand bieden. Dat maakt het moeilijk om Valley te vergelijken met andere spellen, want hoewel het veel elementen van andere spellen in zich heeft, is het nergens mee te vergelijken. De Steam score geeft in dit geval een betere beoordeling, want op een schaal van 1 tot 10, zou ik het een ruime 7 geven. Sommige elementen hadden beter gekund, het spel had groter en uitdagender kunnen zijn. Maar voor een kleine studio als Blue Isle is dit een goede prestatie. Het feit dat er een drietal updates zijn gedaan waarmee een groot aantal problemen die zijn gerapporteerd door spelers zijn weggenomen, geeft bovendien aan dat Blue Isle zijn klanten serieus neemt. Het is geen spel dat iedere speler zal aanspreken, daarvoor is de actie en de uitdaging te beperkt, maar zeker voor veel 'casual' spelers is dit spel een aanrader.

31246571.review:
Upon opening this game and jumping into the first level I was instantly captivated by the beauty of the game and the sheer awesomeness of the landscape and surroundings and the outstanding soundtrack. I enjoyed every moment of the game even whilst 100% with achievements and collectables. The story was interesting enough to maintain my attention and keep me immersed in the world of valley there are also a fair few extra skills and movement abilities unlocked throughout playing which keeps the play style fresh and prevents the game from getting boring, but the main factor of me playing and 100% the game was its awesome landscape and views.

PROS
-Beautiful Landscapes and scenery
-Amazing soundtrack
-New movement abilities every level or so to keep gameplay fresh and exciting
-Non challenging enemies (as its not a large feature of this game)
-Decent story
-Replayability if you appreciate scenery and the game mechanics

CONS
-Short game (3 and half hours of gameplay or so, 5-8 if you are collecting all upgrades and medallions) -Not necessarily a bad thing
-Not much replayability if you don't like linear story driven games
-If you combat is a big feature for you this game will disappoint you

The reason I am listing the pros and cons like this are as followed, combat can be an important part of a game for some people but this game is more about exploration and movement ability, as of which the enemies are very easy to deal with and are not very threatening, which makes this the perfect game to relax with and have a good chilled time. The length of the game is listed under cons simply as the longer the game the more worth you get for your money, of course I would love this game to be longer but at the same time I feel that this could end up dragging out the plot too much and ultimately spoiling a great game so I don't think its a big deal and I am happy with the game length and of course with a longer game length you would end up having styles of levels that are repeated and would end up being boring and tacky. 

As this game is a linear story game it would be great to one day have some additional content for this game, maybe an extra level or something but its not needed for this game to be replayed, I shall probably revisit this game every few months to replay it on a fresh save. 

SUMMARY
Overall I think Valley is a beautiful game with outstanding visuals and soundtrack, the story and atmosphere of the game shall leave you fully immersed, the gameplay is fun and exciting as well as leisurely and calm. The game is a little short but that fits the story well. I look forward to the next Blue Isle Studio game.

- The graphics in this game is one of the best I've ever seen
- The voice acting is decent (all from recordings)
- Decent replay value
- Lengthy game play
- Various areas to explore
- Plot twist
- Easter Eggs

Cons:
- Animals and enemies stand still when far away
- The player can get stuck
- No character development
- You can't save progress until the end of the chapter

Some of the areas, most of them in the beginning, are extremely beautiful.  I was very impressed by how the sun shown through the trees, how the sun glistened off of the waterfalls, and how the wild life moved and looked (very lifelike).  The entire game has some of the best graphics I've ever seen, along with an ending that I didn't see coming.  I took my time with this game and it I played it for about 18 hours before getting to the end, then another 6 or 7 hours trying to obtain all of the achievements.  When you finish the game, you can travel to any of the chapters to try for an achievement.  Best of all, you keep all of your upgrades and abilities as well.

If you want to fly through this game, you can finish in about 2 or 3 hours but where is the fun in that?

Only a couple of things about Valley really bothered me.  First, the wildlife and enemies are visible far into the distance and they stand there as if they're waiting for their cue.  Once you're close enough, then they go into action.  Once you realize this, enemies become very easy targets, but not of them are visible so you still want to stay vigilant.  Second, there are several places where the player can get stuck forcing you so start the chapter over.  Since there is no save system, be very mindful where you jump (The game automatically saves when you complete a chapter).

On a side note, when the player obtains an upgrade, I thought it was very reminiscent of Bioshock.  A video would play telling you what the upgrade was and how to use it... in that same old style informational video format from the 50's (or the 40's in the case of Valley).  I found it amusing.

At the time of this review, Valley was selling for $19.99.  I wouldn't wait for a sale, try it now.

31184319.review:
Valley is beautiful, fun to play, and the story is intriguing. However, as other reviewers have stated before, the game feels unfinished. It just feels... empty. 

There are only two kinds of enemies you face: swarms and wendigos. Even the single "boss" falls into one of those categories. I rarely took damage from enemies - water was the most dangerous part of my Valley experience, killing me maybe 5 times through the whole game (never was killed by a monster, including the boss). Aside from that, there are only two kinds of non-combatant creatures you will come across: deer (I counted 3) and the little green sprites. 

There are a lot of ledges to jump on, and once your LEAF suit has some upgrades, it becomes very easy to access areas you shouldn't be able to get to. I clipped through map elements many, many times. The endgame experience where you have to go hunt down medallions and other upgrades you missed is boring. The areas are vast, and an indicator to point you in a general direction would be appreciated. Otherwise aimless hunting and running around just isn't fun.

It's a beautiful game. I got it at $8, and I don't regret my purchase. But the full retail price of $20 is exorbitant for this game. It actually reminded me a bit of Rage or Syndicate - games that had a really nice atmosphere but just fell short in the overall experience due to a lack of filling the created world with engaging experiences.

31170091.review:
First a word of warning on the save system: it's weak.  VERY weak.  While it saves what you've found and upgraded constantly, it does not save your position at all.  When you see the game's load screen pop up, check the clock.  If you don't have at least an hour left in your game session, stop playing!  Because however far you get, you're going to be sent back to the start of the zone when you come back with all the opposition restored.  You'll know where to go and where the opposition is hiding so it won't take even half as long to get back where you were but it's still pretty frustrating.  If you can't play an hour at a time, consider this review a down vote.

For the most part, this game is really a joy to play.  It's a simple game, both in difficulty and mechanics.  You get some simple tasks to do in a pretty environment with some relaxing music playing.  There's some areas to explore, too, with objects hidden out of the way.  There are some enemies to fight but, if you have any first person shooter experience at all, you'll laugh all but the final boss off.

There are some blemishes, too, though.  The save system is easily the biggest for me.  The story is a bit contrived, especially near the start (it isn't easy to come up with a reason for you to be stomping around in a forgotten valley ;).  If you're into screenshots then you'll find it difficult to toggle the HUD on and off (you'll need to use the console).  Finally, while I understand that the L.E.A.F. suit isn't made for swimming, the way the game kills you for landing in water that would barely cover the thing's feet is a bit rediculous.

None of those are really terrible assuming you've got game sessions long enough to deal with the save situation or don't mind going back over some territory.  I did a decent amount of exploring though nowhere near finding everything and the game took me about 10 hours.  Great for a rainy weekend.

Ce jeu en vue subjective vaut surtout le détour pour son univers soigné sur fond de mythologie précolombienne (arbre de vie, énergie spirituelle etc...) que pour son gameplay assez bien fichu mais à la difficulté inexistante.
La combinaison spéciale permettant d'évoluer est overkill par rapport aux pauvres ennemis quasiment inofensifs, le plus grand danger est de tomber dans l'eau. Après cette combi donne un coté grisant aux déplacements (course rapide, saut démentiel, grappin etc...)
L'aspect steampunk 2e Guerre Mondiale est réussi, le truc des expériences militaires qui tournent mal est déjà vu ailleurs mais c'est bien amené.
Bref à petit prix je suis satisfait de l'expérience proposée d'autant que le jeu est plutôt beau, maniable et sans bug notable.
En résumé voilà une production indé "série B" tout à fait honnête mais bien trop facile.

[h1][b]Its like Firewatch but with more interactivity with the world.[/b][/h1]
[b]Technical[/b]
1. The game runs quite smoothly at unloacked fps.As far as I know the game is greatly optimized and has beautiful graphics.
2. There is some weird mouse acceleration/delay input,but its not a action shooter so its not a really big deal.(I suggest using a controller)
3. Game looks stunningly beautiful, There are some texture issues (eg. low resolution textures on some objects even at high settings. which sometimes pulls you out of the immersion,)but it would be nitpicking as many might not observe or care about it.
4. Thechnically the game runs great & looks beatuiful.

[b]Gameplay/story[/b]
1. As mentioned game is more like Firewatch but with more interactivity with the world.
2. The story unveils through audio logs and pieces of papers/notes scattered across the game.Voice acting is great. The story is not supergreat or something like that, its predictable,yet highly enjoyable.
3.The game presents itself beautifully with rich atmosphere which includes great soundtrack,great visuals, decent story & great voice acting.
4.The game is somewhere around 3-4 hours long.(Just a basic run, exluding hunt for achivement and all that)
5.There are certain mechanics which are introduced in the game which are not fully utilized.They are introduced at the very end and hence not utilized fully.
6. There is one boss in game and he is just too easy to kill.

[b]conclusion[/b]
1. Game looks beatiful, it has decent story to tell, graphics look stunning,voice acting is great & it runs great(No     crashes,no fps drops etc.)
2. Game feels short. The story is nothing new and is predictable,many of the mechanics are underused,boss battle is a joke.
3. I personally enjoyed it and would recommend it.

This is a very enjoyable game. It's not long, maybe 6 hours, but you can extend that time quite a bit if you're intent on getting all the collectables. The music is lovely, the environments are pretty, the movement is very fun, and the story, while nothing groundbreaking, is enough to keep you curious. If you like platforming, this seems like a good game to play around in and explore, but if you hate it (like me) the major platforming sections are not so hard or mandatory that you'll get too frustrated. 

I don't know that I'd pay a full $20 for this game, but on sale, I 100% recommend it. It's a great game to play if you just want to explore some lovely environments, run around in a mech suit, and have some fairly casual (and somewhat infrequent) battles.

31119640.review:
一款优秀的电影式游戏。

从一次新的游戏开始到通关，如果不刻意的去探索，流程长度约3小时左右。

一本道的设计，没有分支没有选项，地图比较开阔，每一个关卡都有不少内容可以自由探索，但差不多就是入口出口都只有一个这样的。全程基本没有难点，在流程中就可以很快的熟悉操作，也不会有可以刁难玩家的设计，会卡关的情况，大概也就只有类似于（我这样的）路痴来回走了三圈才发现自己一直在走同一个地方的迷路状况。


游戏性优良，尤其体现在操作手感上。本游戏给我印象最深的，是速度感特别强，奔跑的感觉特别棒。利用惯性的加速、跳跃，还有钩爪、贴壁行走、水面奔跑、轨道加速等多种移动方式。建议将FOV拉到最高来游戏。

叙事方式及配乐是这款游戏的精髓。从开头一段录音的缓慢叙述来导入故事，整体节奏拿捏恰当，一开始舒缓的森林场景，走向山顶的过程中对于探险的雀跃，到进入工厂探索开始逐渐让人紧张，最后的一路狂奔，全过程中每个场景的配乐都恰到好处，成功的塑造了各个环节的氛围。不过这种风格更类似于电影的配乐有一点美中不足的就是，如果迷路了或者是想探索而在一个场景停留太久的话，音乐结束后就不会再播放，只有些环境效果音，就显得有些单调、孤寂。

游戏的故事背景大概是对于冷战时期黄金年代的幻想，类似于生化奇兵和辐射系列那样的，又涉及到远古泰坦与恶魔什么的，给人许多的遐想空间。故事本身却没怎么展开，就是叙述了主角的冒险旅程。主题是……反战与环保？

总体体验来说，游戏完成度很高，没有遇到过任何BUG困扰，游戏节奏把握很棒，3小时的流程没有一分钟的垃圾体验时间。是款很适合挑一个空闲下午，仿佛看电影般的一口气玩完的游戏。就算只是看看风景也值这个价格了。

31105027.review:
So long as you obey one rule, you will enjoy this game.  That one rule is:  Do NOT hunt for collectables and power-ups.  If you focus on the visuals, the music, and the story, you'll find this to be a delightful game.

Valley is a little more interactive than a walking simulator, but not by much- you can die, you can interact with a few things firing 'amrita' (energy), and there are occasional enemies.  But at its core, the game is about traveling through a landscape and discovering a story.  It's interactive enough that you won't get bored, while still being a relaxing game to play.  If you enjoy the genre, you will enjoy this game.

Pros:
-  Stunning scenery, and music to match it
-  Smooth controls
-  Short but compelling story
-  Is exactly as long as it needs to be (unless you go after collectables)

Cons:
-  A few small collectables in a vasy world, many of which are inaccessable on the first playthrough
-  Full price is a bit steep; wait for a sale.  Pay what you think three quality hours of gaming is worth.

31090720.review:
Somehow the store page managed not to communicate that there is, in fact, a story here. And it's amazing.This is the mechanics of Portal meets the feel of Bioshock with some myth thrown in. The actual story is told through a smattering of short audio cips and a slew of short notes you find. Every answer you get begs one more question.

Pros:
BEAUTIFUL soundtrack and graphics
Excellent pacing, exposition is never an info dump
Simple but effective mechanics, also tied into the story in meaningful ways
SUPER FAST FUN RUN TRACKS
Ruins to explore!!
Masterful use of mood (uplifting when it wants to be uplifting, creepy when it wants to be creepy, sad, etc.
"Fighting" "monsters" doesn't feel hack-n-slash (it's a story thing again)

Cons:
Not really.

If you want an action-y game, or a platformer, and ONLY that, give this a pass. This game has an incredible, neat, concise story to tell, and focuses on that more than monsters. If you love myth or just a really well-told story, you will not regret this. Again, that's not to say that the actual game mechanics aren't good-they are excellent. But that's only one part of this game.

31087192.review:
A cross between Dear Esther and Sonic the Hedgehog, i.e. a running simulator. Great if you love exploring places but are a bit ADHD.

Graphics are generally beautiful but some of the textures are a bit low which makes it look a bit PS3 at times. Soundtrack is amazing, some really beautiful atmospheric, emotional, uplifting music which was composed for the game.

I'm running it on a GTX 980 ti and get around 60 fps maxed out. If I take the anti aliasing down a notch I get 80+ fps which is a VERY noticeable improvement on a high refresh rate G-Sync monitor. When you jump and twirl it's sooo smooth. The game isn't demanding on the CPU.

I'm only about an hour into the game and it's a very pleasant, relaxed, chilled experience, great for unwinding. If you liked it get ABZU, it's the underwater version of this.

31070803.review:
[b]Valley[/b] is a first-person sci-fi adventure, which ended up being much more than the expected walking/running/parkour simulator. The spectacular backdrops and well designed areas provide a relaxed environment to explore, while the story unravels in the form of audio messages and notes/recordings scattered around the world.

You assume the role of an archaeologist which has stumbled upon the ruins of a long forgotten expedition. By utilising a secret suit discovered within the ruins, called L.E.A.F. (Leap Effortlessly through Air Functionality), you start to put together not only the story around the expedition but also the ancient inhabitants that lived within the mysterious valley and their origins.

"Relaxed" is the key word in [b]Valley[/b], as there is no real pressure of pressing forward at breakneck speed or challenging enemies to fight but rather an open world with linear progression, which is completely up-to you if you want to zoom through it or take the time to appreciate and explore it (the travel option can be used at any time to return to any reached areas for further exploring).

[b]Valley[/b] takes around 6-8hrs to complete (~12hrs with all achievements) and has a reasonable price (a steal at it's current £6 discounted tag). Recommended to anyone that has enjoyed similar titles like the Solus Project or Story about my Uncle.

31068700.review: Stunning graphics. Very fun gameplay, you wont get bored. Intresting story aswell. 10/10

30986434.review: Despite the negative comments by a number of 'official' reviewers, I enjoyed every minute of 'Valley'play. First, the story was well thought out and developed (dear reviewers, did you take time to read all the notes?) Second, the fall of momentum while running, jumping or sliding at high speed is not in the least disturbing, as it gives you the opportunity to explore the sometimes stunningly beautiful surroundings. Also, it takes certain skills to avoid obstacles as you speed up while after a stop it is quite easy to be on the move again in no time. Third, as you progress, you obtain a variety of technical means to race and jump about, while at the same time the environment becomes more challenging and game play remains easy. Fourth, the game keeps up the pace, makes you respect the storyline and leads on to a predictable yet nice and logical climax. True, combat could have been more varied and sometimes also more challenging, but then again, this is not a first/third person shooter, it is an action/adventure game and a good one too! I guess less enthousiastic reviewers just expected a different kind of game.

30702765.review:
This short and sweet story exploration game is beautiful and surprisingly emotional. The soundtrack is lovely, the environments are a pleasure to look at, and the main game mechanic - Running And Jumping Real Good - is super fun.

The story is mostly conveyed through notes and audio logs (that don't get interrupted or talked over by other dialogue! as there are no NPCs to worry about) and many of the notes are just background noise to the story, but they were nice as sort of set dressing elements. The tone shift and gameplay focus on movement and momentum reminded me a little of Portal (though this is by no means a comedy) and I recommend it to anybody who likes games that are a sort of one-sitting experience rather than a hundred-hour investment.

30655772.review:
Одна из лучших приключенческих игр, в которые я играл!

Начнём с сюжета и лора. Сюжет подается, как в первых двух частях Bioshock, то есть через аудио-дневники, что делает его ещё более загадочным. И вообще история придумана и продумана очень хорошо. Вся игра носит антивоенно-пацифистский характер, да и её главные идеи жизни/смерти и противостояния человека и природы философские. Лор читать также интересно.

Геймплей у игры действительно уникален. Тут и прыжки на километр, и ходьба во всех плоскостях, и прогулки по воде. Вся долина интерактивна, и её состояние зависит от действий игрока.

Атмосфера и графика. У игры таинственная и мистическо-фантастическая атмосфера, которую действительно ощущаешь. Графика очень красивая и красочная. А от дизайна локаций и пейзажей дух захватывает!

Музыка. Саундтрек у игры божественный! Композиции написаны и подобраны прекрасно.

В общем, игра получилась замечательная! Запомнится надолго, это точно.

10 желудей из 10 :D

30644109.review:
In a world where people spend $60 on AAA trash, I am SO glad that this games exists. 

I don't even know where to begin. 

I'll start with the visuals. And I can't do that without expressing the massive scope of this world. Yes, it's a Unity game, and in most cases, would be a turn off. But the world that was created within the engine is fuckin' jaw dropping. It is MASSIVE! At times I felt like a speck in this world. Everywhere you look, you will find beautiful set peices. Even in the warehouse areas, where most people have complaints about detail, I still found myself understanding the once vibrant mechanical installation being taken over by the nature on this planet. It's gorgeous. 

Next, the gameplay. It's a perfect build up that follows the story the dev's are selling. You learn your way at a perfect pace. With every enhancement to my L.E.A.F. suit, I found myself giddy at the thought of what I can do next. And also, thinking about all those places I was not able to get to previously. Couldn't wait to play through again with all my new found gadgetry. This sucker has replay value. Maybe not forever, but absolutely worth a few play throughs. Your L.E.A.F. suit grants you the ability to swing, jump, run, fly? through this world at insane speeds and it never gets old. Seriously, never gets old. It's SO fun!

Now the story and soundtrack. They compliment the gameplay down to a science. While the story isn't the greatest epic I've ever heard, It was intriguing, and kept me wanting to find the "notes" around the world to get back story as to what happened in this place, and what I'm supposed to do now that I'm here. You really feel like this enviroment you're exploring was here long before you arrived, and you can feel the history of it. Totally cool, kept me going. And the soundtrack. Good lord, the soundtrack. Amazing scores that fit the situation you're in, perfect. Yes, I said scores. This is some orchestral shit right here. You ever watch Braveheart and pay attention to the music? It's no too far off from that. High five to whomever put this together. 

Are there flaws? Sure, every game has them. But the joy I found playing this game overshadows anything I could mention here. Once you find yourself on those rails, you won't care either. :-)

If you're on the fence, take a flyer on this one. Trust me when I say, you've spent a lot more money, for a lot less.

30499950.review:
So I just finished this game.  My thoughts?  It's pretty darn good.  I like indie first person storyline games, and this one did not fail to impress.

Pros:

- Interesting backstory
- The controls are both fluid and solid.  I didnt feel strained to control the character even in the most intense moments.
- The parkour and combat is both enjoyable and difficult, without being too frustrating.
- Graphics are quite good overall.  Decent detail but some things are not as good (look at cons below)
- Some very tense moments
- The music is amazing!  Syncs quite well with afore mentioned tense moments (and exciting ones too)!
- Ran 80+ fps on my Asus Strix rx 480 8gb oc with Highest Settings.
- Indiana Jones meets Fallout 4 and Skyrim. :D

Cons:

- The story could have used a little more time after the ending (SPOILERS!!!) I feel like after the character wakes up from being in the water in the final scene, that he/she should have had some time to re-explore the valley and see the difference.
- Not enough static objects: (trees, bushes, crates in buildings, debris, etc)  Not unbearable but could have used some more interesting things.
- Maybe more creatures???
- Graphics looked somewhat bad at long distances.
- Deer movement animation looked a bit... fake xD

Overall I would reccomend this game!

30484008.review:
Beautiful and well made game all around. Scenery, gameplay, art, design and music - they all interwine harmoniously together creating a solid and enjoyable game. 

The gameplay itself is simple and works. There is a wonderful dreamlike sense of freedom when running like the wind and leaping over boulders and things. You just want to go faster and higher. Come to think of it, the whole game gave me this familiar feeling: "I've had this dream before." 

The story was interesting and well told. I usually don't much care about the story in games - for me it's all about the gameplay and atmosphere. But this time I found myself reading all the notes I could find sprinkled around the gameworld - just out of curiosity. Piece by piece the story and mysteries unfold. I was never given a huge wall of text to read - nor did I feel that the story was forced into my face. Nay, the game gradually reveals the story, mixed with some science, humor and philosophy just the right amounts. I guess this way of telling the story works for me. 

On the technical side I experienced a few bugs and crashes here and there under Linux (thanks for making a port btw). Had to re-replay some parts - but other than that the game ran absolutely great (AMD fx-6300, 8GiB ddr3, Radeon R9 270). 

Overall very well done game that L.E.A.Fs one wanting more.

P.S.

My personal wishes if there will ever be a sequel of sorts:
- Make the gameplay even faster
- Increase the difficulty and challenge
- Make a port for us Linux peasants

30479425.review: It takes a few things implemented well to make a good game. Team Fortress and well balanced character classes, Warcraft and gazillions of things to do, Skyrim and the feeling of a living worlds... Valley does a few things well enough that it can easily be considered a great game. First, it has these 'lively' environments for you to explore. The lightning and the lay out encourages you to go to places. It would be a shame if you could not get everywhere (Remember climbing the Throat of the World for the Notched Pickaxe? what a chore that was...). That is where Valley truly shines, as the second thing it does well is to give you mobility. The controls are very intuitive, so that you are not struggling to figure out how to do that double jump / rope combo to get there. The only difficulty is getting creative in using the skills given to you. Normally these would make an interesting game, but what tops off the Valley is the storyline given through audio logs and personal communications left by the research team. The storyline complements the atmosphere created by the lively environments and actually encourages you to explore more. The only down side is the medium length duration. Which in my case is not a down side at all.

30462188.review:
In a way, this game reminds me of the first Portal. There are no real weapons and it starts off kind of happy and peaceful, but then things start to get a bit dark. 

As others have said, the visuals are beautiful and the music is excellent! The pace, in my opinion, is also quite good. You are regularly rewarded with new upgrades to your suit and the new abilities they add are incorporated into the gameplay well. Nothing feels too tacked on. I even found myself going back after I completed the game to use the fully upgraded suit to find new areas in the earlier levels.

I only have a couple of gripes about this game and they are super minor and nitpicky: 

One is that two of the voices are terrible. The first is the guy in the LEAF suit video. They're trying to make him sound old-timey, but it just sounds like a teenager doing a bad impression. The second is the female automated/computer/warning voice that you hear in the elevators.

My other (again, really nitpicky) complaint is that the signage all over the place uses really modern fonts. Everything else looks so good and polished, but then they decided to use Impact as their font of choice for signs. :(

30460716.review:
Not recommended for people who can't play horror games. Otherwise, definitely give it a try! 

While I really like this game, it has a major flaw that I haven't seen mentioned in any other reviews I've seen: the audio design for most of the game is 1,000% horror, even though it's not trying to be a hardcore horror game. 
[list]
   [*] Many enviormental noises are creepily loud compared to everything else (metal walkways, branches, the small generators, bursts of wind, etc.)
   [*] Eerie dissonant hums or dead silence instead of background music for big chunks of the game 
   [*] It becomes 'Jump Scare: Attack of the Orchestra!' at many points of interest
[/list]

As someone who can't play most horror games without freezing up, this made many parts of the game almost unplayable. I lost track of the number of times I had to pause and walk away for a minute to get away from the ambiance. The rest of the game was good enough that I kept coming back, though.

Pros:
Ok story, fun gameplay mechanics, great visual design, and solid voice acting. Amazing soundtrack. Decent enemy progression: it started off with things that aren't that menacing, and the ones that were suppossed to be a little scary were introduced with enough warning that you could tell that something creepy was ahead of you (no jump scares). 

Cons:
Minor glitches (lighting, audio, and collision detection don't always work right in obscure corners). Awkward save system. Poor choices in sound design make the game feel like a horror game.

30345926.review:
[b]Valley[/b] is a first-person exploration adventure, almost a metroidvania, with [i](very)[/i] light shooteresque elements.

The story begins as the anonymous protagonist sets off to find the Lifeseed, about which nothing is said except that it is purportedly powerful, although whether it actually exists is uncertain. You wash up on the shore of a mountain creek after an assumed canoeing incident and are left to investigate your surroundings. Very early on, you discover what seems to be a cross between a mechanized exoskeleton and a pair of motorized stilts - this contraption [i](a "LEAF suit")[/i] gives you the ability to run superhumanly fast, jump superhumanly high, and more.

As you continue your search for the Lifeseed, you have the opportunity to unravel the stories of previous seekers along the way, via scattered notes and audio recordings. You're also able to find and equip upgrades for your LEAF suit, which allow you to perform progressively more acrobatic feats, which in turn allows you pursue your quest into new, previously inaccessible areas.

The environments in the game are a nice blend of peaceful nature and retro-futuristic industrial settings. All of the visuals, particularly the lighting in the outdoor areas, are extremely well done - I may have had a personal record high screenshots-per-hour while playing Valley. The ambient audio and effects contributed quite a bit to the coherence of the experience, from the pneumatic piston hiss of jumping to the different sounds the suit's metallic feet produced as it impacted different surfaces to the whistling of the wind through the suit's frame as I hurtled through the air.

Gameplay is mostly exploration and parkourish platforming, with some simple environmental puzzles and a small amount of "shooting." [spoiler](Human intervention in the valley triggers the formation of aggressive energy swarms, which can be pacified or overloaded by feeding in energy from the suit.)[/spoiler] The sheer power of the suit makes it enjoyable to climb and jump around on the terrain [i](and you can see [url=images.akamai.steamusercontent.com/ugc/80340029170544676/92CDA1E85F712C521A58558C1FEE22553520E72A/]your feet[/url] - a [b]must[/b] for first-person platforming!)[/i], and the steady feed of new abilities introduced by suit upgrades keeps the experience continuously evolving. I spent about seven hours exploring the valley - some of that was admittedly just monkeying around, but I found it difficult to resist the urge.

If you're looking for an exploration-oriented adventure, Valley might be the place for you.

30345887.review:
Valley by developers Blue Isle Studios can be best described as a platform game with FPS elements where you take control of a daring archeologist as he or she explores the titular valley, a hidden place discovered by the Allies forces during World War II that houses a great, myserious power.

The three main gameplay elements from Valley that sets it apart from other videogames are:

- The L.E.A.F. suit, basically a steampunk-ish exoskeletron your character acquires at the beginning of the game and keeps getting upgrades as you discover new pieces of tech around the Valley. Thanks to the suit your character can run faster, jump great heights and interact with other objects in the environment: in other words, it's used for the platforming elements that made most of this game's gameplay, and it does its job pretty well.

- The life manipulation function of the L.E.A.F. suit. Basically, your character has an energy (life) bar he/she can use to give life to death animals and plants in the environment: vice versa, he/she can absorb energy from the environment to replenish his/her own. If your character dies, he/she will consume a "Energy of the Valley" bar instead and respawn with a bit of energy. While this system sounds unique and interesting on paper, it's undermined by (A) your energy/life being far too easy to recover, even without drining everything else of theirs (B) the total lack of any consequence whatsoever if you end up consuming far too much Energy of the Valley (C) the few sources that can actually be harvested, making the whole thing a bit repetitive.

- The L.E.A.F. suit's combat abilities, which basically boil down to shooting balls of your own energy at enemies. The whole thing is standard FPS fare, and it's not helped by the enemies being basically the same mook over and over again, only with different models.

To be fair, Valley's scenery really is beautiful and haunting at times, and you are given an incentive to explore the various levels by the existence of hidden collectables that allow you to further power-up your L.E.A.F. suit. Unfortunately, though, more often than note you can witness the limits of the game's graphics (lack of polished textures above all the others) first hand.

For being a simple indie product, Valley surely is a more than acceptable videogame with at times original ideas and which is generally fun to play, but it has its clear limits you should keep in mind in deciding to buy it or not and kinda the short lenght (being beatable, exclusind the extras, in well under five hours)
