It's not a long game, the 3 hours I've put in has finished the story mode playing at a meandering pace, but it is a lot of fun.
Pros:
The 'platforming' is amazing. Probably the best first person platforming - it feels amazing, leaping around is a lot of fun.
The story is solid. The main storyline is good, and there are many unanswered questions - presumably they will be answered in secrets I haven't found within the game.
Graphics are good - the various environments are well done.
Sound/music is well done - the music in particular will change with certain set pieces that really are fun.
Set pieces are amazing. What do I mean? There are sections where you basically gotta go faster than sonic, jump insane distances - it has to be seen to be believed.
The death mechanic is well done: Rather than just die or reset, there's an ingame explination involving quantum physics, life and death, its all a little weird but it works well.
New mechanics are introduced pretty much right to the end of the game. It means it's always fresh, there's always something new to do.
Cons:
The story is short - 3 hours isn't that long.
Combat isn't great - it's not bad, but not great. It's not really a focus, and is pretty much more of a distraction than anything else.
... that's about it really, it's a great indie game with unique mechanics. If you like the idea of running and leaping tall buildings in a single bound, this is pretty much as close as you can get.

30280415.review:
Blurring the lines between a 'walking simulator' and an adventure game [h1]Valley[/h1] is an underrated gem released last year which flew under the radar for many of us.

Uniquely beautiful albeit short, the game consists mostly of exploring big parts of a mystical Valley discovered by the player. You're in possession of the L.E.A.F. suit, an old time-y exoskeleton which will empower the player with extraordinary abilities and features. You can run extremely fast, fall through great heights without incident, jump to amazing heights, swing from place to place and the most extraordinary of all... taking or giving life to the flora and fauna of the Valley. The lifeforce of your surroundings powers up the suit but be warned; to gain power by taking lifeforce away is a slippery slope to ruination but more on that later.

There's very little combat in the game but it is there, nothing that will hinder progress or get you stuck, if anything I'd say is too easy but nonetheless I believe it was a very sound decision by the developers in order to preserve the spirit of the game without diverging into more of a shooter.

As you explore the Valley the story is told by 1940's style gramophone recordings, extremely similar storytelling like in the Bioshock series, that is to say it is almost identical. Imitation is the highest form of flattery as they say and I'd have to admit that the plot device works like a charm in this particular case. Without spoiling too much of the story because it is certainly interesting although a tad bit on the cliché side, you can take life from the Valley, either from plants or animals but there's always a cost. Should you die in during your endeavors, the Valley will sacrifice part of its life force to bring you back. Die too many times and face the consequences. The game tends to try too hard with the dialogue and narration especially with quantum theories which I did find a tad bit bizzare but I can understand that it was there to explain a few things regarding the origin of the Valley and its inhabitants. Besides the recordings, there's plenty of notes written by people who've been on the Valley which offer a little bit more lore about the game. 

If you like collectibles and secrets, there are a few spread around the levels and you'll be rewarded with upgrades to your L.E.A.F suit.

Valley however is not without its flaws. There's this huge Valley to explore but the game is fairly linear. Exploration will be done solely on the boundaries of the playable zone and there's not really any motivation besides finding the odd collectible. Some areas are unreachable, some might a little bit glitchy, there's not really lots of items and doodads to interact with and so on. I feel that the game would be even better if it was less linear and offered more side areas to explore but that's not the case.
 
Graphically the game is pretty to look at times... and pretty dull at others. There's some inconsistency and that's a shame cause the environment and effects look pretty darn nice from a distance. Staring at the godrays on the horizon, auroras, sunsets etc, are really great moments in the game but when you get close to some trees or rocks that feeling goes away real quick.

The game is short, ~5 hours to complete but I have to admit that's not actually a terrible thing when compared to the overall spirit of the game. Valley has a story to tell and 'guide' you through it but it doesn't become tedious at any point. Like I mentioned above, combat is pretty scarce and rudimentary and it won't challenge one bit with one minor exception: [spoiler]fighting the Alpha near the end of the game.[/spoiler]

To sum up, Valley is very nicely unique adventure. I loved the story and the storytelling devices, the world is very interesting and there's a nice air of mystery surrounding the place, the L.E.A.F suit feels good for the player to use and upgrade and the developers created an enjoyable experience for the player. Highly recommended for people who like a little bit of mystery, exploration and adventure and I'm kinda hopeful we might see a sequel in the future.

29995245.review:
TL;DR: An extremely fun game about going fast and saving the enviornment.
Disclaimer: Bought on sale.

Pros:
+ A good story that not only deals with the mystique of the valley itself, but also about the risks of science that focuses on weapons for warfare and dangers of only taking from nature.
+ Great voice acting. Even though only two of the actors are in focus, they give very strong performances.
+ Extremly fun gameplay. The game takes great inspirations from Bioshock, but with the L.E.A.F.-suit it almost feels like playing a first-person Sonic game.
+ Beautiful visuals with varied enviornments, a lot of the time very pleasing and with very fitting music.
+ The Daemons are adorable!

Neutral:
* The first 5-10 minutes are very Walking Simulator-like. It may give off the wrong first impression, but once you get the L.E.A.F.-suit, everything changes in the best possible way.
* You can choose between male or female voice for player character. It only changes the voice grunts and nothing else, as the game is in first-person and the player-character never outright speaks, but I do think that it's a nice feature to have.
* Combat varies between fun and boring. Sometimes I had a challenging time combatting enemies, while other times I could just snipe them from afar.

Cons:
- There's a mechanic that you can both give life to nature and take life from it. That could potentially create some challenge, trying to balance the use of giving life, but as there are a lot of orbs around, that challenge is rendered moot. I completed the entire game without ever taking life from nature or animals on purpose.
- Some graphical glitches can occur. There were some times where I could walk through large objects and one point where I accidentally got stuck.

Note: Like some of the people here, I first heard about this game from Jim Sterling's positive impressions-video. I only bought it recently, but I'm very glad that I bought it.

29944942.review:
Valley is a game with fun elements that suffers from a couple of bad decisions by the developers.
The game is best when it's all about speed, running, jumping, swinging - this is a game made for speedruns, for the thrill of speed. The outdoor scenery is beautiful and it's awesome to experience it at a neckbreaking pace - no time to look at the details (which are a bit dated like the two dimensional grass and flowers). Speed is what the game excells in - with tight controls and cool visuals. There's the lovely idea of giving and taking life to survive but it doesn't amount to much. A more philosophical game is hinted at but never realised.
But who thought it was a good idea to put item and log searching in a game that's all about running and jumping? Why are there so many dark and boring indoor levels with ugly textures? Why is there monster shooting at all when it's neither challenging nor interesting? The worst might be the note reading. It's just such an overused and stupid story telling device - and there are tons of notes everywhere! This design decision really confuses me, all the more because the game found a sufficient solution with the auto activating audio logs. Their existence may not make much sense either but at least they don't interrupt the gameplay.
To me Valley is like an overproduced hollywood movie: At the bottom is a brilliant, rather simple idea but in the process more and more stuff got added because the producers didn't trust the original idea ("Hey, why not add a crazy WW2 weapon scientist, those are always fun!") to carry the whole thing. So in the end there's just too much and a lot of it not done right.
I don't mind short games; I completed it under 5 hours but after finishing I had no desire to go back and search for more notes, runes or nuts and I felt no regret when I uninstalled it.
I'd still recommend to play Valley, but be prepared to be a bit disappointed, because with more focus on its mechanics and less story it could have been awesome. 6/10

The combat is boring and unchallenging, and the game is constantly slowing you down when you start to build up speed to open chests and read notes. There's sadly just not enough of the fun, fast-paced platforming that I was expecting. But as much as I have a lot of complaints, this game is incredibly good at what it does (when it bothers to do it) and I would recomend it to anyone interested in a good story and some excellent parkour.

[май инглиш из вери бэд, поэтому я объясню суть на пальцах, а не по сюжету. заодно и без спойлеров обойдемся]

Фишка в том, что у Долины, по которой носится наш герой, есть хп. И она отдает свою жизнь для того, чтобы реснуть нашего гг после каждого косяка. Упали с обрыва - реснулись - оглянулись - деревья полысели. Да, в прямом смысле, и реализовано это крайне круто. Так вот, чтобы восстановить хп Долины, нам нужно раздать энергию всему живому: грибочкам, оленям, кустикам и т.п. Тогда ветка хп заполнится и снова можно косорезить. 

Не спорю, шарики энергии по всей игре появляются крайне часто, и оказаться в критической ситуации практически невозможно, но в этой игре хардкор другой. Попробуйте-ка разогнаться, глядя себе в пятки, а потом не промахнуться мимо мостика, прыгнуть в нужный момент, перелететь метров 500 над пропастью и приземлиться ровно на небольшую площадку, ха?

Лично мне игрушка зашла. Сплошная динамика, приятный глазу графон, потрясная музыка... Если вам надоели монстры и вы хотите просто побегать наперегонки с ветром - покупайте Valley.

Пс, играть лучше на паде - вибрация проработана очень круто)

주인공이 생명의 씨앗을 찾아 나서다 이상한 장비 하나를 발견해 입고 뛰어다니는 이야기.
중간중간 적이 나오긴 하나 전혀 위협적이지 않고 투사체 3발만 맞추면 잠재울 수 있기 때문에
사실상 달리기와 점프가 게임의 전부이다.
적의 종류도 색깔이나 형태만 다르지 그놈이 그놈.
시작할때 주인공의 목소리를 남성이나 여성 중 선택할 수 있는데 점프하거나 착지할때 나오는 소리가 전부이다.

나무를 살리면 얻는 도토리로는 비밀문을 열 수 있고 상자 까면 나오는 메달은 후반부 피라미드 방을 여는 때 사용된다만..
비밀문이래야 이 게임은 수집품이 투사체 발사 횟수를 늘려주는 에너지팩 하나가 전부이고, 길가다 보이는 것만 모아도 후반에는 에너지가 차고 넘친다. 메달은 피라미드 첫번째 방을 여는데 30개, 두번째 방을 여는데 40개로 총 70개가 필요한데 이 게임은 현재 맵에 상자나 메달이 몇개 존재하는지 알려주지 않고 메달 위치에 대한 힌트도 없다. 즉, 메달을 찾으려면 넓은 맵에 몇개 까지 있는지도 모르는채 샅샅이 뒤져가면서 찾아야 하기 때문에 딱히 찾고싶지도 않다..

결국 달리기와 점프가 전부인 게임인데 올클한 이유는 상당히 공을 들인 맵 배경과 음악, 질주할 때의 속도감. 그리고 높은 곳에서 떨어질때 마치 자이로드롭을 타듯 심장에 짜릿한 느낌이 들어서 계속 하게됐다.
슈팅성이나 아이템 수집의 재미는 제로에 가깝기 때문에 그런걸 기대한다면 비추.

대략 3시간 정도면 클리어 가능하고 두번 플레이할 만한 게임은 아니라서 할인된 가격에 사는걸  추천한다.
필자가 4시간이 걸린 이유는 중간에 장비 업그레이드 상자를 못보고 지나쳐서 진행할 수 없게 되어 좀 헤맸기 때문이다..

29877025.review:
Blue Isle Studios, you just made another amazing game.

Valley was an extraordinary experience, it had a good mix of beauty, adventure, stressful fighting, problem solving, and SAD EMOTIONS ;( . Now, I'm not going to spoil anything, (because you need to play it for yourself), but the plot, characters, and plot twists with perfectly executed and was a well thought out story. The graphics and visuals? Hands down, best in 2016. I knew this game was beautiful before I bought it because it's made my Blue isle Studios, which also made Slender: The Arrival, (which you should also check out), and that game was GORGEOUS, even though it was just supposed to be about the horror aspect, and this game definitely kicked it up a couple notches and showed that this company is professional in its story telling and visuals. Though the entire story is about 3 - 4 hours long, that's if you just wander around, doing everything your told and not hunting for secrets. This game has LOADS of secrets and easter eggs that mostly require acorns or medals, (you'll find out once you play), and it's fun to try to track them all down. The challenging level was not as much as some other games out there, it's mostly pretty calm, (besides the monsters), and there's not a place you'll just get stuck at and can't get through, which is nice.  Throughout the entire story, I only lost all my "lives" once, but there was definitely times where I would be VERY close to dying completely, and have to figure out how to gain my lives back.

This game is definitely worth a try, no matter what kind of games you like, and after you beat the game, go try out Slender: The Arrival, because this company is amazing ;)

29876800.review:
plus vite! plus haut! PLUS VITE! PLUS HAUT! OUIIIIIII!

heu...(raclement de gorge) la critique... Valley nous propose d'incarner un ersazt d'archéologue qui découvre une vallée totalement inconnue dans les Rocheuses abritant des restes d'une civilitation mystérieuse, des esprits de la forêt plus ou moins belliqueux et une base militaire encore fonctionnelle datant des années 30 à 40. Vous vous déplacez grâce à un exosquelette construit à ladite base, fonctionnant grâce à des bouboules d'énergie bleues flottant dans la vallée.

Commençons par ce qui fâche, ou fait soupirer tout du moins. L'histoire, bien que bien narrée (ça sent fortement la reprise de l'esthétique de Bioshock), est assez bateau. Et, sérieusement, chers sénaristes, si le scénario n'est pas parodique, évitez les explications pseudo-scientifiques. Gardez le jargon si vous voulez, mais évitez d'expliquer, surtout en maltraitant la physique quantique. Parce que si l'explication est bancale, elle amène des questions qui ne se seraient peut être pas posées dans le flot du jeu. 

Mais si l'histoire oscille entre passable et bancale, le reste est de meilleure facture. C'est beau. Le soundesign s'adapte superbement aux phases de jeu et les phases de jeu proposent quelques très bonnes sensations. Le costume amplifie les sauts et la vitesse et se voit conférer quelques améliorations au cours du jeu qui varient son utilisation. Si les phases de plateformes demandent du temps de prise en main, les phases de sprint sont justes excellentes (OUIIIIII!).

Sur ce, je repars courir et sauter.

29855653.review:
Full review below.

The Good
* Very visually pleasing
* Great soundtrack
* The first 20 minutes of gameplay

The Meh
* The story

The Bad
* The rest of the gameplay
* The price
* About two hours long 
(I don't normally complain about game length but two hours for a twenty dollar game I didn't enjoy I think it's worth mentioning)



While a lot of story-driven indie games these days receive the dubious moniker 'walking simluator' I believe in this case 'running simulator' is a more accurate term. You're character is highly mobile and capable of a handful of acrobatic, albeit standard, maneuvers by the end of the game. This is thank to the L.E.A.F. suit which in addition to allowing you to run much faster and jump higher allows you to both give life back to dead fauna and flora or drain them of life for energy. This ability is more intriguing in concept than in practice as I rarely ever saw a reason to drain life from anything. Even during the games weak combat you give life rather than taking it and there's an abundance of energy pickups scattered throughout the game anyway.  

Despite the short game length Valley has, it manages to overstay its welcome and lose all the monentum it intially has rather quickly. Even so the developers tried to desperately pad out the length of the game by including optional powerups you can find and letting you travel back to previous areas but the upgrades are always just more energy for your suit which is totally unnecessary. 

The second big draw that most games have is the story and while I didn't find this particular entry offensive it wasn't interesting either. The story unfolds through audio diaries that automatically play during your time exploring the world much in the same way it's done in Bioshock, although in this case you don't actually need to find them. The characters seem to exist more as vehicle for the story rather than actual people. The plot does actually have one decent point you uncover towards the end but for the most part is forgettable.

So if the gameplay and story are bad, is there anything redeemable about the game? Yes, there is actually. The game has great visuals, the world can be a little sparse but there's some great vistas to be seen in the game. Also the soundtrack is top-notch and matches what is happening in the game quite well. Unforunately these aspects aren't enough to carry the game but they certainly are worth mentioning.

Ultimately the game comes close to being something I enjoyed but fell just a bit short. I was actually smiling as I was running down those first hills in the L.E.A.F. suit and jumping around but after twenty minutes that feeling went away. For the next 40 minutes I was just kind of hoping for an upgrade that would make the game feel fresh again. The last hour felt just plain tedious and then the game was over. Blue Valley has a good framework here and I'd love to see the concepts explored more fully.

29843317.review:
An exquisitely crafted game mostly about the exhiliration of running and flying through the air, and granting life to nature.

In the Valley, you'll be introduced to an incredible, and lovingly created forestry. It's populated by derpy little forest sprites known as 'deamons' throughout the story, deer, a few rabbits, all scampering across gorgeous fields.

The combat is not exceedingly great, however it is enough to provide some exhiliration when enemies get the drop on you -- which they will, as vertigo can overtake you in a moment and a enemy will sometimes be positioned just right to capitalize on it.

I've recently finished the game, and am going back to peck around for all the hidden tidbits that I missed -- which is quite fortunate because, that means replay value for those who search for such things! In a almost MetroidVania sort of fashion, you can use the cahpter select with all the upgrades you currently posess for your L.E.A.F. suit, and use them to access spots you might be very shocked you missed before, or simply disregarded while being swept up in the colors and speed.

Without being too spoliery, the story isn't half bad. The 'evil scientist' has all the proper motivaitons to drive him to his own doom, the ecologist girl is pretty, intelligent, and thoughtful.

The musical score is phenomenal, and well keyed to certain points of action, where a sudden crescendo will kick in at the pinnacle of your jump, leave the air empty except for the whistling of wind, and then suddenly pick back up at double pace on your flawless landing. It sends a real chill up the spine and for me, at least, sends a chill up the spine and puts a grin on the face.

So, to break it down. Story, pretty good. Combat, so so, nothing extraordinary. But the platforming, and speed? 10/10.

On a personal note, if the developers should happen to see this, I think the rail segment of the facility has a really intriguing chance to be turned into its own thing. Racing games have lacked a unique angle for years now, and Valley might just secretly have what's needed to breathe some life into the genre. Personal opinion, of course.

Hope you enjoy the game as much as I did!

OK - only played the game an hour and a half but I like it a lot. 
Reminds me, in places, of Firewatch but with more fantastical graphics and the ability/need to give life/reap life as a means to progress. I love the controls - there are so few of them. I'm left-handed mouse user but the keys are configurable it seems (personally I use a USB sub-keyboard but it's only standard movement keys that need to be remapped for the lefty).
At first I was disappointed in the 'water' - didn't look real. I thought it an issue with the Unity Engine used. But no - I think it's style-ised just so - you get to realise you're "we're not in Kansas anymore, Toto".
I waited for the game to be on sale (held in my wishlist) but now I know what it's like I'd have paid full price. Beautiful game - in looks, play and atmosphere.
NOT for combat monkeys (I am at times) or RPG-heads (I am often).
It's just a great solo game. Actually not great so far... Brilliant.

29809738.review:
It isn't often that you find a game like this. To sum up the gameplay in a single idea - for me when I would ride in the car as a young girl, I would imagine running alongside the road, leaping from place to place with ease and joy. That is what Valley feels like. But it's so much more. 

In Valley, you play as an investagive journalist (I think) who seeks to discover the truth about the "Lifeseed," a mysterious mythic artifact capable of great destruction and creation. The game opens dynamically as your canoe topples down a waterfall. After crawling through a small cave, you emerge into a beautiful sunlit valley filled with deer, rabbits, and strange sprites. It is an exciting and appropriate opening that emphasizes Valley's two main themes: movement, and life.

You explore mysterious doors and run obstacle courses, but the main activity in the game is wonder. The feeling of running alongside a doe and her faun across the open meadow, bounding up the hill ahead of you and leaping into the air as a new landscape of the valley unfolds to you. 

The game shifts often. The way you move in the valley is always changing and the tone shifts often from immersing you in the beauty and love of life and plunging you into truly terrifying places deep below the ground. There are a few notes that are missed that keep these moments from making Valley a horror game, but the atmosphere is there and the ultimate subject of the game is truly the stuff of horror stories. 

Valley's overarching message is anti-nuclear and anti-war. The game gives you the mostly joyously free movement, power over life and death, and immortality and by the end, you are eager to give it up to stop the terrible power accumulating in the idyllic valley and what that power represents. You are eager to give it up because of how much the game immerses you in the joy of life. Honestly this game is remarkable. It is determined and powerful in its themes and message. It's not subtle, but it is graceful. 

Some notes: 
I like that you choose your gender at the beginning of the game. It doesn't impact the story at all, but it does wonders for feeling like *you* are there running alongside the deer and leaping through the air and controlling great and terrible powers and that is important in this game. 

I don't like the combat very much. It's simple and elegant and really there isn't too much of it. Mostly it serves as like, a jump scare or an abrupt change of tempo in the game. The issue is, the game achieves both those things better in other ways.

29807939.review: I didn't think I was going to finish this game (not my cup of team). But I liked it. All the different updates, the interesting story, the good atmosphere and the relaxed "combat", together with a good platform mechanics and OUTSTANDING Soundtrack, lead me to finish the game and enjoying all parts of it. Definitely reccomended for a 5 hours of something-more than a walking simulator.

29802513.review: 훌륭한 자연경관과 배경음악에 넋을 잃고 플레이했다. 원가에 주고 사도 아깝지 않을 수작이다.

29802449.review:
I was thoroughly impressed by this little gem of a game. Wonderful art and world design, decent voice acting and an interesting (although rather uninspired) story. I got it on half price during a sale for $10 and really wasn't expecting much out of it other than a few hours of fun running around. It turned out to easily be worth the price of admission.

Pros-

Gorgeous out door enviroments and detailed indoor sections make the world itself a pleasure to explore. I took numerous screenshots throughout the entire game. It's a shame I couldn't find a way to turn off the HUD, or some of them may have been my new desktop wallpaper.

The progression system was great, with a balanced drip feed of new abilities and enemies to encounter to keep things fresh during the game.

Running about the place, building momentum and jumping stupidly high was easily the best part of the game. Whilst not particularly difficult, soaring through the air after a well timed jump only to land and do it again, only much faster, is incredibly satisfying. Interesting level design made sure it never gets old either.

The game's narrative, although not it's strongest point, also added to the experience in a positive way. There is a mystery to uncover, as well as many secrets to discover hidden throughout the Valley. This gives you direction during the game, and the ending is well done too.

Cons-

The combat was stupid. No depth, it was just there to give you something extra to click at while running about. The enemies themselves were well designed (all three of them) but the way you go about disposing all of them is the same. You shoot them. Sometimes from so far away the don't even react.

It doesn't run fantastic. Multiple random frame drops throughout the game and my PC is nothing to laugh at. It doesn't ruin the game by any means, but it's still a nuisance.

It was disappointingly short. Although all the content that was there is high quality, there just wasn't much of it. You can draw out the experience by trying to collect everything and open every door, but if that isn't your idea of fun (I know it isn't mine), there isn't too much to see.

Conclusion-

Overall, Valley is nothing short good and nothing more than great. It does what it does very well. And although I have to class it as yet another "short and sweet indie game" it's still a wonderful experience that is well worth the price. If you're looking for something a bit different, definitely check this out.

I've gotta say... this game really surprised me, and I'm hesitant to explain why for fear of overstating things.  Spoilers near the bottom.

The plot is fairly easy to guess, and the "combat" is easy (which I liked - my reflexes are lamentable), but the action is fun, smooth, and stutter-free, and the graphics are pretty ([i]and[/i] I had to set graphics to "Low" - my PC is 4 yrs old).

Another point of enjoyment is that you're free to go back to any area, w/ all the upgrades you've aquired, to keep exploring the world and aquiring collectibles & upgrades.

As for the spoiler... it isn't much of one, but [spoiler]the upgrade progression is really cleverly done, IMO, in that many of them weren't even an obvious "need" until after you had it.  Too many games really telegraph that, these days.  "Oh, gee, a metal wall I can't climb. *yawn*  I'll just come back when I get the metal-wall-climbing upgrade.[/spoiler]

Long story short, and I don't say this often, but if I knew I'd enjoy it this much I probably would've paid full price for it weeks ago.

29736861.review:
Though I own (yet haven't played) Blue Isle's other offering to date (Slenderman: The Arrival), Valley was nowhere near my radar. But then an enthusiastic Jim Sterling recommendation of Valley caught my attention. I'm no Sterling sycophant, but in this case he was spot-on: Valley is an absolute gem, one of those rare independent games with little to no hype but mountains of high-quality heart. Oh, and it's actually FUN! Who doesn't want to run around the Rocky Mountains at breakneck speed challenging every deer you meet to a race and jumping over hilltops like a cow over the moon? And on this point, Valley absolutely nails the vertigo-inducing feeling of launching yourself into the atmosphere at inhuman speed and impossible height. The story is good, the lore believable, the voice acting superb, and the visuals are almost-Ethan-Carter pretty (playing at ultra widescreen 3440x1440 is nearly breathtaking). Sure, seeing the cute little pacman-ghost-like deamons flitting about the countryside almost gave me pause: Uh, is this some saccharine kiddie game dressed up in an action suit? Thankfully, the answer is no. Much to the contrary, the themes in Valley are actually steeped in death--well, the constant cycle of life and death. But the game somehow takes that gravitas and flings it into a positive, thrilling--and FUN--experience. First-person adventure seekers need not hesitate.

Postscript-- I openly admit this is blatant nitpicking, but if I have really only one critique/suggestion for the game, it would be this: I'd bet a paycheck that the same actor who portrays protagonist Virginia King (reading her logs) is the same actor who does the recorded "warning" announcements at the various sites (Astra, Soma, etc.). Though EQ manipulation and distortion are used over the loudspeakers to hide this fact, it is pretty obviously the same person. I get it; good voice actors are probably pricey, and this is a budget title created by a small developer. But still...it would be a bonus to not have this (slightly) immersion-breaking element in the game. I only mention it because I like the game tremendously. And no, I'm not looking for voice work.

Postscript postcript-- ...aaand, guess I just lost a paycheck. Just got to the credits at the end,  and I see that Virginia King and the announcement voice are two different actors after all--Claudia Lenz and Ashley Marie--but wow, they sound amazingly alike. Nevertheless, my only criticism duly revoked.

29620581.review:
I can easily say that Valley is my hidden gem of 2016. It's a shame that this game didn't get much attention. Valley could easily be confused for a 'walking sim' style game like Dear Esther or even Firewatch, and it might seem that way for the first few minutes, but it quickly becomes a fast moving platformer and eventually delves into some action as it takes provides some 1st-person shooter qualities. The way the abilities and combat draw from the same energy, including your health, made a really cool system of risk and reward.

Visually, on a technical level and artistic level, Valley is fanstastic. Also, the performance is amzing and mind-boggling given the visuals and scale of the game. The story is pretty good and unfolds through a mix of audio logs and papers scattered about the world. If you don't care about the story, the game doesn't force you to it. The audio is great though I do have a massive issue with the ding noise while mousing over items in the menus. Holy crap is that loud even when the master volume is at ~20%. 

For me, the biggest draw was the gameplay. I saw the trailer on Steam and thought it looked like a fast paced platformer, and it is. I wish Capcom would play this and take notes as to how they should make a Sonic game in 2017. There are some specific moments in Valley that just had me floored with the speed, the visuals, the music, and level design. Highlights that will stick with me for a while. It may not make it to my Top 10 games for 2016 (or 2017 since that's when I played it), but man is it close. 

4.5/5 I just wish it was longer, maybe 7 hours, and it could have gotten a 5.

29609430.review: This game gave me the feeling of freedom, the music gave me chills while soaring throught the treetops after huge momentum jump. And the whole story made me want to set things right, but the musicbox in the end really got me emotional.﻿ This game, it's beautiful, it truely is.

29566730.review:
Valley ist eine spannende Mischung aus Bioshock, Walking Simulator und Portal. 
Klingt komisch? Ich schlüssele mal auf:

Bioshock:
Die Story handelt von einem mysteriösen Lifeseed, einen Trupp Soldaten aus dem zweiten Weltkrieg - inkl. fanatischen Wissenschaftler - und einen mystischen eingeborenen Stamm. Die Erzählweise durch Audiologs, Briefen und Umwelt scheint sehr stark an Bioshock angelehnt zu sein, auch wenn noch Feinheiten fehlen und nicht mit großen Plottwists zu rechnen ist. Hier wurde Potential verschenkt. Und es wäre noch viel mehr möglich gewesen. 
Gunplay gibt es auch, aber die Anzahl der Gegnertypen ist gering und die einzige Waffe ist der LEAF Suit. Auf Dauer fand ich die Kämpfe sogar etwas störend - aber nicht zu sehr. Der Schwierigkeitsgrad ist insbesondere bei Kämpfen sehr niedrig, ein Tod ist nicht wirklich bestrafend, sondern lässt einen direkt weiterspielen. Ein paar Bäume wiederbeleben sollte aber drin sein. 

Walking Simulator:
Der Begriff Walking Simulator ist für viele negativ besetzt, für mich nicht. Valley führt uns durch mehr oder weniger schön detaillierte Landschaften. Grafisch kommt es nicht an ein "Ethan Carter" ran, aber dass muss es auch nicht. Der Levelaufbau ist sehr linear, erzählt aber überall kleine Geschichten. 

Portal: 
Der Leaf Suit erinnert schon sehr stark an Chells Anzug aus Portal. Sprünge aus großen Höhen sind kein Problem. Es gibt viele kleine Rätsel zu lösen und die werden durch Adrenalingeladene Sprung und Laufpassagen abgelöst. Die Schienenpassage im ersten Drittel ist übrigens mein Highlight! Man kann auch ein paar Parallelen zu "Story of my Uncle" ziehen.

Wenn man erst einmal im Spiel drin ist, will man erst nicht mehr aufhören. Ich habe ca 80% des Spiels in einer Session durchgespielt und die Zeit ist an mir vorbeigerast. Leider ist es mit knapp 3h nicht sehr lang, gerne hätte ich noch weitere Abschnitte gespielt. 

Lohnt es sich? 
Kurz: Ja 
Lang: Wenn ihr den obigen Games und Genres etwas abgewinnen könnt, holt es euch. Man darf aber keinen Actiongeladenen Shooter erwarten. 

Achja: Die Medallienjagd ist ein Witz. Hat man die erste Tür (mit 30 Medallien) geknackt, kommt ein recht sinnfreies Update und eine zweite Tür mit 40 Medallien). Nachdem ich auf YT gesehen haben was sich dahinter versteckt bin ich froh dass ich meine Lebenszeit hier nicht verschwendet habe. Hier wäre ein Potential für einen Plotttwist gewesen.

29507727.review: This is honestly the best game I have played for a few years. It is honestly a shame a gem like this it lost on all the crap steam lets in.

29506973.review:
This game has prompted my first ever review on Steam. 
To cut to the chase - I was so blown away by the whole atmosphere of this game that (once I completed it) I rushed out and bought an rx 480 graphics card so that I can enjoy it even more the second time around. 
(It ran nicely enough on an old 6850 with i5 processor though)
Graphics are beautiful, sound and music is really something special, the story is completely engrossing and the gameplay incorporates loads of well-known elements but - maybe somewhat bizarrely - without gratuitous violence, and I really enjoyed it BECAUSE of this.  It was somehow more "relaxing" (?) than the usual fps games. 
Yes - I wish it was longer but I am enjoying playing a second time looking more closely and taking my time now to explore and find the secrets.  
I REALLY hope there's a Valley 2....

29497570.review:
First ever review...

Game is very fun an fullfilling as you explore rediscover an ancient civilzation with post war tech, only to discover a sinister government conspiracy that took place 50 years ago

Pros-great scenery/graphics
Solid AI nemies
Low stress death mechanic(just respawn where you died 3 secs before)
Decent story telling(if bothered to read it all and listen)
Good area design

Cons-low replay value(can select areas you may want to return to)
Linear storyline

TLDR-a good version of bioshock/half life with up to date graphics, not for speed play or warmongers

29457881.review:
This is a beautifully crafted piece of art from beginning to end. It's very clear that a lot of effort and passion went into the construction of this game, and though it's gameplay mechanics are simple, they do not fail to immerse you in the world.
Although the story is incredibly short and can be finished in an afternoon, there aren't any particularly slow parts that stand out to me or any parts that I felt I wanted to get through quickly due to tedium or noninterest. I easily spent a good forty minutes in the first open field, sprinting through and reviving trees and collecting the acorns they dropped. I do wish the story was a bit longer, however, as I feel I only scratched the surface of this world.
All and all I would recommend this game to anyone who has a free few hours to play something with a surprisingly in depth story, despite being told almost exclusively through audio logs, and an exceptionally deep lore set in a beautiful setting of industrial revolution against nature. I look forward to future games by Blue Isle Studios .

29436847.review:
Great game!
Very short, but its perfect. The movement is fluid, and the lore is fun.
I would highly recomend this game.

29392818.review: This is a very creative, original game, with extremely fun movement mechanics, beautiful vistas, and a surprisingly epic conclusion. The "health system" is quite unique, combat sequences are atypical but rather satisfying, and the last levels do a nice job of testing the skills you've acquired playing the game and applying its mechanics. There's a good amount of story bits and collectibles to find, as well. Overall an experience very well done.

I spent as much time wandering around in the game looking at the beatuiful graphics as i did progressing through it. the difficulty is spot on as well. i cannot recommend this game enough.

P.S. Please make a sequel!

29363509.review:
A beautiful first-person platforming game. Valley does a great job of getting you invested in the environment, as well as conveying a sense of speed and height through sound and visual design.

If you take your time, you will be with this game for somewhere between 4 to 6 hours. This game has a lot of backstory and collectibles to find, and you can easily extend your time finding these things. The only criticism I have of this game is that it is very easy and doesn't pose too much challenge. Pick this up for a more relaxing experience.

29287757.review:
Wow, where to start...

This game was absolutely breathtaking.  At the end when the credits rolled I stood up from my chair and clapped for 5 minutes straght.

Seriously do yourself a favor and get this game.  I can't believe it doesn't have more steam reviews and I also can't believe they aren't overwhelmingly positive.

Pros
Graphics -  Not the best I've ever seen but the game is beautiful and the artwork fits nicely.
Performance and optimization -  Flawless.  There was not a single dip in frames anywhere in the game.  I played at 3440x1440 with everything cranked to the max, except for AA, and I was able to maintain 70-90fps the while game.
Audio - One of the few games these days that has a 5.1 surround option!!! This is clutch!  Also, the sound effects in the game are great.  The sound of your feet on metal, wood, and grass, are all nicely done when compared to the same sounds in other games.
Soundtrack - Stunning.  This is definitely a highlight of the game.  The soundtrack, just like the audio, is very nicely done.  Very relaxing and majestic.
Mechanics - Also great.  The suit that you wear just gets better and better throughout the game.  I LOVED skating on the rails and skimming across the water was also really sweet.  
Level Design - Another big highlight of the game.  I was so impressed by the overall complexity of the level design with the huge jumps, grappling hook, and walking on walls.  

I'm tired of typing so I'm just going to stop here

Oh yea, the one negative.
Save system - The game doesn't have a particularly good save system, so if you get fairly far into a level and you die, or fall off a big cliff, it may take you a bit to get back to where you were, but this only happend a few times during my playthrough and it wasn't a huge deal.  Had I not been able to finish the game in one sitting I would have liked a bit better save system.

29262740.review:
I was honestly blown away by this game. I wasn't expecting much more than a walking simulator, but it's so much more than that. It's colorful, whimsical, and at times has dark themes to counter it. The gameplay is fast paced, and it's always changing with new upgrades that change the way you interact with your environment. The story made me passionate about completing the game's goal, and the voice acting and soundtrack were complimentary with the game, which really succeeded in setting the mood. 

The only negative thing I experienced with this game was that it's not optimized well. My PC can more than handle this game, but I was forced to play on low graphics settings to have 60 frames. It really wasn't that big of a deal, though, because it didn't take away from the game as a whole.

29262663.review:
Absolutely fantastic adventure game! Took me about five hours for first playthrough and it lets you go back to any level after the end to continue hunting for items. Music is really good and it has some cool 'on rails' sections :-D
Story and voice acting were very good too! Simple combat but it suited the game.

29261865.review: This game was a lot of fun. A wonderful mix of fluid freedom of mobility and extreme speed, interesting story, and gorgeous, open environments. I definitely recommend this game to anyone who wants a rush with some exploration sprinkled in.

29260282.review: What a positive surprise! Small game with a really deep story and a complex, yet simple, gameplay that is focused on fun. Walking simulator? Rather fun simulator. Really good game.

29217146.review:
Valley is a First-Person, Walking/Running Simulator, Platformer, Puzzle, Adventure.  You play as an unnamed archaeologist (choose Male or Female) in search of the "Life Seed" and end up stumbling upon the ruins of an expedition that saught out the "Life Seed" decades before you.  Amung the ruins you find the audio recording of archaeologist Virgina King and experimental L.E.A.F. suit which you will wear throughout the game.

You will run, you will jump, you will give life back to nature, and (possibly) take it away.  You will also follow the story of the previous expedition in notes and letters left behind, as well as Virginia King's recordings.  You will NOT be gunning down soldiers or mercenaries, though there are a few creatures in the valley that will attack and will need to be passified with the only "weapon" you have, the L.E.A.F. suit's God Hand.

If you can handle that, Valley is a game you will probably enjoy.

29213350.review: Totaly worth the money if you buy it on sale, The game reminds me of "a story about my uncle" I got almost the same feeling when playing this game. It took me 3 hours to go through the game and I was looking for secrets the first half of the game.

It is more than safe to say that this game is a master piece, a journey that has to be experienced. I am moved and touched by every aspect of it.

29187655.review: 很一般很一般的游戏。大部分时间都不知道去哪。

29157407.review: A good adventure akin "A Story About My Uncle" by gameplay mechanic and general mood. The whole point of the game is exploration, and it is doing a great job in this regard. I am glad I didn't miss it.

29157398.review:
Very fun game. Finished it in about 5-6 hours. I would recommend not trying to find every crate, acorn, medallion, etc. The upgrades are nice, but not really worth the trouble (you can always go back after the game is over to collect them as sort of a NewGame+ mode). More fun to sit back, relax, and run and fly as fast and as far as you can without stopping. Nice break from Fallout 4, Dishonored, etc.

And if you don't upgrade your energy reserves, the game is more challenging during the fight sequences. I had so many energy slots the combat was quite easy - never died from fighting.

Story was good, although didn't quite understand the ending. There's a lot of notes lying around that you can read. They were fun, but not necessary. Again, if I knew better, I would have skipped the notes as well and just kept running.

Graphics were pretty good. Outside definitely better than inside. Couldn't get high-end antialiasing working smoothly, so had to leave it on FXAA, and I have SLI 980Ti's.

Overall, great game if you want to actually finish a game nowadays, which I seem to never do.

29139246.review:
A very enjoyable game.

Excellent atmosphere and environments, well realised. (The concept art work at the end credits is worth checking out too.)

The story isn't Earth-shattering (excuse the pun), but is well told and sufficiently engaging. There are notes scattered about if you care to read more into the story, but the majority is (very well) voice-acted in-game while continuing to play. This means there are no flow-breaking cutscenes, which was an excellent choice here; far more immersive.

I thought the game length was ideal for the price. It felt varied, complete and rewarding. Without outstaying its welcome or intruducing 'padding' just for the sake of making the game longer. It's certainly not a challenging game; yet I still felt involved enough to play all the way through before I realised this.

On the negatives side, there were a couple of places where it was really unclear what to do; which were inevitably game-blocking. This in not unusual in this kind of game, and it's probably better than never feeling that you actually had to contribute something to progress.

Also, there is no save feature; instead checkpoints are used. This actually works really well while playing; being able to save before every single action would probably break the game considerably. The problem comes when you have to stop playing (yes; some of us do ;). Then you can only re-start and the beginning of the entire area, potentially losing considerable progress. 

A final negative is that I didn't enjoy the in-door sections nearly as much as being outside. Unfortunately, the majority of the game seemed to be played in some kind of 'facility' or another. Making far too little use of the tititular 'Valley' imo.

Overall though the game's negatives were insignificant compared to its appeal. Not many games hold my attention right until the end, but this definitely did. Highly recommended.

29133931.review:
UPDATE: I started this up again, and it seemed to be a marked improvement. As a result, I changed my recommendation.

To clarify: I actually love this game. My non-recommendation is for the poor optimization of the Linux. At low settings, the game was struggling to run at 60 fps on my GTX 660 and would drop to 30 in the more intense areas.

That being said, the visuals are gorgeous, even at low settings, and the minimalistic narrative keeps you engaged as the plot unravels. It's actually reminiscent to the likes of Gone Home and Journey. The gameplay couldn't be further from them. Imagine a first-person Sonic the Hedgehog with a grappling hook and you'll get an idea of what to expect this game. The sense of speed is incredible and the platforming is so satisfying.

Assuming the game runs well on at least some of the other platforms, I highly recommend checking it out. Unfortunately, if you're a Linux gamer like myself, I highly suggest waiting to see if the developers will release a patch to optimize the port. If they do, I'd be more than happy to give this a thumbs-up.

29130654.review: I would gladly pay for dlc levels in a game this fun. Hint Hint Also its been a long time since a game made my face hurt from how long I smiled while playing.

29107005.review:
Buy Valley. This game offered unfettered movement of a type i've not seen before in a game. You run and jump seamlessly, picking up speed from downhill slopes to help you jump across chasms. The story is good light sci-fi mixed with 1940's military fiction. There isn't much combat and what there is is very simplified. If you're down to experience a good story and some fun runnin', then by all means pick this up. 

One caveat. Pick it up on sale. You might get hours and hours out of it if you're a completionist but my regular old playthrough only lasted 2.4 hours.

29100286.review:
Yeah, it's not that long but imho, the gameplay makes more for than up for it. It's just so much fun running and jumping around with the suit. As the game progresses, more movement mechanics are added that just add to it. Very cool.

The story is good, the music is just beautiful and graphics-wise this is the best I've seen so far produced with Unity. Well done.

My 5.4 hours are pretty much what I needed to play the game from start to finish. I explored here and there and tried to find most stuff (and failed), so make it 3-4 hours if you intend to rush through.

Eventually, it's short but worth it just for the gameplay. I'd love to see a prequel to expand on the events before the player enters.

29082078.review: The game is very atmospheric, fun to play, with an interesting storyline. You get a nifty suit that allows you to run super fast, jump really high, shoot energy pew pews, and some other fun things. Some have mentioned that the game is short and I won't disagree there, but I thought the pacing was nice and didn't get too monotonous; which is good IMO. Too long and one may get bored with the mechanics, I thought the developers hit the sweet spot.

29080875.review:
Dziwna gra. Chociaz jest widok FPP i masz celownik nie ma strzelania i nie mozesz nikogo zabic. Chociaz inaczej; mozesz zabic. Jak najbardziej. Ale zabijanie nie polega na usmierceniu by zdobyc punkty. Tutaj mozesz wyssac energie zyciowa. Ale mozesz ja takze oddac, by np wskrzesic uschniete drzewo. Lub padniete zwierze. Altruizm to chyba najlepsze slowo. Malo tego. Twoje czyny wplywaja na wyglad swiata naokolo. Im wiecej i czesciej bedziesz umieral, tym mroczniejszy swiat bedzie naokolo Ciebie. Twoja smierc kolejna i kolejna, bedzie wysysac energie zyciowa ze swiata naokolo Ciebie. Kapitalny pomysl.

Masz elementy lamiglowki, ale nie ma puzli i innych trudnych logicznie zadan. Masz podstawowa eksploracje swiata by zrobic to lub inne, ale nie musisz isc do przodu o dwa kroki, pociagnac dzwignie, wrocic trzy kroki do tylu nucac makarene od tylu po arabsku by na koncu obrocic sie w wyskowu jak czak noris by aktywowac teleport ktory .... Nie, tego tutaj nie ma. Fabula ( ktora jest ladnie i dobrze napisana i opowiedziana ) powoli wciaga Cie w historie ... Ktora musisz sam odkryc. Bo warto. Chocby dla samego faktu poznania. A warto! Dawno juz nie chcialem poznac co sie kryje dalej. 

Jest w koncu fizyka. Ale nie jest to Garry's mod. Zwyczajnie musisz pamietac, iz majac swoj egzoszkielet, mozesz skakac dalej i wyzej. Jak dluz utrzymasz moment rozpedu i przyspieszenia. Jesli takiego momentum nie bedziesz mial, spadniesz. Co wiaze sie z powrotem do poprzedniego stanu zapisanego ( ktory to gra robi sama, a robi to dostatecznie czesto bys nie musial spedzic ostatniej pol godz na powrot ) i ponownego skoku. O ile poczatkowo moze ten temat byc irytujacy, pozniej szybko bedziesz wynajdywac sobie drogi, ktore pomoga Ci przeskoczyc strumien ( wejscie do wody konczy sie porazeniem, wszak egzoszkielet jest pol mechaniczny i cos musi go napedzac - szkoda ze dopiero ta gra o tym pomyslala ) czy inna przeszkode. 

Gra idealna na rozluznienie sie i uspokojenie nerwow. Pasuje znakomicie. Muzyka jest kolejnym elementem ktory doskonale pasuje. Jest oczywista, skomponowana na pianinie / fortepianie ale wlasnie jej oczywistosc i uspokajajacy ton powoduje ze mozesz sie spokojnie zanurzyc w gre i czerpac z niej pelnymi garsciami. 

Graficznie takze jest przyjemnie. Gra dziala na silniku Unity. Ta nazwa powoduje u mnie odruchy odrzucenia. Nie jestem fanem Unity. Ale to nie przez fakt samego silnika. Ale przez tworcow, ktorzy opierajac gry na tym silniku, nie dodaja nic od siebie. Zupelnie nie staraja sie by z silnika cos wyciagnac. A mozna. I ta gra to pokazuje. Swiat jest zywy i realny. Brawo tworcom za pokazanie co Unity potrafi. Podczas grania nie mialem spadku klatek, a czytalem ze mozna uruchamiac gre na starszych sprzetach i grac milo. 

Moge z czystym sumieniem polecic gre. Doroslym jak i mlodszym graczom. Ma urok, ktorego dawno nie widzialem. Zachwycila mnie bardziej niz no Doom czy kilka innych WIELKICH tytulow poprzedniego roku. Szkoda ze nie mialem mozliwosci zagrania w nia w 2016. Bo na pewno trafila by na wysokie miejsce na mojej liscie gier roku.  Pomimo tego bede do gry wracal. By sie zrelaksowac. Dla czystej przyjemnosci. I to daje ta gra. Czysta przyjemnosc z grania. I chocby za to ma moja rekomendacje.

29079680.review:
This is a simple game with a goal of having fun. The game was made with the idea of playing it at a fast pace but it does reward exploration a bit, with upgrades and story notes, but the game is so short that it seems pointless. I do not believe there are many or any invisible walls, just mountains and drop offs, so you can find other ways to cut through the path sometimes. You can also explore a good bit but due to the fine tuning focusing on a faced paced playthrough the rest of the game does not lend itself well to this kind of game play.

Overall I found the game quite fun and worth the time. I'll probably play it again or a few times in the future.

28995021.review:
Valley is a game almost solely based around traversing terrain with the LEAF suit. It allows the player to run at great speeds, jump high and far. You follow the story through recordings and notes, of a woman from decades ago who was faced with the challenge of trying to save this mystical land known as the Valley from a military hell bent on using its power for a powerful weapon.

I really enjoyed the short, but sweet journey through Valley. It's a peaceful game to sit back and run through. The thrill of jumping great distances and watching the world pass by is very satisfying.

28945905.review: СВЯТЫЕ УГОДНИКИ ЭТО КРУЧЕ ЧЕМ PORTAL И ТРИАЛЬНЫЕ КАРТЫ ДЛЯ QUAKE III ПЛЮС ОХУИТЕЛЬНЫЙ АНТУРАЖ И ОХУИТЕЛЬНЫЙ САУНДТРЕК ПЛЮС ПОИСК ВСЕХ СЕКРЕТОВ ГОСПОДИ ПРИНЕСИТЕ МНЕ ЕЩЁ ЭТОЙ ХЕРНИ!

28942020.review:
GEIHEIMTIPP!

Man spielt einen Archeologen der auf der Suche nach dem legendärem Lifeseed ist. Zufälligerweise findet man wohl auch den Ort, nur weiß man letztenendes nicht wie man dort hingelangt ist und stellt auch schnell fest, das man nicht der Erste im sogenannten Valley ist. Zur Zeit des Zweiten Weltkriegs waren wohl schon US Truppen dort, welche ihre Hinterlassenschaften im Valley verstreut haben. Man stößt hierbei auf den L.E.A.F. Suit, eine Art Exoskelett oder auch mechanische 7 - Meilen Stiefel. Mit ihm sammelt man Energiekugeln auf  um den Anzug zu laden um Totes wieder lebendig zu machen oder Lebendigem seine Energie zu entziehen. Eigentlich kann man nicht sterben,wenn man in einen Abgrund fällt oder im Wasser ertrinkt,dann wird man durch die Energie des Valleys wiederbelebt. Die Sache hat nur einen Haken. Immer wenn man wiederbelebt wird, wird dem Valley Lebensenergie entzogen. Das wirkt sich auf Flora und Fauna aus. Bäume sterben und das Wild stirbt auch. Deswegen sollte man darauf achten Bäume und Wild wiederzubeleben.
Zur weiteren Story kann ich jetzt noch nicht sagen, da ich es bis jetzt nur angespielt habe, aber diese paar Minuten haben mich schon gleich mitgerissen.
Die Grafik ist sehr schön anzuschauen und auch der Soundtrack lässt die Stimmung und Atmosphäre in die Höhe schnellen. Vorallem gleich nachdem man den Suit erhalten hat macht es einfach nur Laune Hügel hinabzurennen und Wahnsinns Sprünge zu absolvieren und die Umgebung zu genießen.
Für diesen Titel könnte ich mir einen VR Support sehr gut vorstellen. Ich glaube das würde das Spielerlebnis vervierfachen.

28916647.review:
Completed this game today! Loved it. Great music and sense of speed running and jumping around and plenty of places to explore in the more open areas and things to collect - some parts did feel just a little linear but still rewarded going off and looking for the collectables, it also fit in with the story, those particular areas being that way. 

I found the story compelling as well with a good sort of beginning middle and end.

Fair warning though - you could finish this in 3 - 4 hours.. my play time was 7 hours, that included a couple of issues I had in the beginning and at least 2 hours alt + tabbed for.. reasons.. So it depends if at full price $20 or whatever it is represents a good value propasition for you to have 3 - 4 hours of decent entertainment.. 

There would be some replayability here to find more collectables and routes around the Valley - and I certainly didn't get through all the secret areas in my time with it (at time of writing)

28834859.review: "Valley" is the most beautiful game made in the Unity engine I've ever played. Though it's a bit short, it's rather replayable if you're eager to earn all the achievements and explore the maps, especially because you go quite quickly through some of them, while others are extremely complex. The storyline is very interesting and the gameplay mechanics are somewhat unique; there's plenty of narative to listen to as well as notes to find, and you can get quite a detailed story from it all. The sountrack is gorgeous, though one major flaw to this game is it's sound design - it's absolutely, 100% completely fucked. Some other more or less small glitches/bugs in gameplay may annoy you sometimes, especially when replaying maps to get all the collectibles, but otherwise, this game is a must have - I was not aware the Unity engine could producse something as graphically awesome as this, and I'm glad I found this game on Steam.

28828122.review: Fun, high quality experience that gives you a great amount of freedom.

28814323.review: 3 hours in and it's amazing! Wonderful, simple mechanics coupled with amazing story telling.

With gameplay reminiscent of Portal, and environmental storytelling like Bioshock this title is definitely worth a try. Despite not quite living up to the games it is inspired by, it is a solid first person exploration game.

The visuals are impressive for the budget of the title but the level designs are quite outstanding. Despite having detailed enviroments there are always subtle cues that show you how to progress. Levels are mostly linear and the story develops around this linearity, so I feel it would have been good to have a few open spaces to really run around and explore in.

28745995.review:
I found Valley on sale while randomly browsing through the store and thought i would give it a go.

The game is an atmospheric first person adventure game with action and light puzzle elements.
Unity engine makes the game look great and the sound design is very good as well, adding to the wonder of exploring
the valley.

The controls are solid and the life/death mechanic, and how it affects the world around you, is an interesting addition to the experience. 

The story of the game, which is the main driving point, is interesting and succeds in wanting you to learn more and takes you through different emotions along the way. 

The game is a bit on the short side though - Even with me being a "Have to explore everything" type of gamer that doesn't rush, i was able to get through the story in just under 8 hours. But having gotten the game on sale i clearly feel i got my moneys worth, and would recommend others to do the same!

If you like adventure, a sense of wonder, pretty visuals and an interesting story - Check out Valley!

28723048.review:
Game is simply underwhelming and not even worth it on sale.

It's a very basic game, there are no real challenges or consequences. I feel like it would have been a lot better if it were like Journey. This game has some aweful dialogue and it's so forced you can't disable voices in the options menu. Even though there aren't any challenges or puzzles it could have done some real visual story telling. The environments look very good, but they aren't utilized to their fullest. You could have had the whole story told through what you were walking through without a word being told to you. The game treats the player like a complete neanderthal by telling the player exactly what they must think, feel and do. It was insulting seeing these texts pop up on screen instead of just letting me feel and decide this on my own. 

The reason visual story telling would have made this game great is because the story being told was mediocre at best. It was also filled to the brim with cliche's. It's a very generic story where some evil scientist wants to make a weapon. The weapon is powered by the life in the valley, and the good guy must stop them. Another reason why the audio should have been cut out is because the characters aren't fleshed out enough to care for them or relate to. The bad guy wants to make the weapon to compete with the Manhatten Project. He does it because he's evil. The protagonist is along to document life. She see's the weapon is damaging to the environment and must stop the bad guy. It's as boring as it gets.

If you're someone who plays games for their story, reads a lot of books or watches a lot of movies. This game has nothing to offer. It's a very shallow experience that feels like the story was made up in an hour then made into a game.

Zunächst hatte mich einfach nur die Musik des Trailers eingefangen. Davon abgesehen wusste ich nicht was mich erwartet. Umso überraschter war ich, als sich vor mir nach und nach eines der spannensten Spiele, die ich je gespielt habe, entfaltete.

Valley erzählt seine Geschichte leise, unaufdringlich und ohne jeden Pathos mithilfe von Tonbandaufzeichnungen und Berichten, die wir überall in der Welt finden können. Es steckt voller Hinweise auf alte amerikanische Mythologie und wissenschaftlicher Erkenntnisse zur Quantenphysik. Erst nach und nach entfaltet die Geschichte ihre unglaubliche Dynamik. Wer Spaß hat an leise erzählten Geschichten wird hier ein Meisterwerk finden.

Auch die Musik, Grafik und das Artdesign sind bis in das letzte Detail stimmig. Und Spielspaß ? Oh, wenn wir mit ungeahnter Geschwindigkeit durch Tunnel flitzen oder Sprünge jenseits aller Vorstellung machen, dann will man einfach nur aufjauchzen. 

Einziger Wermutstropfen ist die fehlende deutsche Übersetzung. Doch mit ein bisschen Geduld und Schulenglisch kommt man insgesamt gut durch.

Ich persönlich würde mir mehr so stimmig gemachte, tiefgründige Spiele wünschen. Von meiner Seite einen dicken Daumen für Valley :)

28419031.review:
Valley is basically what happens when the Dev team who made Slender play Mirror's Edge and think to themselves, "Yeah, we could do something like that."
One of things I really liked about Slender was that the game could be really pretty- when it wasn't pitch black. The devs are really good at making beautiful landscapes and this game is their talent utilized to its fullest extent. But the gameplay should always be the forefront of the attraction and this is where Valley really shines. The first-person running and platforming is amazing and the abilities are creative and fun to use. The whole game felt like one big rollercoaster from start to finish, flinging you through the air at fantastic speeds while whimsical music is playing. It's not a difficult game in the slightest, but this isn't a game meant to give you a serious challenge (other than finding all the collectables): It's a game designed to take you on a ride and not let go until the end credits, like Half-Life or Tearaway.
If I had any complaints about the game, it would probably be level design. The [u]amazing[/u] rail section is the only time where rails are used. The ability to run on water is only used for one long segment near the end. And yet the grapple and magnetic walls are used throughout. This isn't something many people would have a problem with, it's just something I noticed. But the worst parts of the game are the shooting segments. The game throws enemies at you and expects you to stop and fight them. They're tedious and I usually ran past as many as I could, especially towards the end. And the [b]boss fight[/b]. This game should [u]not[/u] have had a boss fight. 
The story is interesting, not incredible but a good complement to the rest of the ride. I did appreciate how they tried to make the areas feel lived in, though. And the game letting you find out about what happened to the characters before it tells you about their fate was a great touch of storytelling. The game is kind of short, I beat it in one three-hour sitting. That being said, I don't think my complaints detract from the game enough for me to not recommend it to you.
I don't think this game will make any top 10 lists of 2016, but I do think it will be a shining star on the big list of good games of this year. Nicely done, Blue Isle. Can't wait to see what you'll do next.

28379645.review:
I'm almost 15 hours in and I'm finally about ready to be done... I'm at 28 of 30 achievements and may push on a bit longer just to get the last two but perhaps not.... I'm not normally into achievements.

I had a lot of fun exploring the world of Valley. It's a difficult game to describe but essentially it's a gorgeous walking simulator with an action game mech suit thrown into it. The primary focus of play is exploration and even though there are some FPS  and platforming elements thrown in, if you approach it as a shooter or as a platformer, you will find it is too easy and disappointing.

[b]Exploration and discovery are the core motivators and if you don't enjoy that then you probably won't like this game.[/b]

There's a tiny bit of Metroidvania influence in that some abilities gained later in the game can be used in areas encountered earlier in the game, but it is very minimal. I would call Valley a really good game but if they had doubled down on that Metroidvania angle and given you a compelling reason to keep returning to early areas.... it would have been a [b]great[/b] game.

Despite that, highly recommended if you like to explore beautiful environs and uncover secrets. There are zero physically encounterable npc's in the game and the narrative is delivered through notes and audio logs so prepare to be alone and enchanted by the mystery of the Valley.

28301405.review:
You find a suit. It lets you go fast. And it feels amazing, going fast.

You go faster running downhill than uphill. In a sense, I guess it's kind of like that old mobile game, Tiny Wings.

You have several abilities at your disposable, and every ability had its use, although I thought one of them, the last ability you got, wasn't used much, simply because since it was the last ability, there was less playtime with it compared to the previous abilities.

And yes, there is what you could call, combat. But the combat is not as much about defeating enemies as it is getting obstacles out of your way.

So what's playing this game like? Amazing. You're running through the valley at breakneck speeds. Or, you're swinging through a tall forest, with the next platform miles below you. Sometimes you're not moving as fast. Maybe you're exploring, looking for collectibles, maybe you need to fill up your energy.

The path is straightforward. Whether that's a plus or a fault is your interpretation. Moving around is the exhilirating part. There are some REALLY good movement parts in this game - look forward to those.

Buy this? Yes. But know that this is intense in adventure, not as much in action.

28300563.review:
Overview: Vally is pretty straight forward, you're dropped headfirst (probably literally...at least somewhat literally) into a vally and you just move on from there. At first there isn't too much of a story, you came here looking for a thing and you're gonna find that thing if it kills you, probably at least once (but then again not really.) After the story really ramps up, it just keeps getting more tense and adding more reason for you to see your journey through to the end and the finale certainly gives you a great payoff and sense of accomplisment.

Graphics: Certainly one of the prettier games you can get and I ran everything maxed on a buget build PC so I doubt anyone will have much trouble running it (although there were some rare moments of slowdows.) The FX are wonderful throughout and the artwork and landscapes are fantastical while still remaining grounded in reality, you really feel like you're just running through an exceptionally senic location. 

Gameplay: Its a mix of somewhat slower parkour with a few key parts that will really get your heart racing, a sort of FPS style battle but they generally pass quickly(this is all about discovery after all.) The movement of the L.E.A.F. suit felt very realistic for me and you can almost feel the impact whenever you land. It could get boring overtime but for this games shorter runtime, I think its perfect. Along the way you'll get multiple additions to your L.E.A.F. suit all adding new and interesting abilities to use HOWEVER I must deduct a few points in this section. Each addition you get, although fun and well thought out is left solely to certain sections(one upgrade of the suit is used only for one section of the whole game), I understand that could be a minor gripe but I just feel like given the world you're allowed to explore that there should be more creative ways to use these peices of technology such as along natural structures rather than the designated areas you are given.

Runtime: I'd like to think I'm in majority in that I played through not nessercarily searching every single nook and cranny but also exploring anywhere I thought look fun so I guess the average playtime for your average person is going to be between 4-5 hours so take that into account when you buy. That said if you really want there are a few things left to discover hidden around although from what I personally saw there really weren't too many things hidden from sight. 

Closing: Vally is certainly a unique game and I'll get this out of the way now, its one I might play again in passing but not something I particularly think I'll ever return to so if you're looking for replayability, this may not be your game that said the single playthrough experience was plenty and I quite enjoyed it.

Because of the short run time, I'd suggest you try and play through the full thing in one sitting, the story certainly lends itself to a more full experience like that. I'd recommend the game for most people to at least try but just keep in mind you're paying more for what I'd call an experience rather than the average game.

28273412.review:
Fameux archéologiste un peu idéaliste, vous êtes à la recherche d'un soi-disant artefact miraculeux.
Aussitôt tourné risible par votre ami qui n'y croit pas une seule seconde, ce dernier vous invite plutôt à faire du kanoë.

Un peu hésitant, vous vous accordez le bénéfice du doute, et partez à cette randonnée, qui vous emmenera droit dans la gueule du loup.
Un camion militaire, des enregistrements anciens, une vallée abandonnée comme l'Eden?Qu'est-ce-que cela signifie?

Ni une ni deux, vous ouvrez la première caisse devant vous, et vous voilà tout-puissant.
Basé sur une technologie quantique encore non découverte de nos jours, l'exosquelette que vous trouverez sera votre seconde peau, si ce n'est la seule finalement.

Pendulum et ses savants inspirés ont pondu l'arme ultime, l'arme de l'amour et l'arme de la mort à la fois.
Badinant avec les entités environnantes, vous remarquerez assez vite que cette vallée est habitée, et ce sera votre rôle de propager l'absolution.

Cours plus vite que le vent, vise cet arbre ami et frère de millénaires, abreuve de vie ce daim inerte, et surtout, maîtrise-toi.
Un chef d'oeuvre.

绝对值得买的游戏！！！
因为很重要所以要说三遍。
看别人的评测大都和我一样是3到4个小时通关这款游戏的。根据贴吧12小时差不多可以做到全收集。剧情方面有一定的深度，好在游戏世界开放有大量的时间给玩家来思考游戏深层的含义。
——————————————————————————————————————————————
因为有大佬已经很好地评测了这款游戏我也就不加赘述。
就先说说游戏的不足：
1.游戏的流程较短。
2.游戏的前几个场景在室外，风景甚是优美。但随后的几乎所有关卡都在昏暗的室内或是夜晚，让人感到些许压抑。此后几乎再也看不到室外美丽的风景，确实是不小的遗憾。
3.刚开始的时候我原以为游戏会有大量的解密元素，其实不然。解密玩家不要对解密元素吧抱太大期望。
4.游戏以疯狂的奔跑、跳跃等操作为主，跑起来确实爽快，但跑多了确实有些累人，有种在玩神庙逃亡，已经打了很久了不想打了，但为了分数还在死命跑的感觉。（好在累了还有些风景看。）
再说说优点：
1.游戏的音乐，特别是室外关卡纯跑路的时候的音乐，绝赞！所以原声碟一定要买！买买买！
2.游戏的风景。排除一些小细节，室外关卡的风景真的是美的无法用言语来描述，通过截图也是可以感受得到的。而且这些风景再怎么看都还嫌不够多。
3.游戏的操作性很好。动作与动作之间的衔接都处理的非常不错，不会有任何生硬的感觉。
——————————————————————————————————————————————
个人感想（轻度剧透）
游戏的主题：保护环境。
游戏中的LEAF外骨骼拥有吸取和释放生命力的能力，而我们的主角的生命值的回复靠的就是将环境中散落的生命力收集起来然后将生命力不足的植物或死去的动物复苏来达成的。
而LEAF外骨骼制造的初衷却是作为战争的工具，在一关的读取界面里能够看到一个工厂，一边生命力进去，另一边核弹出来。
游戏中期也能到达一个满是坑的，当时人们测试炸弹的地方。
到游戏的结尾，主角成功地破坏了工厂，自己也成功地逃脱。最后主角趴在木板上漂在小溪里，旁边是已经脱下地LEAF外骨骼。我们的主角毫不犹豫地将这样一件战争道具推下了木板，不希望再有人得到它。
整的游戏可以说是警醒世人，我们从自然中拿走了多少，自然就会要我们还多少。
同时也对世界永远和平地一种祈愿。
评分：10/10 
PS：谁能告诉我松果是干嘛的？

28131544.review:
Valley is a first person adventure from the makers of Slender: The Arrival. This was a blind purchase for me! Did it deliver on the devs' claim on being an adventure unlike any other or did it fail? Read on.

Story - Not much is known about our protagonist other than the fact that he or she, is an archaeologist. What is known is that he or she is after a Life-seed, an ancient relic with amazing properties.  

Graphics/Presentation/Sound - From the first minute of controlling your protagonist, you have a small hint of how beautiful the visuals will be. It's not the greatest graphics ever seen, but it isn't remotely bad either. Walk further along and one will get to see just how beautiful Valley truly is. The environment, some of the life that inhabits it, and colors are nicely done. Add the chirping and other sounds of nearby creatures, combined with breathtaking views when in flight (more on that later), you feel like you want to take a vacation here, never to return home. I have to admit, I have stopped to admire the visuals and sounds a couple times while playing. The music fits perfectly with the environment, and speeds up the tempo when danger is near. 

Gameplay - You manage to find an exoskeleton suit called L.E.A.F. With it equipped, you have the agility and speed to cover a lot of area that would deem impossible for a regular man or woman. With your momentum, you dash on some land and leap off ramps to feel the breeze as you glide in the air. The suit also gives a god like ability to restore life, as well as take it away. See a dead lifeless thing, bring it back to life with some color. Want to take the energy away from said thing, do so and it becomes lifeless and dull again. Such power isn't unlimited as there's a meter that measures how much energy you will have. Run low on energy and you are powerless. Fortunately, you can look for energy orbs that are scattered throughout the world. There are enemies abound in this world. They will try to halt your progress to the life-seed. With your energy shooting abilities, you can dispatch them quickly and collect any loot that is dropped. As you travel in this world, you find upgrades for your suit to help you advance further. The game does an excellent job in making all of your abilities useful in some way. The excellent level design supports this in that you get to use most of your upgrades to advance and feel cool doing so. 

Pros - The controls are excellent. When a game has outstanding responsive controls, it helps make the experience that much more enjoyable. As already mentioned, impressive visuals and sound makes the world come alive. The level designs are really varied and unique to your newfound abilities. Puzzles are not too difficult or frustrating to figure out. Useful upgrades work well to help you in your journey. This gives the game a sense of balance often missing in most other titles. The pacing is very good. From the characters you encounter, the voice acting is done well.

Cons - As beautiful as the world of Valley is, there are some cons. Lack of wildlife. Valley doesn't have as much wildlife as I thought it should. For such a big world with mountains, plush landscapes and terrain, and sea, I would have liked to have seen more in it. This is a minor con as it didn't take too much away from my immersion. Another gripe I had was that the enemies seemed fairly easy to dispatch. There's no difficulty settings to adjust from what I noticed. Anyone looking for a challenging encounter may feel like they want more.

Conclusion - I purchased Valley on sale (Cyber Monday), not knowing what to expect. The asking price however, is not unreasonable. You can finish the game in about 5 hours. The replay value is definitely there as you can speed run through if you wish to start over. Overall, with what Valley has going for it, the beautiful atmosphere, nice audio, unique level designs, excellent controls, and god like ability to take or give life, Valley is as the developers have stated, it's a game unlike any other!
