28069031.review:
By no means a bad game, Valley has plenty of good ideas, some of them very well implemented, but these, sadly, do not take the form of a cohesive whole. 

The L.E.A.F. suit is the game's main mechanic and selling point. It is fun to use and you will acquire upgrades as the story unfolds, however, the level design, no matter how polished, restricts many abilities to self-contained areas. For example, one of the upgrades to your suit gives you the ability to run fast through certain marked tracks, but it comes too late into the game (which not only feels but actually is very short) and seems detached from the rest of the levels. Same with your magnetic ability. Why are "these set pieces here and not in other places in the valley?" is a question that you'll raise several times. Contrast this to the Portal gun in both 1 & 2, which is perhaps the only gimmick in your repertoire, and the games give you a great variety of uses with its environment even though you possess just one ability. Or, if not, try a comparison to Metroidvania-style games where each new ability gives you new opportunities to explore those games' worlds, designed around that very fact. Valley is not like that.

The story unfolds through audiologs, which is becoming quite a tiresome way of telling a story these days, but unlike Bioshock, you will not collect them (where you could very well miss some of them and still understand the backstory of those games) so much as be guided to them and somewhat forced to listen to them right there on the spot. The story leaves much to be desired, as it is very conventional and your silent protagonist dujour takes it all in and accepts it at face value, and for all we know he is just some random explorer who might as well be called "Player: Your Name". As for characters, there are none besides those mentioned in the logs. The premise that the environment itself can take the shape of a character is nice, but it's lacking and despite being titled Valley, you will spend half the game in decadent industrial settings. You will encounter many of the creatures called 'daemons' along the way, but you won't form a bond with them, even though they become central to the storyline right when the adventure comes to an abrupt ending, which is detrimental to your enjoyment of this "wildlife" you'll encounter through most of the game but won't have a clue as to what they really add to the experience until its too late.

Somewhere in Valley there is a very good to even great game, but its flaws are hard to overlook. Despite great environmental design, quality voice acting, superb audio, and the amazing potential in the L.E.A.F. suit, it simply doesn't come together in the end despite the promise of a unique gaming platform.

Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed my time in the game, warts and all, and kudos to the Dev team, but I feel compelled to add a contrast to the mostly positive reviews the game has gotten since those warts can very well be deal breakers for other players looking for a different kind of game. Valley has the potential, but it's not quite there yet.

This game thoroughly surprised me. I had no expectations going in, and it would have blown them away even if I did. Everything is very well polished: to the visuals, movement, interface, "feel". Nearly everything about the game is satisfying, it would have been nice to know what happens to the protagonist in the end, which is my only gripe. Or perhaps... It's being set up for a sequel (I really hope so)?

So in short, it's a part platformer, part shooter, part "walking simulator" with some RPG elements (key word being "elements") as you collect items to open up certain areas and finding upgrades for your "LEAF" suit which acts as the mobility device throughout the game, as well as finding notes scattered throughout the game that give further exposition. The music is GREAT with some really memorable moments created by it working in conjuction with the gameplay. The life/death mechanic is also very inventive, and like the rest of the game, is satisfying to use.

Satisfying. Entertaining. Worth a buy definitely.

26727268.review:
It's been a very long time since I had a blind buy blow me away.

[I]Valley[/I] exceeds all of its goals. The game is gorgeous with a fantastic soundtrack, but the gameplay is the real kicker.

I like games where you move fast, and if there's anything that [I]Valley[/I] nails it's the sense of speed you can get. The sound design, visual changes, and especially animation all blend together to form something exhilarating. This game has a huge potentional for speedruns and though it lacks a level timer, there are numerous tricks you can pull off with the mechanics to create shortcuts through levels and generally move even faster than the developers intended. While [I]Valley[/I] certainly isn't an open-world game, the mechanics involved let you make your own playground. Equipment you get later in the game can also be used in earlier levels, both in developer-implemented secrets and with your own ingenuity. Now, this isn't to say that this game is difficult. In actuality it's incredibly easy; the few enemies that are involved move little and your health pool is easily replenished from sources in the environment, but as said earlier there are a variety of tricks and techniques you can pull off that require somewhat larger-than-average understanding of the game.

The story is simple and sweet, with enviromentalist tones and a decently enough developed romance wrapped throughout. If there's one criticism I have it's the game was too short, primarily due to the introduction of elements and questions from the narrative that were never addressed. Much of the narrative is handled through notes, with only two characters providing narration, but what voice acting is there is done well and can be heard repeatedly without annoyance.

[I]Valley[/I] is a game that I'd wholeheartedly reccommend to anyone.

26551514.review:
Play if you're looking for: a game with a lot of running, jumping, and movement based puzzles.  Interesting story given to you through narration, delivered well.  Play if you like collecting all the little widgets.
Don't play if you're looking for: A first person shooter or complex puzzler.  Both elements are present, but they are by no means the focus of the game.

Valley is a game about the joy of moving fast and looking at pretty scenery, and it does very well in both respects.  It's rare to find a first person game that does movement and jumping puzzles well, and a lot of effort obviously went in to making it work.  It's more than just moving in the right direction and hitting the jump button at the right time: you pick up momentum by sprinting a distance, more momentum by going downhill (less uphill), and the direction of momentum when you leave ground plays a big role in where you'll go and how far.  Later mobility upgrades (such as double jumping, grappling hook, and other cooler upgrades I won't mention) increase the variety of puzzles, how you can approach them, and greatly extend those movements of blissful, sprinting through the wilderness joy.  The game encourages speed too: between the shape of the valley ahead, the energetic music that just started, and the wild deer running alongside you can't help but be pulled along.

Scenery and setting are done very well.  The scenery is a joy to explore and look at, from the close up to the distant skyboxes, and there were a lot of moments I stopped to stare (or moved to a better vantage point and did it there).  Indoor areas feel immensely large but that way do not interfere with movement and gameplay (more cramped areas would be difficult to navigate and break that feeling of freedom of movement).  A lot of games look good, though, what makes this one special?  The little ways that it presents you with this beauty: coming out in to the valley for the first time with the sun shining through the trees as the cave slowly opens up in front of you, hearing a door mechanism screech a few seconds before it opens, having your eye drawn to something important or impressive by a glimmer of light from a wandering sprite or the sun's reflection or a flashing emergency light; it's all perfectly designed to get you to look there.  And on that note, it's hard to get lost: there's usually something fairly unintrusive such as fireflies, lights, even the slope of the valley or shape of a peak that draws your eyes (sometimes without you realizing it) and says "go here to advance level."

The game isn't perfect: it's a game about movement, but sometimes you're forced to stop and at that point it gets frustrating.  I want to run, you told me I could run!  Generally, narration is well timed, but occasionally it will pop up at a wrong momement and I would stop to listen because I didn't want to miss part of it or potentially interrupt it with another narration cue.  The game features collectibles, some of them scattered during joyous runs through valleys or underground pipes, and interrupting that to go poking in corners brings the game to a screeching halt.  You can go back to any previous level fairly easily to collect more things (in fact, you have to for some as they require later game upgrades), which is good, but there was little encouragement to me to do so which meant I got them the first time or not at all.  Occasionally, the overly large areas also get in the way of play: pretty to look at, but when you're still hiking around that giant mound two minutes later to see if there's a box or secret room hidden behind it that kind of sucks.

Overall, a very enjoyable experience.  Play to go fast, and enjoy how the game encourages this.

26379041.review:
Both straightforward and simple in practice, but that's not a bad thing.

The story is, while not the deepest, still quite interesting and engaging. A tale is weaved of an abandoned WWII research facility and it's patrons, a results driven overseer, a group of elite soldiers known as the Pathfinders, and an archeaologist discovering secrets of the namesake Valley and a mysterious Lifeseed. You yourself, an archaeologist whom after a canoeing accident, finds yourself wandering this same valley, once stumbling upon the LEAF suit the Pathfinders had used, find yourself unraveling the mysteries buried within the Valley. The narrative of the base in its prime is told through audio logs and notes littered about the environments, from multiple points of view, all the while leaving the character just as intrigued as the player. While it starts off slowly, it becomes a rather compelling tale as time progresses.

The audio design is excellent. An orchestral soundtrack with a variety of themes, all fitting to the current situation you find yourself in. From slow, sweeping ambient backdrops to heart pumping banging overtures, everything is encapsulated very well in the sound design. The sound effects as well, from ambient noise to the sounds of the power suit, the archaic machinery springing to life, all of it is crafted excellently and unobtrusively. The voice acting, while not incredible, is still above average.

Visually, the game is stunning. Vivid details in the surrounding area, excellent shaders and lighting effects contribute greatly to the aesthetic and charm of the game. The variety comes in between areas, with large open natural maps, to dilapidated military installations, to dark underground bunkers and caves. However, two of my major complaints come in the graphical department. One, the distant LOD textures leave a lot to be desired, especially in a game where many areas are so open you'll constantly be observing them. Secondly, while I understand the darkness in certain areas is there with good reason, many feel slightly too dark, leading to many a circle ran trying to find out where to go. Thankfully, with the latter, the brightness can be adjusted up in the menu if you don't mind a slight gray haze to everything.

The gameplay, as was said before, is simple. Once obtaining your LEAF suit, you're able to give and take energy from surrounding flora and fauna in order to progress, and throughout the experience, many upgrades will be found, allowing you to grapple, double jump, as well as increase your energy reserves. Taking energy from the environment however, is not without cost. Take too much, and the Valley's life meter diminishes, the same as if you miss jump and fall to your death. Let it fall too far, and on your next death, the Valley dies. Unfortunately, as the game is very forgiving and all in all, very low on the difficulty scale, the implications never feel too dire, as I'm sure they were intended to be. There are a multitude of secrets hidden in each map, between doors unlocked with golden acorns received from giving life back to the Valley, the plethora of lore notes and audio logs, and collectible medallions used to unlock an ancient ruin, some of which are gated behind later upgrades, you'll find yourself exploring each map time again. And though the game itself is relatively linear in where to go, there will be a few instances of having to evaluate your surroundings and the potential of getting lost, as there's very little in the way of signposting your direction beyond the occasional quest marker.

There is a combat portion in the game as well, though it isn't particularly complex or difficult either. Enemies will fire projectiles that sap your energy reserves until they are pacified by being hit with energy themselves. In many cases, combat isn't even required as if you have an idea where to go, the projectiles move slowly enough they can be avoided as you travel.

In conclusion, Valley is a game that didn't try anything esoteric or outrageous, but instead opted to provide a simple, but incredibly polished experience. It is an unfortunately short game, and the lack of difficulty can sometimes detract from the experience, but as a whole product, is well worth the time.

Story: 8/10
Visuals: 8/10
Audio: 10/10
Gameplay: 8/10

Overall: 8.5/10

26226128.review:
I have now played all the way through the game and I really enjoyed this experience.  Its feels more like a puzzle platformer (think portal) but there happens to be shooting as well.  Although, the shooting feels very peaceful.  I would even say, there is a bit of 'walking simulator' in this game too.  But that's a big caveat, the walking/running/jumping is WAY WAY WAY better than any walking simulator that I have played so far.  Primarily b/c jumping/running/grappling are so damn fun!

Oh, did I mention there is a grappling hook!  The grappling hook isn't free form though (which is a bit of a bummer) and requires specific mount points to use.  I'm ok with that though as I am guessing the game would be too easy if you could grapple anywhere.  

When I started playing this game, I got the same feeling I did when playing the original portal (not portal 2, as I don't know why but portal 2 just wasn't as engaging for me as portal).  Maybe its the landscape, maybe its the great sound track, maybe its the unique little creatures, maybe its the elf like unity with the environment.  I don't know, but this game has the magic for me.

Onto the performance.  Its not great but is still playable.  I get between 30 to 60 fps on my NVidia GTX 960 + Core i7-4770 3.4GHz + 16GB Ram runnong on Ubuntu 14.04 LTS.  It also has that unity Setting screen before the game.  I don't know why b/c their in-game settings seem pretty decent.  It seems the developer would know how to turn off those settings since the game overall feels fairly polished (sans the frame drops).  I also experienced 1 game crash at the beginning of the game which made me go through the first section again (at least I had my suit so it was easy to repeat that first walk plus I took a slightly different route)  

Overall, I would highly recommend this title.

26160838.review:
POSSIBLE MILD SPOILERS BELOW

Ok so: Valley. An uncut gem of a game whose devs need a second shot and a ton more money.

GRAPHICS

Not bad. Good optimization. A very efficient use of polys, some great water effects, and kudos for showing a ton of grass/particles at a respectable distance without mutilating the performance (played on a GTX 960). It's not jaw-dropping but it more than does it's job. I've seen far worse FPS on graphics that were perhaps only slightly better.
Enviromentally, the game is really pretty to look at, both when you're leaping across hills or exploring abandoned structures. There is much love evident in the crafting, as also shown by the beautiful concept art you see in the ending credits. Made me think of Elysium when i played Sacrifice, long ago not so very long ago.

SOUND

Major point of strenght. The ST is very suggestive and also often dynamic. Pan-flute galore. There's perhaps a couple moments of annoyance where the game expects you to just run like crazy but you feel more like slowly exploring and poking around, yet have to deal with frantic rythms. That's hardly a flaw, though. Nothing bad to say about sound fx, either. Character voices are also good.

PLOT

Nicely executed, but rock-bottom unoriginal and predictable. It has an enjoyable feel-good vibe (if you're into talks of nature and balance and preservation and mysticism and life vs tech etc., like me, otherwise it could just register as "hippy bullcrap") and some moments of genuine drama and tension, but it will hardly surprise you. 
There are many entries from well-voiced characters and lots of docs to read, if you're into it. Major kudos for having chosen a system where the various docs' and diaries' text is just shown in mid-air when you mouse over them, without having to open each one. There is no journal to keep all those entries (not that i could find) but this way the whole thing is appropriately uninvasive for a game whose primary point is mobility.

Just one thing i wish to say directly to the developers: there is a secret base in your game and you call it SOMA? Are you fucking serious? I hope that's some sort of knowing homage.


GAMEPLAY

Heh. This is where i find the game is at it's weakest. From the jumping puzzles to the combat, the challenge is absolute zero, unless you're really new to FPS. It all feels like a formality you have to go through to get to the next plot point (a plot that, as already said, is seldom rewarding). Unless you refuse to open the average loot crates and upgrade your suit's energy for some reason (the mobility upgrades are mandatory) soon enough you're virtually a god no enemy can threaten unless you really let them. 
And when you die... you actually don't: each death (you'll die mostly by slightly touching water) immediately respawns you and reduces "valley health" which you can quickly replenish by shooting lifeforce from your suit (more on that later) into dead things, like withered plants or animal corpses. And the game's enviroment does a great job in keeping you absolutely STUFFED with dat shit. I never once ran out of valley health and died for real, earning the achievement "immortality", which really didn't feel like one.
It is, however, a more elegant system than merely having you die and reload the last checkpoint. Kudos to every game that incorporates the dynamics of death and rebirth within it's own story mechanics.

Exploration? Zero. Which is perhaps this game's greatest shame. When i first heard of this game i thought it would've been set in a sandbox, and that would've been awesome. Instead you're pretty much railroaded everywhere, without even a faint illusion of true freedom. You can free-roam after you've beaten the story and find secret rooms/ledges using the fullness of your suit powers, but that's pretty much it. 

Now then: Suit powers. Your suit is this exoskeleton that basically turns you into Roadrunner. You can go crazy fast and jump crazy far when running downhill, you get a grappling hook, you can walk upside-down on magnetized surfaces, land from any heigth and even skip across water if you approach it at a low angle (but still, be extremely careful around the damn thing). Insane, right? Yet, given the railroading nature of the game, you really won't enjoy these abilities fully unless the game decides it's time. You really aren't that fast without a hill to run down from. IMAGINE how great this system would've been in a Far-Cry like sandbox, or in The Forest (punching one of those cannibal assholes in the face while coming at him at 100 kmh? Pure candy).
There are some truly exhilarating running sessions: but what is a point of strenght also gets across the point of weakness. You run like hell because there's pretty much nothing else you can do. The environment in that moment is shaped to allow you to run like hell, and in no other point of the game you can equally run like hell because you chose to.

Now, on to more underused powers: your suit can both give and take lifeforce freely (WTF), in the form of this blue energy called "Amrita" (the water of ethernal life in hinduism. Nice to see the devs chose to come up with a name that makes sense and not something made-up and/or cheesy) which opens to some truly sick possibilities, yet the game's exploitation of them is skin-deep. You basically pac-man these light balls that are almost everywhere and charge your suit, then using either left or right mouse you can give lifeforce (which is also your one and only weapon against enemies) or take it, either from trees or wildlife. Such energy also acts as your health during combat, but by the time you meet enemies that can actually put a dent in it, you'll have unlocked reserves too massive to worry. 
The game gives the Treehugger achievement for mending enough trees, and i guess it'll also give one if you play Gul'dan and drain the fuck out of X things, but there is no karma/morality system in the game to punish or reward either behaviour.

Bottom line: not terrible, really. I played far worse for far more. Such a shame to see big ideas and love crammed in a vessel so tight because of mere lack of means. The guys that made this game should be plucked from wherever the hell they are now and dropped in a major company's computer room, given all the toys and funds so that Valley 2 is a proper soil for their very good ideas to grow. A huge triple A sandbox version of this game needs to happen.

26002487.review: I just finished Valley, clocking in at 7 hours and 51 minutes.The game itself is probably much shorter than this, but I thoroughly enjoyed looking around and taking my time exploring the stunningly gorgeous Valley. If you're looking for a FPS or RPG, this isn't it. If you're even looking for a game with a deep story, this isn't really it. But I have several reasons why I enjoyed this game so much. The game is just BEAUTIFUL. The sun rays peeking through the trees, the golden hues of sunset, the fall colored leaves and trees, the aurora borealis at night, the shimmering waterfalls, etc. Add to the scenery beautiful, serene music and this game is almost relaxing! Also, I found the game metaphorically beautiful as well. I can't even explain the warm, fuzzy feelings I got being able to breathe life back into a dead, broken tree or a fallen deer... you use the "amrita" energy and suddenly the dead trees are lush and full of splendor, and the deer stands up and gracefully bounds away. I mean, if you wore a suit capable of giving dead things life, wouldn't you use it? I know I would. The small amount of voice acting there was in the game was good, and I enjoyed searching for notes and supply boxes as I continued the story. Also, the key mapping for PC gameplay was very comfortable to me. WASD to walk, space to jump, left mouse button to give life, right mouse button to take it away. All in all, this game is not perfect, but it was a fun and enjoyable little escape from reality for me. Well done, Valley!!

The main issue I have with the game is that the story sucks.  I haven't finished it, mind you, but I don't want to because I don't care.  I won't give any spoilers but the story is generic as hell, and barely qualifies as a story, as there really aren't any characters, and the ones that exist (mind you, you only hear them through audiologs) are not rich, interesting characters, but mere nararrtors spewing out information about the land you are in.  There is no character development, no real struggles, just some audiologs about the weird place you are in, and a ton of notes that really don't serve the game well.  For example, notes between scientists telling each other to stop stealing the other's coffee or pens...

This game seems to want to be Bioshock very badly, but doesn't have combat, an upgrade system, or real characters, so you are left with a pretty world, a shitty story and audiologs.

The people harping about how fun the movement is blow my mind, as it's adequate but not something I give a shit about.  Playing a game like Prototype has 10x the satisfaction of movement. 25990197.review:
Just finished the game, relitivley short for only 4 hours of playtime but I'll get into the basics of the gameplay and touch a bit on the story as to not spoil it. 

Lets start off a bit with the pros and cons (like almost every steam review)

-Pros-
1. AMAZING soundtrack. Really beautiful and lots of great music to listen to (the railways was my favorite moment of all with the music sync to gameplay)
2. Many moments in game where you feel like you're running very fast and it is quite thrilling
3. Very nice graphics for an indie game
4. Great voice acting and level design
5. Tutorial sections when you get upgrades to your suit feel natural and the game keeps flowing which is nice.
6. Game runs really well, never crashed, no hitching, no fps drops.
7. Overall a very peaceful experience at times and thrilling at others.

-Cons-
1. Like I mentioned, the game is short, only ~4 hours but I tried to explore as much as I could whilst I played. So if you really speed run it, it might be more like 3. Based on this I'd say wait for a sale.
2. The screenshots look like you always get to go fast like sanic whenever you want but many moments go from running at incredible speeds to a sudden screeching halt where it's just normally paced which can be annoying after such intense high speeds.
3. I found that some levels I explored too much and found that after doing some running and jumping over hills I ended up back at the beginning where I started. (luckily I Skyrim jumped my way back over) But this made me painfulyl aware of how "on a rail" this game is. Some points are open and some are really condensed with only one way to go.
4. The story is told through audio logs and letters with story elements around the levels which I really don't care for as a means of storytelling
5. Enemies really pose no threat, even the main boss of the game was really easy and the fight was over before I even knew it.
6. Story is really generic, seen it a dozen times before

As far as the story goes it's nothing special. You're an archeologist that goes to find the "lifeseed" and in turn track it down to this valley, when you get there you find men and women were there during WW1 (or 2?) and were performing experiments in the valley, you go on a journey to find the lifeseed and find out what they were doing there.

Overall the game isn't really "Bad" per say, just short and not really challenging. I'd say it is a fun and relaxing game to play but a sale when you buy it is a good idea. 

I'd give it a 7.5/10 for the gameplay
A 5/10 for the story, something new to the genreral idea but nothing we aint seen before
10/10 on the soundtrack, I bought the game and started playing and wanted to go back and buy it right away.

25975147.review:
Valley is a first person platformer. While looking for the Lifeseed, said to be powerful enough to shatter the Earth, you come across an old military crate. Inside is a L.E.A.F suit, which lets you run fast, leap high, and give/take life from the world around you. [spoiler]Upgrades include the ability to run on water, along magnetic walls, a double jump, and increased top speed.[/spoiler]

The gameplay is actually kinda like a simplified Metroid Prime. Technically, you go from point A to B through the adventure, but you can go back to early stages to look for collectibles at any point. The game does introduce enemies pretty early on (and one of the screenshots does show this) but combat is never the focus of the game, the platforming is. [strike]Also worth mentioning: The game does NOT track your collectible progress, so trying to find the last ones for 100% completion can be quite tedious without a video walkthrough.[/strike]

My opinion: This one surprised me quite a bit. What initially starts out as just a platformer does take on different forms of gameplay as you go, with the rail sections being the most memorable, but overall it's a very solid adventure with some interesting gameplay to keep you engaged. [strike]Just don't expect a fun post-game (after the approx. 5 hr. story) unless progress for it is patched in later.[/strike] [b]EDIT: The devs added collectible tracking when you go to the level select, so ignore the crossed out parts.[/b]

[b]Recommendation:[/b] As someone that has played some of the Sonic the Hedgehog games (which this has been compared to), this is the best first person equivalent yet. The ride the game takes you on is quite short, but that ride is fast & fun. Highly recommended.

As someone who really can't get into most survival horror, and especially hated the effects of slender on the internet, I almost dismissed this game outright based on its developers. After watching 4 minutes of Jim Sterling's video on it, though, I soon came around to wanting it. Though by the time I bought it, on sale for $14, I had forgotten what about the game made it so interesting to me.

When I opened it up I was expecting a bog standard walking simulator, minus the needed plot. After a few minutes, I found the game's L.E.A.F. suit and soon remembered what made the game great. Valley isn't a walking simulator, but a running one, one where one must travel between points quickly by managing and balancing their inertia. One might compare it to Sonic the Hedgehog but I think a more apt comparison is the Marble Blast games.

Unlike those however, Valley is beautiful. You will need a monster of a card to run it, I have a 660 and I was barely getting 60 fps at 1080p on low on the later levels (albeit at a very high fov since I am super prone to montion sickness). I think a 960/Rx 480 is nessisary for getting 60 fps on ultra, though. It's definitely not Ark bad though, and the game looks good enough to make up for it in my opinion.

The music design is excellent, mostly. It tries to match the mood of you or your character as you traverse the valley. There is one level where this is pulled off perfectly with it matching the tension and happiness of your character as he or she speeds down a railway. There were several sections where I missed the trigger to play the next song and was left with a few minutes of silence.

This happened because I spent a significant amount of time looking around for collectables and upgrades. If you do this you will both mess with the pasing of the game, and its scripting. For this reason I highly recommend just avoiding going out of your way as much as you can. To do this will require significantly more skill, since you won't have as many energy pickups, but will lead to a more satasfying experience overall, I think.

25927951.review:
Valley will mehr sein als es ist. 
Ich bin recht unbefangen in das Spiel hineingekommen und es machte die ersten 10 Minuten einen passablen Eindruck. Grafik ganz gut und der Sound angenehm.

Kurze Vorinformation: Das ist die erste negative Kritik, die ich verfasse. 
Und ich habe mich lange gescheut diese zu schreiben, doch jetzt bekommt ihr eine volle Breitseite meiner Ansichten!
Sorry wenn dieser Text unnötig lang wird (wird er).

Es hat Potential, das es nicht ausnutz und Spielmechaniken, die man meiner Meinung nach anders einbringen hätte können.
Es könnte mehr sein, will es auch, ist es aber nicht.
Die Story ist meiner Meinung nach fast zu vernachlässigen und sehr Klischeebehaftet (dazu später mehr).

Es wird geworben mit einer lebendigen Welt, in der man Leben manipulieren kann und der eigene Tod das Verderben des Tals sein kann. Soweit stimmt das.
Das Tal hat 10 "Lebensblätter". Stirbt man verliert der Ast mit den Blättern zwei Blätter, die durch wiederbeleben der Natur wieder hergestellt werden können. Und hier haben wir schon einen große Lücke: Es stehen überall tote Bäume rum und es scheint das Tal nicht zu kümmern. Erst wenn man stirbt und diese wiederbelebt tritt der vermeintliche "Untergang des Tals" in Kraft und es verliert Blätter.
Andererseits kann man vorher 10000 Bäume wiederbeleben und trotzdem wird das Tal 20% Leben bei deinem Tod verlieren. Diese Mechanik ist entweder schlecht durchdacht oder soll einfach nur irgendeine Art von Challenge reinbringne. Meiner Meinung nach ziemlich schlecht umgesetzt und auch nicht glaubwürdig der Welt gegenüber.
Um überhaupt Leben zu manipulieren braucht man Orbs, die sich überall auf der Map befinden und scheinbar nach spawnen (Story erklärt später warum). Das heißt ein wirkliches Energieproblem hat man nie, und selbst wenn einem die Energie mal ausgehen sollte, kann man Tieren und Bäumen Leben entziehen auf Kosten des Tals.
In diesem Fall greift wieder: 
-Du entziehst 10 Bäumen Leben und das Tal stirbt fast, obwohl du vorher deutlich mehr Bäumen Leben geschenkt hast
Triffst du nicht mit deinen Energieorbs die toten Bäume oder Tiere verschwinden diese einfach im Nirvana.

Dann der L.E.A.F. Suit
es könnte so schön sein, allerdings wird einem nur in bestimmten Situationen ein wirklich interessantes Upgrade gewährt.
Man kann unendlich lange schneller laufen, höher springen und einiges mehr.
Man beschleunigt nur wenn es bergab geht, oder wenn eine Rampe vor einem ist. Oder wenn eine Rampe auf dem Hügel ist und du bergauf laufen musst. Meeh.

Vor jeder neuen Herausforderung findest du genau was du suchst!
Oh die Klippe ist zu hoch? Ah hier direkt vor der Klippe ist das Upgrade welches du brauchst.

Da ist Wasser und du kommst nicht weiter?
Eine Kiste! Hiermit kannst du für begrenzte Zeit über Wasser laufen! Mach das noch 10 mal, damit sich das Upgrade auch lohnt! Gut das vorher solche Herausforderungen nicht da waren.
Dazu noch folgendes: Es wird gesagt man kann nicht in das Wasser, da der Anzug zu schwer ist. Ok akzeptiere ich.
Aber wenn einem ein Upgrade gewährt wird um über Wasser zu laufen, ist dies doch eher der Geschwindigkeit zu verdanken und nicht der Energie die der Anzug noch hat (Vorher gab eine keine zeitliche Begrenzung für die Upgrades, nur Energiekosten)

Das Spiel will soviel innehaben und doch wirkt alles nur hineingezwängt als hätte jemand gesagt: Macht alles rein und guckt mal was passiert.





SPOILER!!





Die Story handelt vom gierigen Militär, dass den Lifeseed besorgt hat um unendlich Energie daraus zu schlagen um den Krieg zu fördern. Punkt. Alle 1000 Jahre könnte der Lifeseed die komplette Erde auseinanderreissen und ist das Werkzeug ultimativer Kraft und Schlüssel zur Weltmacht.
Wir wandeln jetzt also auf den Spuren der Vergangenheit und hören und Audiologs an während wir auf der Suche nach dem Lifeseed sind.
Wir hören auch die Stimme von einem der Wissenschaftler, der nach und nach immer verrückter nach der Weltherrschaft wird.

Das ist keine Story, die ich nicht schonmal irgendwie gehört habe. Wir ich vorher gesagt hatte: Klischeebehaftet.
Allerdings sind die Elemente und Schlüsselteile im Spiel durchaus etwas womit man arbeiten könnte.
Diese Sache sehe ich allerdings eher in einem Puzzle Adventure oder einem Jump and Run.
Besonder das Handling des L.E.A.F. Suits.

Ich könnte das Spiel so zusammenfassen: Die Welt ist sich seiner eigenen Regeln nicht treu und möchte alles, kann aber wenig.

Ich bin eigentlich noch lange nicht fertig, möchte euch allerdings nicht weiter mit meiner Meinung auf den Nerv gehen.
Ich hoffe ich konnte meine Meinung gut rüberbringen.

PS: Ich fühl mich hier grade etwas fies, aber gerecht fies.

25916309.review:
It's an OK game. For those that like game that let you move fast, it's like Sonic the Hedghog mixed with Tribes ascend, except not as good as either.

The movement has that very irritating "Bounciness" where if you are running really fast and hit, say, a 3 inch rock, you will go sailing 30ft in the air. This isn't usually that big of a deal, but at one point the game literally has you speed boosting over large moguls, and instead of running, you just keep flying off and have to repeatedly build up your speed.

You also die in like an Inch of water. If you miss a jump by a hair (which is hard to do because your speed is always changing and it's hard to get a reference point) your big toe will touch the water and think it's to cold, causing you to instantly die.

Every character in this game is also dumb as a sack of bricks. This is especially bad when the main character pops up one of his box blurbs that just states LITERALLY what we already just heard. EX: Audio log "I am going to betray someone." Cue our character poping up one of their moronic statements "I wonder if that person was planning on betraying someone?" This is never worse than the main point of the story. I'm going to put it in spoiler tags, but It's seriously not even a spoiler if you have wached any movie focused on a magical forest in your life: [spoiler]Early on we find that they are trying to make weapons for the war using the magic spirit energy from the forest. When things start to die, OBVIOUSLY IT'S THE BIG LIFE SUCKING REACTOR YOU BUILT IN THE MIDDLE OF THE DARN PLACE!!! [/spoiler] the fact that it takes hours for every character to come to this conclusion is downright PAINFUL!

The gameplay is pretty fun though. Other than the afformentioned bouncing problem, it flows pretty nicely. It would have benifitted without collectables, as collecting things really breaks the pace which is supposed to be really fast and kenetic. The grapaling hook is pretty bad though. It could have searved as more of a hookshot/blink type transportation, zooming from point A to point B and would have felt fine, or even just a normal rope/lasso, but instead we get this weird rubber band... thing, where you move in a streight line directly from where you are standing, past the anchor point, and then bungie chord back. It just feels bad!

I never finished the game as for some reason in the prison area a door shut permenantly behind me (there is no reason there should be a door there) and when I climbed over a mountain looking for collectables, I ended up on the other side of it, not being able to open it. 

Maybe I'll go back and play it one day, but right now, I wouldn't recommend this game unless it was on sail for less than $8

Unique game that may not be for everyone.

Valley is a very unique first person platformer with very light shooting elements. Its story has some highpoints and tackles interesting subject matter, but is not enough to hold the game afloat by itself. The transversal System is though.

The so called LEAF suit is actually great fun to use. The maps and levels are quite varied and almost always exhilarating. The developers have done a fantastic job creating unique gameplay, unique themes and a great atmosphere. 

Its last strength and weakness is its length. Maybe 2-4 hours depending on the person. I ran through it pretty fast at 2.5 hours. The game never outstays its welcome, and keeps things fresh, but to those looking for a long atmospheric game may find the ending abrupt.

I really enjoyed the game. Hope you do too.

25895849.review:
The Kotaku review listed here on the store page for Valley says: "“A Moment Of Pure Movement Bliss, Courtesy Of Valley”.

Having played through the game, they aren't kidding. They're wrong though: there are many moments of pure movement bliss. I don't normally pay attention to blurbs, considering them to be about as useful as a jelly brick, so imagine my surprise when, while I was playing, I was in pure awe at the sheer fun of the game. Just running along at insane speeds, afraid to blink lest I miss something, leaping across chasms and flying through the air like some beast...

Valley's a short game. As I write I've got 15.5 hours logged, about a third of which is hunting for missed collectibles. For all that it's not very long to play through it, it's rich in story. Some minimal combat scattered here and there to break things up, but it's the least part of the game. What's fun is [i]moving[/i]. I don't want to go too much into it so as to not spoil the surprises, but this game encourages you to [i]speed[/i]. And it's sheer bliss the whole time. Imagine, travelling (according to the game) at 110 miles per hour and suddenly hitting a slight upwards ramp, only to find yourself soaring one hundred feet in the air without even having jumped, passing over gigantic trees, slowly returning to the ground like you're coming down at an extremely low orbit, and then landing still at top speed and charging down a hillside only to [b]do it again and again[/b]...

Doesn't sound like much to base a game on, but it's pure fun, and it keeps bringing me back. Best of all, once you're near the end of the game, you get to explore all the old areas all over again, going over the places you missed and discovering all new secrets that make the game even better. And since it's a wide open world instead of claustrophobic hallways (most of the time), then you'll have plenty to explore to find all those tiny little secrets.

Which is a bit of a downside. There are, barring 'upgrades' for the L.E.A.F. suit, two types of collectibles. One is trivially easy to get and can even be farmed beyond what you'd ever need, and the other one is scattered across everywhere in everything. You need 70 out of the 80 of them, as there are apparently ten extra, but when your collectibles are kept in little boxes that are insanely easy to miss when you're moving at blurred speeds, soaring through the air, unable to see what's on the ground or behind that inconvenient rock or on that distant island that you missed when you blinked... the collecting is a bit tedious. The game is about speed and movement, and to enjoy it you have to go really fast to get places, and then stop. Kind of kills the buzz.

Still, those moments of bliss are worth it. The full price might be a tad much, but I don't regret the 30% off I bought it at.

Astute readers will have noticed I don't really mention any of the other gameplay elements, like the health/life system or the various suit upgrades. The former's not super important and the latter is best left to discover as you go. I know I'm casually dismissing something that's constantly used, but it's simply [i]there[/i], and for the upgrades I wouldn't want the surprises spoiled if it were me! Half the pleasure is suddenly being able to do something amazing and using it to the fullest.

It's a fun game. Especially if you've done some Tribes "skiiing" and loved it. It's that on overdrive. Wait for a sale and give it a shot. It's short lived, but it has moments of pure ecstasy. Nobody was more surprised to see that come true than me.

25894787.review: Alright, I just finished the game, and I very much enjoyed playing it. Valley ain't super challenging nor original, to put it nicely. 25884015.review:
Wow!  I really enjoyed this game!  It's hard to believe some of the other reviewers were playing the same game!  For one thing, I can't imagine any possible way anyone could play this game in less that 10 hours!  Maybe a replay where you run as fast as possible and don't try to find any items along the way.  I'm not sure how long I played (doesn't show!?) but I know it must have been close to 15-20 hours, and I thought I was going at a fair pace too, but then I'm more of a casual player than an expert gaming master.

This is a first person adventure game with a little bit of everything - running, jumping, a sort of puzzle solving in path decisions, grav boots, grappling hooks, aqua boots, and super high speed running - which I really enjoyed!  The graphics are top notch for the most part, and has no feeling of a rushed quickie game (save for the ending).  The maps are well-designed, but occasionally seem a bit too large and physically stretched out near the end, but not too much.  Interesting site-seeing, unusual topographic artifacts, good story, a beautiful score, and overall a very good and classy game that would be well worth a AAA title cost, for me.

On a 10 point scoring system, I'm giving this game a solid 8.

A higher score would be given for a more complete ending (it's a little abrupt!), a more forgiving respawn system (because the grappling effect can be very tricky in quick sequencing), better fade-outs for the score changes, and a little less rambling around, and a little more getting to the point (I'd rather have a tight game with less fluff, than a longer game that felt like it had pointless padding).  I'd like to have seen a bit more resolution and explanation for some of the interesting creature and forest issues, which could have been made in to a nice ending with more closure, a little denouement, if you will.

So if adventure gaming with less shooting than a typical FPS, exceptional graphics, good story, level design as good as most AAA titles, interesting and unusual gaming elements that lasts a fair amount of playing time - I would highly recommend this game, and if it's on sale - it's an absolute must buy and try, IMO.

25878358.review:
This was a great game that I just bought when it showed up on a sale.  I had never heard of it and found it really quite enjoyable.   The developers made a great game that is worth your investment.  I highly recommend this game if you like a fun FPS action adventure game.  Here is my breakdown of what I think of all the parts:

The Graphics and visluals were very good and well done.  My only issue was vysnc did not always work 100% so I got some screen tearing at time but not enough to make it awful.   I loved the world they created.

The sound and music in the game was also done well too.  Some times it was even down right creepy.  They did a good job with the sounds of your metal feet when running over different materials.

The gameplay is where this game was a blast to play. It was so much fun to run and jump in this game.  I really enjoyed giving life back to trees and animals.  You find upgrades to your LEAF suit and get rewarded for looking everywhere.  There is combat in this game and was not too hard either.  The death mechanic was a new one in that when you die so does some of the world, so keep giving back life to make up for it.

The story is good and told through papers and film reels throughout the game world.  I found it fun looking for the next piece of the puzzle and watching it unload as you progressed in the game.

I cannot believe how much fun I had.

25876716.review:
This is a very wierd and different game. Great story, which is not too unoriginal.
I had a lot of fun in this short, but good game.

You run around in some WW2 secret exoskeleton, which you upgrade as you go with the story.
The upgrades either improves ur exo, energy or adds a new ability. This ensures that the game constantly
changes, while keeping its core gameplay. You will be swinging in the high trees, jumping kilometers, run over water and 
ride old trainrails. I was worried at first, but the game introduces combat, where you shoot enemies. It is basic, but tons of fun, as you fly around (You can't fly).

When you die you will get revived, but the world will die around you (trees, plants), which is a really cool element.

The game is very good and for 13€ (on sale) it is a rip off. The achievements and collectables/upgrades, make it fun to do a re-run. 

I would love if the Devs took everything this game had and made a online FPS. With these mechanics, you would get a insane online FPS game. And some huge maps and a flag (CTF) and let the player join a 16vs16 match.
The game reminds a bit of Tribes. Just a tiny bit.

25876427.review:
I give this game a postive review (6/10) for a few reasons:
1. I now know how Sonic the Hedgehog feels - especially on the rails.
2. The walk on walls magnetic boots mechanic is cool.
3. I bought it mainly for my 12 year old nephew. He LOVED it.
4. The respawn mechanic is original with me tied to the environment.
5. Cost only $14.
6. Visuals are beautiful which is why I mentioned #5 below.
Things I wish they would have improved:
1. I could only grapple where they wanted me to.
2. Created more capable, varied opponents. I feel like a Jedi slicing basic republic battle droids.
3. It was too easy to follow the compass waypoint and sort of sleep run through a level.
4. I rarely ran out of energy, never ran out of "acorns" and had more "medalians" than I knew what to do with.
5. Didn't make this for VR. It would have been AWESOME in VR.
One minor annoyance: the "ping ping ping ping" of the menu. No way to turn that off.

25851133.review:
Valley is a good game and a bad game rolled into one, with high highs, lower lows, and very little middle ground to speak of.

You start the game walking around, soaking up a bit of scenery, watching your character's laughably unimportant thoughts on screen. 

Then, you get the Power Legs. I know the game calls the Power Legs the "LEAF Suit", but the acronym that it stands for (as told to you in brief cutscene that manages to last far too long & be far too aggravating) is such an absolute insult to the player's intelligence that I'm pretty sure each word knocks a point off of the IQ of anyone who hears it.

But anyway.

Now you have the Power Legs.

You have the TOUCH.

You have the POWER.

You are the Flash mixed with Usain Bolt mixed with perhaps a certain type of land mammal with spines that is known on occasion for being expedient & fighting evil doctors who wanna bend nature to their will or whatever. (This is a very relevant comparison, as the game's main antagonist ends up being every bit as cartoonishly evil in his nefarious plots to harness the power of the Valley to accomplish his own nefarious plans- namely, making a literal Spirit Bomb via the power of Nut. Did I mention that? Your character's motivation for this journey, as explained in the opening cutscene, is that he's searching for the Life Nut. God, I wish I was making this shit up.)

So you roll around at the speed of sound for a bit and almost entirely give up on looking at the pretty scenery because it's flashing by too goddamn fast for you to make anything out anyway, and it's a blast. 

Then, you start climbing a mountain for some reason, which is not at all conducive to going fast at all, so it's pretty lame. You get a grappling hook, but it's a shitty grappling hook, & any game with a shitty grappling hook is almost always a steaming load, something Valley doesn't entirely manage to redeem itself of.

Since the grappling hook sucks, you may realize some of the game's advertized mechanics do indeed exist- namely, if you die, you respawn at the cost of some of the Valley's "health"- but they're almost entirely inconsequential as you can refill this health bar within seconds of respawning. They say that dire consequences will befall you should you sacrifice the Valley to save yourself, but I'm pretty sure nobody will never find out what said consequences are unless they deliberately hurtle themselves off of a mountain a few dozen times to do so.

Oh yeah, you climbed the mountain. Now you get to play "wander slowly through the dingy corridors for far too goddamn long" and "feel absolutely none of the tension the game is desperately trying to build because there's literally nothing here" while the game's shitty, shitty story unfolds itself. Thankfully the devs were kind enough to add an option to skip story elements entirely when replaying maps, so you're not forced to suffer through the---the---Shut up shut up SHUT UP YOU ARE A SHITTY CHARACTER WITH SHITTY MOTIVATIONS AND I DON'T WANNA HEAR YOU TALKING IN MY EAR WITHOUT MY CONSENT ABOUT YOUR ABSOLUTELY MEANINGLESS AND POORLY WRITTEN GARBAGE THAT /ISN'T EVEN HAPPENING RIGHT NOW/, SHUT UP, GO AWAY, THIS IS HARRASSMENT, AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA

...

So yeah. Dingy corridors. The game wants to be Bioshock or something all of a sudden. It sucks.

Then you get to the SPEEEEED TUUUUUBES.

Wait, maybe something happened between then and now? I don't remember. 

SPEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEED TUUUUUUUUUUUUUBES. 

Highlight of the whole game, in my opinion, and even though you're in a grungy underground tunnel, some of the game's best creative direction shines through here. Not just in the art, but in the music. You're not just going fast, you're SUPERCHARGED, sparks are flying all around you, the music knows exactly what you're doing at all time, a high-tempo piece that gets more intense the faster you go & swells and crashes perfectly in time with your danger-filled jumps over giant chasms & really enforces the feeling that YES, this is what the game is about, it is about being fast and awesome and everything else is just filler, just RUN! 

And then the Speed Tube Fun Time is over & everything else is kind of depressing in comparison, aside from any other SPEEEEED TUUUUUBE encounters you may have. 

Let's see, uhh, next, you uhh... There's something about walking on walls, and uhh... can I go back to the Speed Tubes yet? Please? Oh, I can run on water for a bit now if I have enough speed built up? That's cool, I guess...

And then you do... something... (I can't even remember, it felt so inconsequential) to fix the things Mr. Evil Cartoon Villain messed up some 60 years before you ever arrived on the scene; and your character walks away from it all empty handed- and I mean entirely empty handed, he even discards his Power Legs, because he's apparently a stupid jackass who hates fun- and... game over. It's done, folks. You can replay everything, you can hunt for tokens that unlock doors in a temple on one level that apparently contains (useless) bonus upgrades- I only bothered to hunt down enough tokens to open the first door, which gave me unlimited use of the shitty grappling hook that was absolutely no problem to use in the first place before giving up. Maybe the other doors had something a little less depressing, but I personally don't intend to find out.

"So", you may ask, "why the Thumbs Down? It seems like outside of its problems you absolutely love the game!" To which I must say, well, yeah. As I said, the good things are great and the bad things are utter shit. But the biggest factor into my thumbs down has to be the play time. With 23/30 achievements unlocked, nearly fully upgraded Power Legs, as well as several secrets & aforementioned Bonus Tokens, I've only spent 7 hours in the game. 2 of those hours were probably spent replaying the SPEEEEED TUUUUUBES. The game is depressingly short. A straight run through of the game with minimal time spent upgrade-hunting & replaying the SPEEEEED TUUUUUBES would probably last about 3-4 hours, tops. Maybe even less. I've probably spent longer writing this review than it'd take to do a direct runthrough. And at $20, that's not the best money-to-game ratio you could ask for, and it compounds the negative aspects of the game into absolutely crippling problems that the positives don't balance out, but instead end up leaving you feeling short-changed & making you wish there was more. Because what this game does right, it does VERY right.

25850118.review:
There's a Kotaku review listed, at least as I write this: "A moment of pure movement bliss."  Unfortunately, it was really just a moment.

It was great game, while it lasted.  Unfortunately, it came to an abrupt halt, and only lasted a touch over three hours.  As others have said, it's beautiful... for the parts where you're in the open, which are few and far between.

There's just so much wasted potential here.  It's a good premise, but it desperately needs more to the story, something to resolve the valley's history.  I'd also like to see more of the open valley it's set in, rather than the places inside it.  Without that, I just can't recommend it for the price.  Maybe pick it up on sale - just remember it will only last a few hours.  A wonderful few hours, but far too short, and far too unresolved.

25841276.review:
"Sonic the HedgeGod"
- Jim Sterling

Or as I'd like to call it, mechanical satyr running simulator 2016. Personally, I like it just for the storyline and atmosphere it sets. It's a fascinating tale it spins of life, death, jealousy, human hubris, victory at all cost and love.  The music is top notch.

As for the mechanics? Not as satisfying as I had hoped. The game has a marvelous sense of movement. You really feel like you have mechanical legs, landing with a satisfying metal thud and leaping across hills, lakes and chasms is utterly exilerating, but there's very few situations where the game's marvelous sense of movement counts. 80% of the time in this already very short adventure, you're just trudging through bland rooms and while there are very memorable moments, god knows why the Dev didn't seek to repeat those more often. Furthermore, the shooting and enemy mechanics are non existant.


I'm absolutely torn between these two qualities and if I had the option, I'd leave this review without a negative or positive recommendation. As I'm forced to do so however, and the game stands at a 96% Steam approval rating at the time of this writing, which I think is too high for its flaws, I feel forced to give it a thumbs down. 

What a tale though.

25784575.review:
[b]Персональный рейтинг - 4,5 из 10[/b]

Главному герою Valley не сиделось, и он отправился в район Скалистых гор в попытках разгадать тайны этого места, уходящие корнями в прошлое. В загадочной долине он обнаруживает удивительный костюм L.E.A.F., позволяющий ему прыгать как кузнечик и носиться как гепард, а еще находит приключения на свою задницу, заброшенные лаборатории времен Второй Мировой войны и километры полупустых территорий. 

В костюм, помимо гидравлических протезов, встроена любопытная функция "взять жизнь/забрать жизнь", но она не оказывает никакого воздействия на игровой процесс. А ведь какие могли бы открыться перспективы! Например, можно было бы дать жизнь дереву и получить возможность пройти по его ветвям. Или забрать жизнь у какого-нибудь папоротника или плюща и открыть потайной проход, который до этого скрывали ветви растения. Увы, но разработчики решили иначе и пошли по пути наименьшего сопротивления. Дав жизнь растению или животному, мы просто теряем одну единичку энергии. Соответственно, высосав жизненные соки из растения или одного из представителей местной фауны, мы... правильно - получаем одну единичку энергии! Вот и вся система! Авторы стращают, что запасы энергии у нас небезграничны и она может закончиться. Все так, но даже если резервы окажутся исчерпаны, мы можем абсолютно без труда раздобыть себе новые. По округе практически всегда валяются энергетические сферы, которые восполняют наш запас ресурса. Сферы, что интересно, появляются заново через некоторое время после подбора. Наконец, энергию, как уже было упомянуто выше, можно черпать из живых существ или деревьев, коих в округе предостаточно. Но даже если ни зверья, ни флоры рядом нет, то авторы заботливо ставят в локации несколько генераторов, откуда мы можем пополнять энергетические запасы. Генераторы, уж простите за каламбур, тоже, кстати, генерируют "ману" аккурат после разрядки, стоит нам подождать с минуту. То есть нехватка в ресурсе мы не испытываем вообще никак. Не будь в игре функции дать/забрать жизнь, то игра не потеряла бы абсолютно ничего, ибо на геймплей она не влияет практически никоим образом.

Можно целый час скакать по горам и холмам как горный козел и не найти ничего, кроме пустых скал, обтянутых мутными текстурами. Игра, которая побуждает нас исследовать огромные локации, не может предложить ничего, чтобы как-то мотивировать игрока изучать окрестности. В большинстве случаев там пусто! Присутствуют некоторые ответвления, которые можно с чистой совестью отнести к секретам ввиду того, что спрятаны они действительно неплохо, но таковых единицы и зачастую сразу ясно, что тот или иной туннель/пещера/коридор ведет в секретную область.  

Наплодить лиги скучных территорий разработчики смогли, а вот сделать процесс исследования интересным, наделить его смыслом - уже нет. В Valley практически ничего не происходит - это пустой и мертвый мир. Верхом режиссерского замысла для меня стала выкатившаяся на меня из ниоткуда пустая банка не то из-под консервов, не то из-под шпината.

Иногда авторы дают экшена и напускают на героя каких-то лесных духов. Мы вольны отбиваться от них, пуляясь в них той самой энергией. Разумеется, подобные включения выглядят совершенно дико и ничего кроме отторжения не вызывают - экшен из Valley никакой.

Теоретически из Valley могла бы выйти неплохая адвенчура, сюжет тут обставлен весьма недурно. На худой конец можно было бы соорудить что-то вроде раннера, где герой проходит уровни на время - в игре есть элементы, которые неплохо подходят для такой задачи. Увы, кудесники из Blue Isle Studios выбрали самый амбициозный и, как следствие, самый неудачный вариант. Во всяком случае при вышеперечисленных раскладах происходящее не вызывало бы такую скуку. 

Единственное, за кого становится действительно обидно - это за композитора. Человек проделал великолепную работу, саундтрек прекрасен и делает по крайней мере 70% атмосферы. Жаль только, что игра банально не дотягивает до уровня музыкального сопровождения - композиции превосходят саму Valley как минимум на две головы. Работа такого уровня идеально подошла бы для какой-нибудь породистой RPG, а не для кривоватого полуплатформера про исследование того, чего нет, кем на данный момент является Valley. 

Фактически все, что заставляет проходить Valley - это музыка, неплохая история и поиск секретов. Если для вас данного набора качеств достаточно, то можете с осторожностью попробовать.

25774089.review:
Valley is a fairly short (about 5 hours) first person... game... thing... It's kind of hard to pin it to an exact genre, but I suppose it's a mix between FPS and platformer.  It's probably not going to blow your mind, but I found it a lot of fun.  Basically, you're given a suit of power armor that has all kinds of weird abilities (like super fast running and jumping) and asked to traverse a bunch of levels with it.

If I had to pick one flaw, it would be the lack of difficulty.  This isn't really an issue for me, I don't mind "easy" games, but if you're looking for a challenge, this probably isn't going to provide it.  The shooting is pretty rudimentary and you get enough health upgrades to make most encounters fairly easy.  The platforming is also pretty easy, and though there are a few instant death pits that might get you, the penalty for dying is pretty light.

However, while it might not be super challenging, I thought it was pretty fun.  You're given enough abilities that make moving around the world feel exciting and interesting.  While the platforming didn't make me sweat, it did get me to say "wheeeee" a bunch of times.  It's hard to describe, but I defintitely found a lot to like in the movement mechanics in this game.

The story is decent, if a bit cliche.  The visuals can be surprisingly gorgeous at times, and the soundtrack is really nice as well.  The level design is kind of middling, sometimes being really exhilirating to move through but boring to look at, and sometimes being really pretty to look at but kind of tedious to actually traverse.  I did like the touch that allows you to choose if the main character is male or female; since the game is in first person, it doesn't change much aside from the  "oof" noises you make when you get hit, but it's a nice feature.

Overall, I really liked this one.  A surprisingly entertaining and polished title from a fairly small studio that had me grinning  every time I booted it up.

25770852.review:
This game isn't nearly as fast as I was expecting.  The game opens in a big, hilly valley, so it's easy to build up momentum and you've got a lot of space to run in.  But after a little bit you end up in a much more industrial setting, so you cant really move much.  There's a few areas where you get to go pretty fast, but they're all pretty on rails, sometimes literally.

The game's more of a point and click adventure than a platformer.  And even then, I can hardly remember any of the puzzles.  You spend most of the time picking up notes and listening to audio tapes.
The story was okay, a bit of a cliche.  Evil WW2 scientists use magic to try to build super weapons, nothing really new.  
Combat is also pretty braindead, enemies are all really weak and simple to fight.

I had fun, but I don't think the game is worth 20 dollars.  Maybe 5 or 10.
If the devs made a game with these mechanics, but focused more on the level design, I think they'd have a real winner.

25695203.review:
Buy

Gameplay:
you have a suit (called L.E.A.F.) that lets you have abilities, as you go through the game you earn upgrades that allow you to do feats like grapple and jump really high. This greats an experience where you are trying to  chain the moves that your suit gives into a fast paced experience. It's actually fun to just travel through the world.

Story
You are told the story mostly through notes, that give extra details about what is happening, and who is involved. I enjoyed it, but many people won't care I can imagine. But it's up to you if you really want to delve in deep.

Longevity
The game is really short I think I clocked in at 3 hours. It feels like it is 1/3 the game done then its over (soon after you get your last upgrade).

Final
I loved it, even though it was short, it was addictive and fun, and the asking price is worth it in my opinion.

25529756.review:
Поиграл я в эту игру от  Blue Isle Studios (создателей Slender: The Arrival) и вот что могу сказать... Я почему-то дважды сомневался по поводу игры, стоит ли брать её или не стоит, добавлял её в список желаемого, удалял и опять добавлял. В итоге определился и взял. Собственно, не зря взял.
Игра очень понравилась. Это динамичный квест с красивой музыкой и хорошей графикой. Играть приходится за мужчину или женщину (зависит от выбора), облачённого в специальный экзоскелет времён войны. Особенность экзоскелета в том, что он может возвращать к жизни (или отбирать жизнь) растения и животных, расходуя (или накапливая) при этом энергию. Но и способен возвращать нас к жизни, в случае гибели, "принеся в жертву" что-нибудь живое. Факт того, что своими смертями мы постепенно убиваем всё окружающее, очень завораживает, но в то же время вызывает и грусть. Хотя ничто не мешает вернуть к жизни то, что погибло ради нас, если есть немного лишней энергии. К тому же экзоскелет имеет прокачку.
Локации в игре разнообразные, начиная от ярких красивых гор и полян и заканчивая тёмными старыми зданиями и научными комплексами. Некоторые из них я проходил ради достижений, а некоторые просто из-за того, что охота пройти определённые участки снова. По железнодорожным тонелям я бы с удовольствием бегал всю вечность.
Любителям пособирать всякие светящиеся шарики, поискать упавшие желуди и разбросанные записки, с ветром рассекать яркие игровые пейзажи с красивой фауной и растительностью рекомендую поиграть.

Dieses Game hat leider bei weitem nicht die Aufmerksamkeit erhalten, die es verdient. Die Grafik, die Musik! ja die ganze Spielatmosphäre ist einfach spitze! Die Story ist interessant und sehr gut in Szene gesetzt und man blickt so nach und nach in die Geschehnisse und Geheimnisse des Tales ein.

Das Gameplay ist einfach nur Spitze, es hat sich noch nie so gut angefühlt sich einfach durch die WElt zu bewegen, der hohen fast grenzenlosen Mobilität sei dank. Der Shooterpart wenn man ihm so nennen will (es gibt ab und an Gegner die man besiegen muss) fällt sehr simpel aus. Er passt zwar thematisch in die Welt fällt aber SEHR leicht aus und ich bin nicht einmal an einem der Gegenr gestorben...nicht mal ansatzweise.
 Der Spielfocus liegt ganz klar im Entdecken der fantastischen Welt denn in einem knallharten Überlebensspiels, also Freunde des Dauersterbens sowie der Herausforderungen werden sich vllt. etwas im Spiel unterfordert fühlen aber das Spiel hatte nie den Anspruch ein Pakur-Dark Souls zu sein.

 Mit etwa 8 Stunden Gameplay sofern man sich mit der Erkundung der Areale auch Zeit lässt und versucht so viele Geheimnisse wie möglich zu finden, fällt das Spiel in meinen Augen weder zu Kurz aus, dass man sich unzufrieden fragt, ob es schon alles sei, noch ist es zu lang und ich hatte an keiner Stelle das Gefühl dass dasd Spiel künstlich gestreckt wurde oder dass mir das Gameplay langsam zu einseitig wird. 

Kurz und knapp ein echter Geheimtipp den ich wirklich jeden unabhängig vom Spielertyp ans Herz legen kann!

Its like they made an original sonic game. Game play is there, the story is there, and the graphics are most certainly there. 
I would call this an adventure/exploring/platforming game. You get rewarded for exploring but its not truly necessary to advance in the game as it gives you enough to keep going. You never feel like you get bogged down cause you may have missed 1 secret early on. For the puzzle/platforming they are just hard enough that you feel satisfied when you figure it our but not so hard you have to go look up a walk though. The music also makes the game great! It matches perfectly with whats happening as your going, from a slow stroll in the rolling hills to the high speed corridor running it makes it all that much better.

No game is with out fault. I felt like if i didn't stop at even little spot I'd miss something or an upgrade or a piece of lore/fluff/story. Its very bothersome when your in the middle of a high speed run and stop just to have a look around. My other gripe is the swinging/chain, it may have been user error but i ended up falling off so many times or just not having enough monument. Often Id only use it if there were no other ways around and even then Id try to break the area just to avoid it. Thankfully it doesn't come in to play often.

All and all I'd give the game an 8/10.

25481803.review:
Wow, wow, wow.

If you want a gritty first person shooter, this isn't it.  But if you want a game that is completely engrossing from a visual, auditory, and story level, this is exactly what you want.  The game is on the short side, maybe 8-10 hours (although you'll want to play it more than once!), but I wish more developers would focus on telling a good story and backing it perfectly with visuals and audio rather than just stacking on level after level of repetition.  

Every minute of this game feels new and different, nothing feels like the rinse/repeat of so many other games, and the enjoyment you'll get from it is well worth the low price.

Highest recommendations from a very picky gamer.

25413890.review:
Prior to it's release, I heard absolutely nothing about Valley. Didn't even know it existed. A friend of mine raved about the game the day it was released, and I got it the next day.
I can't believe there wasn't hype for this game.

The graphics of this game are gorgeous. Unfortunately, they are also a bit hard on some computers. I am stuck on a laptop that, even on medium settings, lags a bit with the graphics.

The music is also beautiful. If you are into game soundtracks, I highly recommend this one. The soundtrack is also on Youtube, if you want to check it there before committing to it.

The gameplay is so, so satisfying.
The game incorporates some physics a lot of games don't, such as accelerating you if you are moving downhill, which in turn has an enormous impact on your flight distance if you jump. As a result, you get to soar through some very gorgeous scenery.
The life/death mechanic is something I haven't seen before in a game, [spoiler] and though I feel like they could have done a bit more with the life-taking mechanic [/spoiler], I rather liked it.
Combat is not particularly challenging, as this game is more focused on story and atmosphere. If you need a game to punish you to like it, Valley may not be for you. For those of us who are not masochists, this should not be a problem.

While I am not finished with the game, if you explore as you play, this could be a longer game (I had some friends try out the game, so my current play time is a few hours shorter than what is listed). Someone who speed runs this game could potentially finish in only a couple hours. Take that as you will.
---

Overall, if you like exploration games with fun gameplay and story, I HIGHLY recommend this game (and soundtrack). My only warning is to make sure your computer can handle the graphics.

25370393.review:
Valley is a fun and exhilarating first person adventure game that really hit the mark for me.  If you're a casual gamer like myself, this game will be sure to be a hit!  I just completed my Let's Play series and it's available [url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL_8AuschIyY1DbEFilKjqse8ZkguOvOF4]Here on YouTube[/url] if you'd like to check it out - including the Medallion Temple reveal!

On to a bit more thorough of a review.  On my first playthrough of the game, it was very easy to get engrossed in the storyline.  Any enemies you encounter are fairly easy to dispose of, but add a level of stress to the game that makes it just a little more challenging - and really embraces the thoughts of the characters you read about in the notes along the way.

I felt particularly taken in by the way the main story is told in a narrative, at critical points in the game and it was done very well.  At points, the sound effects alone are enough to get the heart really pumping!  All of that being said, I did have to go back and re-play a majority of the game to get some of the medallions, and it was still a riot.

I think I developed stockholme syndrome and a touch of paranoia in doing so, though.

The only thing I didn't really like about the game is that there are certain things that are generally anti-climactic.  When you expect to finally have reached a point in the story line, it gets pushed back just a little further out.  No big deal, really.  It added a little suspense.

I logged 20 hours on this game and ended up with 25/30 achievements.  There's still room for some replay, but I'm a bit burnt out!

For the $20?  A+ game, and Blue Isle did an incredible job.  Thank you for your hard work, and I hope that it has paid off for you guys!

https://youtu.be/I2gPKLeytH8

Valley is a first person Action Adventure game where you play a faceless and nameless Archaeologist who has set out to discover the Mythic Life Seed, an object so powerful it could destroy the world. To aid you on your journey, you find a L.E.A.F Suit, a powerful Exoskeleton with a wide range of abilities.

Through the course of your journey you uncover a long-dead experiment surrounding the L.E.A.F project that was underway the same time as the Manhattan Project in order to help the Americans win World War 2 in a story that is delivered in combination between Text and decently performed voice acting.
PROS:
-	Beautifully done world
-	Well-crafted levels
-	Interesting story
-	Fun gameplay
CONS:
-	Lackluster Combat
-	Yet another game with Wendigos
-	Short (less than 4 hours)
-	Low replay value

I gave this game a 7 out of 10. If it were longer and the combat mechanics more in-depth it would have scored an 8 easily. Still, with it’s flaws it’s a fun game and I have no qualms recommending it.

25355355.review:
Edit: Nominated for Steam's "Whoooaaaaaaa, dude!” Award. The shortcomings aside, this is the only game I've played in the past... year(?) that seriously blew me away.

A great game, for sure. I've literally never had this much fun just running about without giving a damn about where I was supposed to go. Just enjoying the astonishingly beautiful environment and the feeling of almost flying through the area. It's just wonderful.
The sad part? The game isn't just about that. When I started exploring dark facilities and shooting angry enemies, I didn't enjoy things as much anymore. Which was disappointing.
All in all... It feels like someone took several really good aspects and crammed them into this relatively short game. Which technically isn't a bad thing, but I would have preferred to see a bit more of each aspect, instead of having the game move on to the next one. The huge area shortly after one acquires the LEAF suit was my favourite part of the game, as described at the start of this review, but why was it pretty much the only one like it?
Despite that, I still consider this a great game. One that could be better, but still.

25312365.review: Valley offers a gorgeous setting and unique gameplay. A refreshing experience with an intriguing storyline along with matching score that increases the Valley experience from incredible to an artistic masterpiece.

25305934.review:
Valley is a First Person Adventure game created by Blue Isle Studios, the developers that brought us Slender: The Arrival. In this game you play an archaelogist (able to choose gender) who goes on an expedition to the Canadian Rockies to find the mythical Lifeseed, a mysterious artifact. When you arrive at your destination you discover you aren't the first one there. There are remnants of an old American WWII science team and WWII army units who used exosuits called the L.E.A.F. suits. Able to run incredibly fast, jump incredibly high, able to manipulate life & death itself, there is a lot you can do with the L.E.A.F. suit.

This is a game that's best played without knowing much about it going in. I didn't spoil anything in my description that you wouldn't have figured out in the first 5 minutes of playing or from the store page trailer. Part of the appeal of it to me personally was all the mystery and wonder of the game world Blue Isle Studios built. I won't talk too much more about the story but I will say that this game has a ton of platforming, secrets and suit upgrades. The game is also beautiful to look at and the soundtrack is perfect for it. The best words I could use to describe the soundtrack during some parts of the game is "enchanting" and "whimsical". The music is adaptive, meaning it changes with your actions. During certain parts, if you're running and jumping the music will change to reflect that. Lastly, this is NOT a walking simulator. There is a combat system in place that you will learn how to use fairly early on, as well as some really fast paced sections that are a treat to play through.

I highly recommend this game and it's definitely one of my favorites this year. It would have totally been out of sight, out of mind if I didn't watch Jim Sterling play the first 5 minutes of it so credit to him for turning me on to it. Game length averages anywhere from 4-6 hours if you breeze through it but it can last a few more hours than that if you look for all the secrets and go for all the achievements. You can return to any previous area you've been through via fast travel so there is absolutely nothing keeping you from going back and collecting everything. Whether you feel that length of game time is worth $20 I'll leave that up to you but I do not regret my full price purchase.
